column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Prisoners (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Students (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column9: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

In response they looted the Regeza market and ransacked the homes of the suspected ANR agents. The ANR agents have subsequently been arrested.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

Residents from surrounding villages gathered with spears, machetes and clubs to release the suspected thieves. Naval forces arrived in the town to reinforce police during the clashes.

column17: 3 people were killed and 3 others kidnapped after Ugandan ADF rebels attacked Mukoko, Beni and looted the town.

column6: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column17: 5 people were killed when ADF rebels attacked Kisiki and Maibo. Several houses were also looted.

column6: Military Forces of Burundi (2005-)

column6: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column17: ADF-NALU rebels attacked Oicha, killing 9 people with guns and machetes and wound 4 others. They also looted several houses.

column6: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column17: Violence by ADF-NALU rebels was reported in the town of Erengeti, nearby Beni town.

column17: 40 associate professors at Kinshasa University staged a sit-in to demand pay.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Simba)

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

The gunmen, believed to be part of a Mayi Mayi militia, then fled.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column17: Change to armed group: A new rebel group has formed in Eastern DRC with the aim of attacking Uganda. The group is composed of the remnants of the youth who were part of the attackers during tribal clashes that rocked Rwenzori region in July. The group has reportedly allied with Esyomango, the youth military wing of the Rwenzururu Kingdom.

column6: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column17: 30 people were killed and 9 injured during an ADF raid on the neighbourhoods and villages around Beni, including Ngadi. The attackers were said to have used machetes and clubs, and broken into and looted several houses.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

Judges at the Tribunal de Grande Instance (TGI), Kalamu Peace Court, and Tri-Peace Assossa courts joined the magistrates strike the following day, while the National Union of Magistrates of Congo (SYNAMAC) announced full support for the strike two days later.

column17: 4 youths arrested in Drdza village after 2 police were burned to death there, were found dead in the jail of the district prosecutor in Bunia. They were allegedly tortured to death or starved, but it is still unclear how they died. An investigation has been opened.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 4 people, including 2 Ugandans, were kidnapped by an unidentified armed group. They were later released.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column8: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column17: On 3 January 2015, FARDC and MONUSCO forces regained control of the town of Abia (Beni, Nord-Kivu) in Virunga National Park northeast of Beni, after heavy fighting with the ADF. 5 rebels were killed and 4 others injured.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column8: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column17: FARDC and MONUSCO soldiers have taken control of Mavume, ""an important position of the ADF"", after heavy fighting with the rebels. 11 rebels were killed during the fighting and 3 FARDC soldiers were injured.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: FARDC and MONUSCO soldiers have recovered all bases controlled by the FNL on the Uvira plateaus, and specifically around the town of Ruhoha. No casualties were taken by the joint forces, while casualties for the FNL were not reported. Provisional casualties were announced at 2 FNL fighters dead and 29 wounded during the operation.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Clashes broke out between residents of Kebya-Kamwanga and the police, which were only dispersed by the police firing their weapons into the air. Calm was returned by the arrival of FARDC soldiers. It is not clear what started the situation but allegedly a member of the security services was humiliating a resident, which led to the riot.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Health Workers (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Hundreds of employees of the Panzi General Hospital have protested outside the facilities of the Directorate General fo Taxes (DGI) against the freezing of assets of their hospital and collection of taxes on their income.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Arrests: Police arrested dozens of activists (""opponents of the regime of President Joseph Kabila"") who were distributing invitations to a meeting off the political opposition on Jan.11.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A journalist was stabbed by two unidentified armed men. He was seriously wounded.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Agreement: Nyanderema, the head of a Raia Mutomboki Mayi Mayi militia which bears his name, surrendered to FARDC forces in the locality of Luizi in Kabare, accompanied by 9 of his men bearing 12 weapons.

column6: Yatota Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Zambo Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 3 people were killed and several others injured by knives and firearms during a land dispute between the villages of Yatota and Zambo in Bumba locality. Police intervened to restore order shortly after.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: The National Press Union of the Congo staged a march in solidarity with the French press following the Charlie Hebdo attack in Paris. The march began in the Gombe commune of Kinshasa.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column8: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column17: On 10 January 2015, FARDC and MONUSCO forces took control of the Pilot and Issa camps of the ADF in Virungu National Park, near Halungupa (Beni, Nord-Kivu).

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 2 shells fell in farmers fields near the road leading to Kisangani. It is uncertain who fired them, but they destroyed ""several hectares of farmers fields"".

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: UNC: Union for the Congolese Nation; FIS: Front for Social Integration; MLC: Movement for the Liberation of Congo; UDPS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: About 300 people (including members of the UNC, MLC, UDPS, and Front for Social Integration, FIS) participated in an opposition march against amendments to the electoral law. The march was quickly dispersed with violence by police who beat protesters and fired tear gas. 15 people were wounded and 30 others arrested. The police also reportedly fired on protesters, some of whom had bullet wounds, including the President of the FIS. The police claim that the protesters were violent and threw stones, injuring 7 police officers and 4 Transco bus employees.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A student was hit by multiple bullets fired by police during the dispersal of an allegedly banned demonstration.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Opposition parties have continued to protest against the proposed electoral law. The police attempted to disperse protesters with tear gas and shots fired into the air.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: UDPS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column9: UDPS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column17: Two factions of UDPS clashed in front of their HQ in Mbuji-Mayi after dissident UDPS youth attempted to put up the flag of the ""presidential majority"". Afterwards, the dissident youth attacked the home of the Vice President of the UDPS youth league. In retaliation, youth league members attacked one of the dissident UDPS members houses with stones. Police intervened and arrested several people. At least 1 person was injured.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: FARDC soldiers have ""dislodged"" the Mayi Mayi militia led by Cheka from 4 localities in Walikale, including Mpofi, Luvungi, Kigoma and Kailenge.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: FARDC soldiers have ""dislodged"" the Mayi Mayi militia led by Cheka from 4 localities in Walikale, including Mpofi, Luvungi, Kigoma and Kailenge.

column17: FARDC soldiers have ""dislodged"" the Mayi Mayi militia led by Cheka from 4 localities in Walikale, including Mpofi, Luvungi, Kigoma and Kailenge.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: FARDC soldiers clashed with the Yakutumba Mayi Mayi militia, killing 2 militiamen, in Tulongye, near Lulimba. 1 FARDC soldier was killed as well.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: Fighting began between FARDC soldiers and FRPI militiamen in the village of Aveba, and spread to other villages in the chiefdom of Walendu Bindi (in Ituri), including Tchekele, Kaswara and Bavi. Thousands of people were displaced during the fighting.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: Fighting began between FARDC soldiers and FRPI militiamen in the village of Aveba, and spread to other villages in the chiefdom of Walendu Bindi (in Ituri), including Tchekele, Kaswara and Bavi. Thousands of people were displaced during the fighting.

column8: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: Fighting began between FARDC soldiers and FRPI militiamen in the village of Aveba, and spread to other villages in the chiefdom of Walendu Bindi (in Ituri), including Tchekele, Kaswara and Bavi. Thousands of people were displaced during the fighting. In Aveba, UN helicopters assisted the Congolese forces, and at least 14 FRPI and 6 FARDC soldiers were reported dead in Aveba.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: UNC: Union for the Congolese Nation; UDPS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress; PUDEMO: Peoples United Democratic Movement
column17: A peaceful march by the opposition parties (UDPS, UNC, UDEMO, Labour Party) was undertaken to express their rejection of the electoral law.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: Fighting began between FARDC soldiers and FRPI militiamen in the village of Aveba, and spread to other villages in the chiefdom of Walendu Bindi (in Ituri), including Tchekele, Kaswara and Bavi. Thousands of people were displaced during the fighting.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: LRA rebels kidnapped 13 people from Bili total, including 10 women in one attack and 7 men in another, but 4 of the men managed to escape.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Two Mai Mai Simba militia men were killed in clashes with the armed forces of the DRC at Penge, a mining quarry located over 119 km from Mambasa territory. A dozen others were injured.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column9: UDPS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column17: Clashes occur between demonstrators, who threw stones, and the police during protests against the proposed electoral law. The crowd also attacked two MONUSCO peacekeepers, injuring one. Some demonstrators were wounded and others arrested alongside opposition political leaders, including Rubens Mikindo, federal leader of the Union for Social Progress and Democracy [UDPS] in the east; Christian Badose, Ecide parties spokesman; Leon Tembo, Federal Chairman of the Union for the Congolese Nation [UNC] in the east and Jean Baptiste Kasekwa, Ecide parties executive secretary in eastern DRCongo.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Protests against the proposed electoral law took place in Bukavu on 19th January 2015.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A 22-year-old man was wounded when police tried to break up a demonstration near the parliament building. Eslewhere, Police open fire to disperse a gathering of students near to the university. Two youths reported injured by gunfire.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Police fired tear gas and live bullets at crowds protesters that gathered in the streets of Kinshasa. Tyres were set on fire, and the crowd threw stones at police. Between 19th and 21st January 2015, Human Rights Watch report that 36 people were killed in these protests in Kinshasa. The government denies this, estimating 27 killed in total, including 4 in Goma.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Protests against the proposed electoral law reported in North Kivu on 20th January 2015.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: In Ngaliema commune in western Kinshasa, two public transport buses were razed down by protesters. No deaths reported.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Hundreds of youths torch a town hall in Ngaba, a southern neighbourhood of the capital, while several prisoners escape from an attached building.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Protests against the proposed electoral law reported in Katanga on 20th January 2015.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: In Masina, clashes between the police and demonstrators were reported. One man killed.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Police fired tear gas and live bullets at crowds protesters that gathered in the streets of Kinshasa. Tyres were set on fire, and the crowd threw stones at police. Between 19th and 21st January 2015, Human Rights Watch report that 36 people were killed in these protests in Kinshasa. The government denies this, estimating 27 killed in total, including 4 in Goma.

column6: Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019) National Intelligence Agency
column17: Security measures: Authorities in the Democratic Republic of Congo shut down internet access and SMS services. The instruction was relayed to internet and mobile phone providers by the National Intellgience Agency, claiming it will help prevent more protests. Internet service restored 22nd January 2015.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Near the University of Kinshasa, the road leading to the campus was partially barricaded late in the morning with stones, pieces of wood and other materials to prevent vehicles from proceeding. The police arrived, threw tear gas, and made a number of arrests. One woman killed.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Protests against the proposed electoral law reported in South Kivu on 20th January 2015.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: At least 3 Chinese nationals were seriously injured and over 50-53 Chinese owned stores were looted by rioters during the protests against the electoral law.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019) Republican Guard
column17: In Kinshasas General Referral Hospital, a delegation of legislators had visited the victims from the riots. A group of Republican Guard soldiers entered searching for these, who had already left. They randomly shot at people, injuring three, including two women, one of whom suffered a miscarriage.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Police fired tear gas and live bullets at crowds protesters that gathered in the streets of Kinshasa. Tyres were set on fire, and the crowd threw stones at police. Between 19th and 21st January 2015, Human Rights Watch report that 36 people were killed in these protests in Kinshasa. The government denies this, estimating 27 killed in total, including 4 in Goma.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Gunshots were heard at the University of Kinshasa during a confrontation between police and students who called, ""Kabila get out!""

column6: Ngbanda Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Lingotebe Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Clashes occurred between the populations of Ngbada and Lingotebe villages in South Ubangi. At least 5 people were killed, and the villagers have since fled fearing reprisals. A mixed national police/FARDC force has been sent to investigate.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: University students supported by some locals set up barricades on the national road number 2 to protest the adoption of the bill aimed at modifying the countries electoral law by the National Assembly. Demonstrators clashed with policemen who attempted to reopen the road. Karale police station was demolished by demonstrators. 20 demonstrators and certain policemen who robbed locals properties during the riot were arrested.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Students demonstrated against the decision to cut internet access and SMS messaging. They established barricades and set fire to tyres. Police fired live bullets and tear gas to disperse demonstrators. One student reported injured. A butcher was killed by a stray bullet. Elsewhere in Goma police opened fire on protesters in Goma and used tear gas to repel rock-thowing youths. Three deaths reported.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The inhabitants of Ndosho district took to the streets in the early morning. They placed barricades on the Ndosho-Sake road while others burned tyres on the road to Masisi. Some sources report two deaths, while others report up to five deaths.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Demonstrations held in Mbandaka, with government and opposition supporters. No major incidents reported.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki)
column17: Members of the Raia Mutomboki Mayi Mayi militia used force to evict approximately 750 artisanal miners from their mining site along the river Ulindi in South Kivu. The militiamen claim they are preparing for an offensive against the FARDC.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Agreement: About 85 Raia Mutombaki Mayi Mayi militiamen voluntarily surrendered to the FARDC Sokola II operation force at Ibanda in Bukavu.

column6: NDC: Nduma Defence of Congo
column17: NDC militia fighters made an incursion into Kasugho. They looted and burned house and injured 4 people. The UNOCHA reported this, saying that the NDC have become more active in the Lubero area around Fatua and Lasugho recently.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: UPDS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: About 50 UPDS members gathered at their HQ to protest against President Kabilas rule, but they were quickly dispersed by ""seven jeeploads of police"".

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Thousands of people attended a march organized by the Mayor of Lubumbashi in support of President Kabila, including MPs, provincial ministers, and business and civil society leaders.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: UPDS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column17: The UPDS has accused the police of arbitrarily detaining 40 of its activists, and of torturing them in detention.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri; Mayi Mayi Militia (Simba)
column17: At least 52 prisoners were injuring during a riot at the Central Prison of Bunia between two groups of prisoners who clashed and threw stones at each other, one of which is associated with the FRPI and Mayi Mayi Simba Morgan militia. 8 were injured seriously. Police, UN forces and military forces were deployed to calm the riots.

column6: Ngbaka Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Ngbandi Communal Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A Ngbandi was beheaded by Ngbaka community members related to a land dispute between the two communities.

column6: FNL: National Forces of Liberation
column17: 1 person was killed and 2 others seriously injured when FNL rebels attacked a mini-bus near Uvira.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Uganda)
column9: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019); MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-); Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A group of armed men killed 15 people in a nightclub, including an official of MONUSCO of Indian nationality, 2 FARDC soldiers and 1 police officer. Others were injured.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 4 people were abducted in Rutshuru territory by an unidentified group. They were later released after being ransomed.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Residents of Mahagi rioted after the arrest of the city manager, his assistant and the sports department head. Police fired shots into the air to disperse the protestors. 2 people were injured and houses were reported burned and broken into related to the riot.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Former militia fighters protested against poor living conditions in the military training centre where they have been cantoned for five months and the slow speed of demobilization.

column6: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column17: On 3 February 2015, armed men killed at least 21 people in Mayangose-Kibidiwe village (in Virunga National Park), 15km northeast of Beni, near Halungupa, according to the governor of the province. They were said to have been killed with machetes and the perpetrators are believed to have been members of the ADF.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: An opposition march was held to protest against the arrest of a Jean-Claude Muyambo, a lawyer held in Kinshasa, and a perceived broader trend of the government trying to silence opponents through the justice system. Another march (they may have been the same) also occurred against the trial of Vital Kamerhe, reportedly drawing thousands of people.

column6: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column17: 6 decapitated bodies were found in Bwanasura, a village 120 km south of Bunia. The ADF are believed to have been responsible for their deaths.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Around 4,000 supporters of President Kabila rallied in Bukavu.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura)
column17: 6 armed men believed to be Nyatura Mayi Mayi militia fighters killed a trader, and then shot a soldier who was buying food in a shop nearby. The soldier died later in the Rushuru general hospital.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: 8 people have been kidnapped by suspected LRA rebels, who have also looted properties and agricultural goods in the localities of Digba and Dizaga in the Ango area.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Students (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Youths who claim members of the Hutu community in Kiwanja killed a trader set fire to houses belonging to members of the Hutu community. Police fired shots into the air and tear gas to disperse the crowd. A young woman was hit by a bullet and later died in hospital. At least 2 others were injured. Students were present during the protests.

column6: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column17: 4 people have been killed and 1 seriously injured in an attack by the ADF on the Mbau-Kamango road northeast of Beni. They were killed using machetes.

column6: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On 6 February 2015, FARDC forces have reportedly clashed with ADF fighters while pursuing them in the Virunga National Park, near Halungupa (Beni, Nord-Kivu), after they attacked the village of Mayangose-Kibidiwe earlier this week.

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: At least 1 FARDC soldier was killed in an ambush by FRPI fighters in the Ituri area between Feb.4-9.

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: At least 2 people have been killed, 7 women raped, several children kidnapped and 300 cows stolen in attacks on 7 villages by the FRPI around the Ituri area between Feb.4-9.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: ""An INGO worker was driving in his private vehicle when armed individuals, who were attempting to stop the car, opened fire. The INGO worker was taken to hospital.""

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Batwa Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A pygmy chief and his four companions were killed in an attack by an unidentified group in the Kinsunkulu area of Manono.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Police officers protested to ""denounce the omission of their names on the payroll"" and claimed that they are awaiting three months of backpay.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Charles)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 6 FARDC soldiers and 3 elements of the Mayi Mayi Charles militia were killed in clashes in the Nyamilima area.

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 2 FARDC soldiers and 3 FDLR rebels were killed during ambushes around Nyamitwitwi Kafuzo, near Nyamilima.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Clashes between FARDC and Raia Mutomboki Mayi Mayi militia forces have pushed residents of Itebero to flee. Fighting was reported between Feb.12-13. 1 militiamen was reported killed.

column6: Bantu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Batwa Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column7: Vigilante Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Youth residents of the Bankoko neighbourhood of Bunia lynched and burned alive a FARDC soldier who was allegedly caught robbing a house and killed a young man.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Clashes between FARDC and Raia Mutomboki Mayi Mayi militia forces have pushed residents of Itebero to flee. Fighting was reported between Feb.12-13. 1 militiamen was reported killed.

column6: Bantu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Batwa Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 7 people were killed and 12 others injured in a clash between the Pygmy Sengatchimbu and Bantu communities in the Manono area. 27 total were killed in attacks of this kind between Feb.9-15.

column6: Ngbandi Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Ngbaka Communal Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A Ngbaka was beheaded by Ngbandi community members related to a land dispute between the two communities.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: The UNHCR reported that at least 25 abductions by the LRA took place during February 2015 near the border between CAR and DR-Congo (8 of which were abducted on Feb.5 in the Digba area).

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Christian Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Political opposition parties organized a march in partnership with a Christian group in memory of the ""martyrs of democracy"" and to demand the reopening of the Sovereign National Conference (SNC).

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: 2 rebels and 10 other people were killed by the NDC-R as they attempted ""to neutralize any presence of the FDLR in that part of North Kivu"" between Feb.16-17. 6 people were also injured.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: FARDC forces investigating an LRA attack engaged in a gunfight with the rebels, leading to the death of at least 2 civilians and serious injuries to at least 2 others. 4 LRA fighters were captured during the clashes.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Prisoners (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019) Prison Guards
column9: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Prisoners held in solitary confinement protested their conditions after the death of a sick prisoner. Military forces were called in to assist the guards. 1 soldier and 4 inmates were wounded before order was restored.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: Several people were injured in an ambush by LRA rebels on a civilian vehicle in Nangume in Dungu territory.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia
column17: 4 people were killed and 10 seriously injured by Mayi Mayi militiamen who attacked Ezekere, near Bunia. They also burned more than 20 homes and looted property.

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: Suspected FRPI militiamen killed 2 traders in an attack on a convoy of 3 vehicles in Mussa, near Bunia. The attackers were dressed in FARDC uniforms and opened fire on the convoy, and then robbed it. The 2 traders were killd when they tried to flee into the bush.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki)

column7: UDPS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress; Students (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: UDPS activists and students marched in protest against the mayor who they say ""muzzles"" all their activities. Police fired in the air to disperse the march, and protesters responded by throwing projectiles. Police then allegedly opened fire on the crowd. 2 protesters and 1 police officer were injured.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Angry miners who had been dislodged from the Okapi Wildlife Reserve blocked traffic on Highway 4, at Bandegaido. The protesters were dispersed by the warden assisted by FARDC soldiers, with the soldiers reportedly firing several shots. Some sources claim 3 people died during the incident, while the administrator of the territory said that one person was seriously wounded and there were no deaths.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Women (Democratic Republic of Congo); Health Workers (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Gunmen stormed the Bunia Evangelical Medical Centre and stole clothes and money. They also fired on a nurse and injured her.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: A police unit was attacked in the Nyamilima area was attacked by FDLR fighters.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: Clashes were reported between FARDC and FDLR forces in the Lemera area of Uvira following the official start of military operations against the FDLR in South Kivu. 3 FDLR were reported killed, 2 captured, and 3 women and children recovered.

The authorities say they were promoting violence. The US diplomat and journalists were released the next day.

column8: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: FARDC soldiers have reportedly claimed control of thirty-five localities previously occupied by FDLR rebels. 21 are located in South Kivu and 14 in the southern part of Virunga Park in North Kivu. They also say 237 FDLR rebels have been neutralized in total, of which 13 have been killed (fatalities covered in previously coded events).

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: At least 1 FARDC soldier was killed and 3 others seriously injured, and an injured soldier captured, after an attack by FDLR rebels on a FARDC position in the Busesa locality in Binza group of the Rutshuru territory. The attack was repelled after 2 hours, during which time one FDLR rebel was captured and one killed.

column6: Protesters (Central African Republic)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: At least 4 people were arrested following a demonstration by Struggle for Change (Lucha) activists to demand the release of their colleagues.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Residents of a village on the outskirts of Lengabo demonstrated outside ""the gates of Bunia city with machetes and sticks in hand"" to express their discontent over a land dispute with a local MP.

column6: Protesters (Central African Republic)
column7: Christian Group (Democratic Republic of Congo); Teachers (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Teachers from the six territories of Maniema have gathered in Kindu for an event, supported by the Catholic NGO Caritas Congo, to demand wages for March.

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: Gunmen believed to be FDLR rebels attacked a truck travelling near the village of Fusso Buhuma in the Nyiragongo area, killing 1 and injuring 3 passengers.

column6: Gini Lau Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: West Lau Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Two communities in West Lau area of Yakoma clashed with knives and home-made firearms, resulting in 2 dead and 30 houses burned. The two groups were the Gini Lau and West Laug groups and the fighting was due to a land dispute.

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: FRPI militiamen attacked the Ruzinga Mukubwa IDP camp in the Walendu Bindi chiefdom, in the Ituri district. They fired shots into the air, severely wounding a pregnant woman, and stole at least 20 goats.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 8 FARDC soldiers out of a patrol of 12 are missing after a clash with LRA rebels in the area near Mangbanga. It was not clear whether they were kidnapped, killed, or had deserted.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: UNC: Union for the Congolese Nation
column17: The UNC staged a sit-in to protest against what it sees as false allegatons against its president Vital Kamerhe related to the 2011 parliamentary elections in Kinshasa.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Simba)
column17: 5 people were killed, at least 5 women raped, and others kidnapped during attacks by Mayi Mayi Simba fighters in the Mambasa area since Apr.12. The militiamen also looted villages and used both machetes and guns during their attacks, which were allegedly in response to FARDC operations.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column17: FARDC soldiers have allegedly discovered between 4-5 mass graves with at least 47 bodies after taking control of an ADF camp in the Bango area. The identity of the victims is unknown but is currently speculated to either be ADF militants killed in clashes with the military or civilians executed by the rebels.

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: FRPI militiamen attacked a convoy of the NGO Solidarity. They assaulted a woman and stripped a man, and stole large amounts of property and equipment.

column6: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column16: Xinhua; Le Potentiel; AFP; Radio Okapi
column17: ADF rebels killed at least 18 civilians, including as many as two pregnant women, and injured 5 others in attacks in the Matiba and Mbau areas. The 5 people killed in Mbau were beheaded with machetes. 2 people were later arrested in connection and allegedly admitted to being ADF rebels and involved in the killings.

column6: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column17: FARDC soldiers have allegedly discovered between 4-5 mass graves with at least 47 bodies after taking control of an ADF camp in the Bango area. The identity of the victims is unknown but is currently speculated to either be ADF militants killed in clashes with the military or civilians executed by the rebels.

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: Between 30-40 people were abducted by FDLR rebels in an attack on Rwindi, and demanded a ransom from their relatives.

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: FDLR rebels attacked the town of Ngobera in the Nyiragongo area, killing 2 people and looting cattle.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: One person was killed in the Lubero territory by FDLR rebels.

column8: Longonya Dive Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column8: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Prisoners (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Rioters reportedly killed and burned an ""official"". Police and military forces clashed with the rioters before restoring order.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Armed men in FARDC uniforms broke into a home and robbed it. They killed 2 people during the incident, the son of the owner of the house and his sister.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A DR-Congo government spokesman said that about 300 Rwandan soldiers made an incursion into North Kivu which was repelled by FARDC soldiers, resulting in one FARDC member wounded. The Rwandan soldiers had been encamped at Musangoti Hill in Virunga National Park and retreated across the border after the clash. The Rwandan representative to the UN has denied the events, although park rangers and local residents have confirmed the incursion occurred.

column6: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-)
column17: Movement of forces: About 200 Ugandan soldiers have reportedly crossed into DR-Congo in the Ruwenzori area and settled into several villages, including Kalehaleha, Kalindera (coordinates approx) and Mumbiri (coordinates approx). They continued to be in the area as recently as Apr.24. The Ugandan government denies its forces have entered the DR-Congo.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Young people allegedly intercepted a Kingdom Hall of Jehovahs Witnesses truck that was allegedly carrying machetes and axes that they say were to be used to commit crimes. The angry youths got into a dispute with those unloading the truck and attempted to set fire to the group's building but were prevented by the police.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 2 FARDC soldiers, including a senior officer, and a woman were killed and between 3-14 soldiers kidnapped when unidentified armed men attacked a military position in Kairenge.

column6: Bogbonga Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Bogbonga Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 2 people, including the Bogbonga group leader and a local village chief, were seriously wounded and over 50 huts burned during clashes between two segements of the Bogbonga community over fishing rights on the Momboto river. The group leader later died of his wounds.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Officials of the National Forestry Fund (FFN) protested around their offices against expanding contract positions with the organization.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Prisoners (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Former Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019); Prisoners (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Military and civilian prisoners of the Kisangani Central Prison clashed after a prisoner who was a FARDC captain refused to end a phone call to return to his cell. Civilian prisoners attacked him, leading to a fight involving thrown bricks. At least 42 people were injured, including 33 soldier-prisoners. 9 people also escaped during the violence, with 7 later caught.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 4 people were killed and 1 other is missing after unidentified armed men opened fire on a vehicle, which then drove into a lake with all its passengers aboard except one who had been killed attempting to flee.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: UNAFEC: Union of Nationalist Federalists of Congo Party
column17: Gunmen attacked the house of a UNAFEC MPP, injuring him and 3 other members of his family seriously.

column6: NDC-C: Nduma Defense of Congo (Cheka)
column17: NDC-Cheka and Gedeon militiamen have clashed in the Ihana area of the Walikale territory for control of mines near the town of Misusu, causing many people to flee the area.

column6: Militia (Gedeon)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Agreement: A rebel leader of the Gedeon militia along with 11 other militiamen surrendered to FARDC soldiers in Mitwaba.

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: 3 local community leaders were kidnapped by suspected FDLR rebels.

column6: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Following an attack on a vehicle by the ADF, FARDC soldiers clashed with the rebels and diserpsed them. No casualties were reported.

column6: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column17: 2 people were killed and 3 wounded during an attack on a vehicle traveling about 50 km north of Beni by ADF rebels.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Movement of forces: 300 FARDC special forces have been deployed to stabilize the Nyunzu area due to intercommunal violence which has taken place recently.

column6: Batwa Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 3 Luba were killed and 5 others injured during an attack by a pygmy militia in the Kitentu area of Manono territory. The pygmy militia burned the village and displaced at least 50 families during the violence. They also simultaneously raided the villages of Ndubuzi and Mambwe, also in the Manono area.

column6: Batwa Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Luba Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 3 Luba were killed and 5 others injured during an attack by a pygmy militia in the Kitentu area of Manono territory. column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Werrason)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 4 people, including 3 police officers, were killed in an attack on a mining site in the Babila Babombi chiefdom in Mambasa territory by suspected Werrason Mayi Mayi militiamen.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: 2 FDLR rebels were captured by FARDC soldiers after an ambush in Kilembwe in the Fizi locality of South Kivu.

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: At a demobilization camp for FDLR rebels, an FDLR rebel undergoing demobilization stabbed a FARDC colonel following a dispute regarding who would be included in a delegation related to the DDR program to Goma. FARDC soldiers then fired on unarmed FLDR in the camp, wounding 6. Following the violence, 50 FDLR rebels took refuge in a nearby MONUSCO base and others fled into the bush.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: Heavily-armed LRA rebels kidnapped 17 people and looted food from the Yangili locality before releasing 6 of them after forcing them to help them carry their loot.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A youth selling fish was shot by a police officer point blank and killed after refusing an allege extortion attempt in Kadutu town, near Bukavu.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: National staff of MONUSCO staged a 72-hour sit-in at MONUSCOs various headquarters across the DR-Congos provinces.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: After a police officer allegedly caused a motorcycle-taxi driver to fall of his bike, causing him serious injuries, a crowd believing the driver to be dead beat up the policemen responsible, putting at least one of them in the hospital. They then pursued other police, and forced them off the streets for 48 hours.

column6: Militia (Elements)
column7: Bantu Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Batwa Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 4 people were killed in an attack by the Bantu ""Elements"" militia on indigenous Pygmys in Kitutwa village in the Manono area, allegedly in retaliation for attacks on Bantu villages in the Bakongolo area.

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: FDLR rebels looted property and lifestock in the Mukondo area of Nyiragongo. Gunshots were also heard in the area. They kidnapped one villager to assist them in carrying the loot, who has not been found.

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: FDLR rebels clashed with FARDC soldiers near a military position in Rusayo in the Nyiragongo area before looting a nearby village.

column6: NDC-C: Nduma Defense of Congo (Cheka)
column17: 4 civilians and 5 militiamen were killed in a clash between NDC-C and Kifuafua Mayi Mayi militiamen in the Nsindo Waloa Uroba group in Walikale territory. 10 others were wounded, while thousands have been displaced.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: FRPI militiamen allegedly burned an FARDC camp in the village of Nyongo in the Aveba area.

column6: UPC: Union of Congolese Patriots
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019) Republican Guard
column17: Between 5-8 people were killed, including 1-4 FARDC soldiers (anonymous source in the Republican Guard claims 4 according to AFP) and 4 assailants, and several wounded, during an attack by heavily armed suspected UPC gunmen on Goma airport. 3 gunmen were also arrested. The attackers were believed to be attepting to rob supply depots at the airport, as well as potentially an arms depot, while another source claimed the gunmen were associated with an unidentified rebel movement created by Mbusa Nyamwhisi (later sources point to UPC involvement as well). At least one of those killed was a member of the Republican Guard. The assailants were then chased into Goma town by the FARDC soldiers.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: National staff of MONUSCO began a second series of sit-ins in front of some UN mission sites in the DR-Congo, including Kinshasa, Kisangani, Bunia, Goma, and Bukavu.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Kifuafua)
column17: Two Mayi Mayi factions, Kifuafua Delphin Mbaenda and Makucha-Makucha, fight in Waloa Loanda.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column8: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: FARDC soldiers engaged in an offensive against all FRPI positions in Aveba, successfully dislodging them and capturing the area, reportedly causing heavy casualties. MONUSCO helicopters and peacekeepers patrolled during the operation to ensure the safety of civilians.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 4 soldiers were arrested on Jun.5 accused of killing at least one civilian in the town of Mulekera (lat/longs not available), near Beni.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: One soldier was killed, one wounded, and one was kidnapped after an attack by Simba Mayi Mayi militiamen on a FARDC position near Badengaido in the Ituri area (lat/longs not available, coded at district capital at Geoprecision 2).

column6: Luba Dragon
column7: Bantu Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Batwa Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 10 families were kidnapped by a Bantu ethnic militia called Luba Dragon in the territory of Manono and a ransom demanded.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019) National Intelligence Agency
column17: Arrests: 33 members of the UPC were arrested along with rebel leader Celestin Kambale in connection with a recent attack on Goma airport. An elected representative of Goma was also arrested by the ANR.

column6: Menga Otete Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Menga Otete Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A clash occurred between two segments of the Menga Otete community (lat/longs not available) in the Lubefu territory over a succession dispute related to the traditional chieftainship of the village which killed 3 people.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Shebi Muhisa)
column17: The factions of the Raia Mutomboki, including those based out of Ntoto, and Mayi Mayi Shebia Muhisa militiamen have allegedly been fighting regularly in the Walikale area since early June.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki)
column17: The factions of the Raia Mutomboki, including those based out of Ntoto, and Mayi Mayi Shebia Muhisa militiamen have allegedly been fighting regularly in the Walikale area since early June.

column17: On Jun.16, it was reported that heavy fighting had been ongoing in the Walendu Bindi area between FARDC soldiers and FRPI militiamen for the past 10 days, resulting in over 17,000 displaced. Fighting is part of a joint operation with MONUSCO forces.

column7: Journalists (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Journalists protested in Bukavu against death threats and attacks on journalists following an attack on the director of Iriba FM radio.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Uganda soldiers entered the village of Ovo (lat/longs not available) in Aru territory and destroyed a dozen houses recently built by Congolese on area they say is a neutral zone between the DR-Congo and Uganda. Residents of Aru flooded the area to protest the actions, whereupon the Uganda soldiers fired tear gas to disperse them.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column7: Mbororo Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: More than 30 people were kidnapped by LRA rebels supported by Mbororo herders, who looted their homes during the night of Jun.8-9.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column7: Mbororo Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019) Republican Guard
column17: FARDC soldiers freed 12-13 people kidnapped by LRA rebels and continued to pursue them to free another 18 out of the total 30 who were kidnapped on the night of Jun.8-9.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column8: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: Official sources have claimed that 34 FRPI militiamen have been killed, 27 wounded, and 4 captured since the beginning of the military operations against them launched by FARDC and MONUSCO forces, with the fighting occurring in the Walendu Bindi area. They also claim 4 FARDC soldiers killed and 13 injured. Fatalities divided from 3/06 to 10/06.

The administrator of Kabambare sent a FARDC detachment to restore calm.

column9: Batwa Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Incidents of looting, rape, torture and kidnappings attributed to the Bantu ""Elements"" militia in the Soswa, Kabonzo and Kabeke localities. Communal violence between Bantu and pygmy ethnic groups has been ongoing in the area.

They also brought with them various pieces of military hardware, including machine guns and rocket launchers.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column8: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column16: AP; MONUSCO; Le Potentiel; Xinhua; Radio Okapi
column17: ADF rebels dislodged FARDC soldiers from at least part of Eringeti on Nov.29 before being pushed out a few hours later on Nov.30. The rebels attack stretched from Makembi to Eringeti and simultaneously targeted a FARDC position, a MONUSCO base, a hospital in Eringeti, and the office of the PNC in Beni territory. 1 UN peacekeeper, 7 soldiers, 10 civilians and 21 rebels were killed, while 1 peacekeeper and 4 soldiers were injured. 5 more people believe to have been killed during the fighting were found a few days later. During the violence at least 43 homes were also burned. At least 2,000 people ahve fled following the fighting.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

Police allegedly fired first, while the youths threw stones.

column17: A man was killed by an unidentified group in Kamuronza group in Masisi territory, causing residents of the area to take refuge in neighbouring groups.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Residents of Mugunga protested and blocked roads to demand a verdict against those believed to be behind the killing of the ""leader"" of Mugunga.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Hundreds of Brasimba officers staged a work stoppage in Lubumbashi after it was announced that some benefits would be halved and others eliminated.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019) Garamba National Park
column17: An LRA rebel involved in poaching was killed by Garamba park guards.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Clashes between FARDC and Raia Mutomboki-Mabala forces in the Nindja area of Kabare have caused displacement of residents to Kalonge. 4 soldiers and 3 militiamen were reported killed.

column6: NDC-R: Nduma Defence of Congo (Renewal)
column17: FARDC soldiers have withdrawn from the Ihana area of Walikale, followed by an occupation by NDC-R forces.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019) Kahuzi Biega National Park
column17: A park ranger in Kahuzi Biega National Park was killed by suspected rebels, although their affiliation was not reported.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki-Mirage)
column17: Raia Mutomboki-Mirage militiamen have occupied the villages of the Bakonjo grouping of Walikale after the withdrawal of FARDC soldiers.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Unidentified armed men referred to as poachers looted property and raped women in the Wamba area, including in the villages of Bapoa, Opiko, Baza and Agoyo. Sudanese soldiers and LRA rebels are known to poach in the area.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Clashes between FARDC and Raia Mutomboki Mabala militiamen were reported in the Bushamba area of Kabare territory. 9 were killed, including 4 soldiers and 5 rebels, with 2 soldiers injured.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A FARDC soldier allegedly shot a woman in the chest in the Walikale area, injuring her. No other information was provided in the report.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Movement of forces: Heavy weapons have allegedly been moved into Lubumbashi by FARDC, including tanks. Residents have expressed concern that the stockpiling of heavy weapons systems is connected with the coming elections.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Simba)
column17: Mayi Mayi Simba militiamen were reported to have committed ""many atrocities against civilians"" during an occupation of the mining town of Muchacha in Ituri. Specifically, at least 2 women were raped by militiamen and property was looted, before they withdrew from the area.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019) Kahuzi-Biega National Park
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Unidentified armed men fired on Kahuzi-Biega park guards. No casualties were reported.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki-Kizamoto)
column7: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki-Kyakwama)
column17: Clashes have occurred recently in the Lulingu between the Raia Mutomboki Kazimoto and Kyakwama militias on one side and the Kabazimiya faction on the other have resulted in the deaths of at least 4 civilians, all of whom are reportedly members of the family of the Kyakwama militias leader. These clashes were sparked by the killing of the Kabazimiya leaders son on Apr.27, which is when they started (first reported on May.12).

column6: Nyatura-FDLR Coalition: Nyatura -Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: Some Nyatura-FDLR coalition fighters killed the traditional leader of Zanganano village in the Boshimo area of Bashali Mokoto grouping.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Health Workers (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Health providers at 25 health centers, including a general hospital in the Oicha area, observed a work stoppage to protest insecurity in the area.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki-Mabala)
column17: A traditional leader from Kimbili village was kidnapped by Raia Mutomboki Mabala militiamen.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia
column9: Hutu Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Suspected Mayi Mayi militiamen in the Binza area killed the ""Hutu president"" of Binza group.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Nyamilima Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Residents of the Binza area beat a soldier who came upon the murder of the ""Hutu president"" of the Binza group. It was not clear if they thought he had killed him, or if there was another reason for the violence. 2 people were seriously injured during the incident when the soldier fired on the crowd while attempting to escape. He was then ""arrested and stoned by the angry crowd"", which led to his death.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Residents of the Binza area demonstrating after the death of a ""Hutu president"" in the area were engaged by the military, which arrested many of them. Few details were available on the event.

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column7: Lendu Communal Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Hema Communal Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Looting: A local Lendu leader looted= allegedly seized about 390 cows from Hema community members while accompanied by suspected FRPI militiamen. 80 cows were later reclaimed by Hema community members peacefully.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A young girl was injured during a funeral march for a the recently killed ""Hutu president"" of the area when an unidentified assault opened fire on the crowd. The march seems to have also seems to have been a demonstration, as protesters were later arrested by the military.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Students (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: More than 10 people were injured during a clash between students of the Higher Institute of Agronomic Studies Bengamisa and police in Bayaswa, near Kisangani (Tshopo). The dispute started over the arrest of a student by traffic police.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Heavy weapons firing was heard in the Kiliba area where FARDC soldiers have been staging an offensive against FNL rebels in conjunction with the Burundian army (which is operating on its side of the border).

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column17: 2 FARDC soldiers were killed by ADF rebels during an ambush in the Opira area.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki)
column17: 55 people were kidnapped by Raia Mutomboki militias (led by Kokodikoko and Dembi Kaboyi) between the villages of Kifuko and Kamituga. At least 18 people were also raped and property stolen.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Residents of Nizi and workers of the SOKIMO gold minig company staged a demonstration to oppose the signing of a gold mining agreement between the their company and another.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (PARECO)
column7: Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura)
column17: Mayi Mayi Pareco and Nyatura militiamen have allegedly committed ""several atrocities"" against residents of the town of Kalembe in North Kivu. They are also accused of holding residents of the village hostage and levying taxes against them.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: 2 FARDC soldiers were killed by FRPI militiamen during an ambush in the town of Kolu near Aveba. Overall, 41 separate attacks were carried out by FRPI in April, primarily in the areas surrounding Geti and Aveba. Dates not provided.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 2 villages in the Kitababeya group in the Salamabila area of Maniema were attacked by 4 heavily armed men in military uniforms. In the first village they looted property, kidnapped people, and raped at least one woman. 4 people were also seriously injured in the attack. The second village saw looting and ""torture"" of the resdients, but no cases of rape or serious injuries, although one woman was reported to have two broken ribs.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 3 people were killed in an explosion either caused by a car bomb or grenade targeting a vehicle on the main street of Bukavu, in the Ibanda municipality.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Vigilante Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 2 men were allegedly killed by their sons after the sons accused their fathers of being """"witches"""" following the deaths of a sister and brother due to childbirth and malaria respectively.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 2 men in police uniforms allegedly attempted to steal a motorcycle from a private residence and killed 2 people who attempted to resist them. 1 woman was also injured.

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: 2 women were wounded by gunfire and 2 others kidnapped and property stolen during raids by FRPI militiamen against at least 7 villages in the Walendu Bindi chieftaincy, near Irumu.

column6: Military Forces of Rwanda (1994-)
column17: Movement of forces: Hundreds of Rwandan soldiers allegedly crossed into DR-Congo territory in the Buhimba area while searching for FDLR forces.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura)
column7: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column9: Mercy Corps; Aid Workers (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 5 aid workers of the NGO Mercy Corps were abducted by alleged Nyatura fighters and FDLR in the Mushikiri area between Nyanzale and Kikuku. The workers were later released.

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column8: Kawangu Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: FRPI militiamen attacked the Kawangu locality, near Geti. One woman wounded an FRPI fighter with a machete while attempting to resist their pillaging, and was in turn injured by gunfire. Overall, 41 separate attacks were carried out by FRPI in April, primarily in the areas surrounding Geti and Aveba. Dates not provided.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: At least 2 people were killed and 8 injured, including a policeman and a soldier, following rioting by the resident of Kolwezi after police allegedly killed 2 people while attempting to steal a motorcycle the night before. The police are reported to have fired on the crowd when its members demanded to see the bodies of those killed. 2 bodies were later found in a nearby lake, and are believed to have died in relation to the rioting in Kolwezi.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Property destruction: Police torched around 140 houses in the village of Asanga Kianga, allegedly in retaliation for the death of a police officer as he carried out his duties by a resident of the village.

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 3 FARDC soldiers died of their injuries after an ambush by the FDLR in the Buvunga area of Rutshuru. The deaths were alternatively reported to have occurred during an attack on a camp in the Katale area.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: UNAFEC: Union of Nationalist Federalists of Congo Party
column17: UNAFEC offices in Kinshasa and Lubumbashi were allegedly invaded by police (or ""bandits"" supervised by security forces, depending on the article) who damaged property and took down party banners and other effects. In Lubumbashi UNAFEC supporters threw stones at men in uniform who took a portrait of the former government of Katanga, Moise Katumbi. Many youth were allegedly arrested and others wounded during the incident.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: UNAFEC: Union of Nationalist Federalists of Congo Party
column17: Property destruction: UNAFEC offices in Kinshasa and Lubumbashi were allegedly invaded by police (or ""bandits"" supervised by security forces, depending on the article) who damaged property and took down party banners and other effects.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 12 people were killed in clashes between FARDC soldiers and Mayi Mayi Simba militiamen in the Biakato area. 11 of those killed were militiamen. 3 others were also injured.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: UNAFEC: Union of Nationalist Federalists of Congo Party
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Police forces used tear gas to disperse as many as 5,000 UNAFEC demonstrators angry at the involvement of police in interfering with their party HQ in the city and calling for the ouster of President Kabila. The protesters allegedly clashed with police, injuring 5 of them, and vandalized shops. 13 protesters were arrested. At least 1 American and 3 others foreigners were also allegedly arrested.

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: FARDC soldiers turned an ambush by FDLR rebels on Ishasha road in the Kitwiguru area. 5 rebels were killed during the fighting.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: LRA rebels abmushed 6 artisanal miners near Sambia, while traveling to Dungu. They had their property stolen and were kidnapped, but 4 managed to escape.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: FARDC soldiers clashed with Mayi Mayi Gumino militiamen in Kajembwe in the Bijombo highlands area. 2 Gumino militiamen were killed and 5 wounded. They were also dislodged from the area.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: LRA rebels ambushed 6 people between Dungu and Sambia, stealing their property and forcing them to transport it before releasing them.

column6: Nombe Ovungu Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Nombe Ovungu Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Two families in the Nombe Ovungu group in the Sankuru area clashed, with one person being stabbed to death, over exploitation of a forest in their area.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Health Workers (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Care workers of the MIBA hospitals in Dipumba and Bonzola engaged in a strike to demand their wages for the past three months. They also staged a sit-in.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Agreement: 19 Raia Mutomboki militiamen voluntarily surrendered to FARDC soldiers at a base in the Bakano sector of Walikale.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Arrests: 2 sons of Pierre Lumbi, chairman of the MR party, a member of the G7 opposition coalition, were arrested in Lubumbashi on what Pierre Lumbi says are unfounded charges.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: G7 Opposition Coalition
column17: Opposition parties held a rally in front of the Martyrs Stadium in Kinshasa. During the rally, they called for more independence for the Constitutional Court and for political change. The rally also disrupted traffic in the area.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Employees of the General Directorate of Revenue of Mongala (DGREM) protested against the non-payment of their salaries, alongside members of the areas civil society.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: FARDC forces dislodged 2 armed groups, including the Gumino, from several localities in the Bijombo highlands over 2 days of fighting between Apr.26-27. The locations recovered include Mikengne, Mikarati, Muramvya, Kinyonyi, Nyawaranga, Kajembwe and Bijombo Centre. No casualties were reported.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: FARDC forces dislodged 2 armed groups, including the Gumino, from several localities in the Bijombo highlands over 2 days of fighting between Apr.26-27. column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Property destruction: The HQ of UNADEF, a member of the G7 opposition coalition, in Lubumbashi was set on fire by a small group unidentified assailants. UNADEF activists blamed the police, but this could not be verified.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki-Kizamoto)
column7: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki-Kyakwama)
column17: Fighters of the Raia Mutomboki Kazimoto and Kyakwama factions killed the son of the Kabazimiya Raia Mutomboki militias leader. It was not clear whether the son was a member of his fathers group or not.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: FARDC forces dislodged 2 armed groups, including the Gumino, from several localities in the Bijombo highlands over 2 days of fighting between Apr.26-27. The locations recovered include Mikengne, Mikarati, Muramvya, Kinyonyi, Nyawaranga, Kajembwe and Bijombo Centre. No casualties were reported.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 3 people were killed and 3 others injured during an attack by Nyatura fighters on a FARDC position in Mulamba in North Kivu.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: FARDC forces dislodged 2 armed groups, including the Gumino, from several localities in the Bijombo highlands over 2 days of fighting between Apr.26-27.
