column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A Mayi Mayi militia invaded the town of Kalera in order to release some of their colleagues. However, they had already been transferred, so the militiamen burned down the police station and then shot and beheaded a soldier.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura) Kasongo Faction
column17: Two Nyatura militias, one led by Colonel Kasongo and the other by General Benjamin, clashed in the Kivuye area of Bashali Mokoto following the pullout of FARDC from the area. One of the militias managed to caputre the area from the other.

column6: Nyatura-FDLR Coalition: Nyatura -Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column9: Nande Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 7 people were killed, including at least 6 members of the Nande ethnic group, and 5 others wounded when suspected Nyatura-FDLR coalition fighters (also described as armed Hutu) attacked the Nande population of the Kibirizi area of Rutshuru. Huts were also reportedly burned down. Some sources described the event as a clash between Hutu and Nande, although civilians appear to have made up all the fatalities. The attack was allegedly in response to an attack by Nande on Hutus on Jul.17. FARDC soldiers intervened to end the fighting.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A civilian accused of colluding with those responsible for a recent attack on Kibirizi was stoned and killed by Kibirizi youths.

column6: FOREBU: Republican Forces of Burundi
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: FOREBU rebels attacked a FARDC position in Madjaga village in the Uvira area.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 1 person was killed and 5 others injured after militiamen attacked a truck in the Kyanyunda locality in South Kivu. One of those injured later died in hospital. The attackers had been robbing some motorcyclists before the truck showed up and they started shooting.

column6: FOREBU: Republican Forces of Burundi
column17: Recruitment: FOREBU rebels have allegedly been recruiting in the Bijombo area, specifically in the villages of Chanzovu, Kagogo and Kateja.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 3 Mayi Mayi militiamen were killed in a clash with Congolese soldiers in the Busafa village, Mitwaba.

column6: PERCI: Civilian Personnel of the Military
column7: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Between Jul.18-23 three cases of ""torture and extortion of property"" were recorded by the ""PERCI"", a civilian paramilitary unit organized by the military. On Jul.20 a farmer was beaten and had a bag of rice stolen in Mbulula, while 2 other incidents occurred in Kahenye and Sayi, all in the Kongolo (Tanganyika) area.

column6: PERCI: Civilian Personnel of the Military
column7: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Between Jul.18-23 three cases of ""torture and extortion of property"" were recorded by the ""PERCI"", a civilian paramilitary unit organized by the military. On Jul.20 a farmer was beaten and had a bag of rice stolen in Mbulula, while 2 other incidents occurred in Kahenye and Sayi, all in the Kongolo (Tanganyika) area.

column6: PERCI: Civilian Personnel of the Military
column7: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Between Jul.18-23 three cases of ""torture and extortion of property"" were recorded by the ""PERCI"", a civilian paramilitary unit organized by the military. On Jul.20 a farmer was beaten and had a bag of rice stolen in Mbulula, while 2 other incidents occurred in Kahenye and Sayi, all in the Kongolo (Tanganyika) area.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura-Raia Tujigemeye)
column17: A newly created ""Nyatura"" militia, Raia Tujigemeye, has occupied Butale in the Bashali Mokoto grouping.

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Kamwina Nsapu militiamen attacked the offices of the deputy commissioner of the Fuamaba National Police and forced the police to retreat before burning it down.

column6: APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
column17: 3 people were killed, including a civilian, in a clash between the APCLS and Raia Tujigemeye Nyatura groups in Butale. The APCLS managed to dislodge the Raia Tujigemeye group from the village.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: After a man died of his injuries following a beating by police, an angry mob ransacked and burned a police station in Miabi

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: FRPI militiamen attacked a passenger vehicle in the Matafa area of the Walendu Bindi chieftaincy, injuring at least 3 traders and stealing goods.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: During an arrest, the son of a police commander slapped a villager who was angry about the police action, leading to a clash between residents of the area and the police, with anger specifically directed at the police commanders son.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 6 people were killed by unidentified assailants using machetes in the Bwalanda area of North Kivu. At least 3 were burned to death in their homes.

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column17: Kamwina Nsapu militiamen ambushed a vehicle being driven by a pastor and his family. No injuries reported.

column6: Mbororo Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A farmer was shot in the foot by armed forces identified as UDA as he was traveling west of Kaka II, DRC. After being shot, he managed to hide in the bush for a few hours before being stransported to the hospital in Dungu, DRC by a motorcyclist.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The leader of a Raia Mutomboki faction, Simuzizi Labani, was shot in the head and a child wounded in a clash with Congolese soldiers in the Luberizi area.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column8: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: Movement of forces: The Congolese army and MONUSCO launched a military operation, named ""Kiboko 3"" against the FRPI in south Irumu, including the use of air support.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Motorcycle taxi drivers staged a protest-strike in Kisangani against alleged arbitrary arrests and harassment against them by agents of the cities traffic police. They built a barricade on roads leading to the city centre and allegedly trashed a police station and some businesses. Some protesters engaging in a march were also dispersed by police using tear gas. At some point during the events, 3 protesters were allegedly killed during clashes with police along with several injured, including policemen. The police allegedly opened fire on the protesters.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Burundi)
column17: A trader was killed and 3 others injured in a suspected attack by suspected Burundian militiamen in the Uvira area.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: UDPS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Police and UDPS supporters clashed in Lubumbashis Matshipisha neighbourhood. No other details were given.

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: FRPI militiamen attacked the village of Fangasa, near Aveba, killing a woman accused of collaborating with FARDC and looted property.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: PPRD: Peoples Party for Reconstruction and Democracy
column17: The governor of Kasai-Oriental held a march in support of political dialogue in DR-Congo, which included members of the presidential majority.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: PPRD: Peoples Party for Reconstruction and Democracy
column17: A march in support of dialogue was called by President Kabila in Gbadolite. The march included members of the provincial government, MLAs, officials and activists of the party of the presidential majority.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: UDPS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Police and UDPS supporters clashed in Lubumbashis Matshipisha neighbourhood as UDPS activists gathered to discuss and celebrate the return of their leader Tshisekedi. 4 people were arrested.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A Soficom agent traveling with a large amount of money was killed in an ambush that allegedly involved several FARDC soldiers and other unidentified individuals.

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: FRPI militiamen attacked the village of Mayimbi, near Aveba, killing a woman.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A position of the army was attacked by a Mayi Mayi militia led by Charles Kakule. The militiamen forced the military out of their camp and wounded a woman. A soldier is also MIA after the action. The military re-occupied their position after the events.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: PPRD: Peoples Party for Reconstruction and Democracy
column17: The presidential majority held a rally in the capital to support the political dialogue announced by President Kabila. Many MPs and activists of the PPRD were present. As many as 40,000 people attended.

column6: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: 7 people were killed in an attack by the ADF on Oicha, which was repulsed by Congolese soldiers and MONUSCO peacekeepers. Among those killed were 2 civilians, 3 attackers and 2 soldiers. A MONUSCO peacekeeper was also wounded and 3 ADF rebels captured.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Congolese soldiers attacked a camp of international poachers in the Niangara area who have allegedly carried out attacks on the local population. Both South Sudanese soldiers and LRA rebels have been known to poach in the area.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Bakata Katanga)
column17: Recruitment: 31 July. Mayi Mayi-Bakata Katanga militia staged a recruitment in Kyalwa village.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: OCR: Rally of the Congolese Opposition
column17: Activists of the various political parties making up the Rally of the Opposition coalition rallied in front of the UDPS HQ in Mbuji Mayi.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Congolese soldiers re-occupied the Mwalika area, an ADF stronghold whose population had been forced to grow food for them, without a fight.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: OCR: Rally of the Congolese Opposition
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The OCR staged a rally to protest against a potential third term for President Kabila near Kinshasas Martyrs Stadium which reportedly attracted thousands and included a speech by leading opposition figure Etienne Tshisekedi in which he demanded elections be held by the end of 2016. Police were present during the rally, which later turned into a march, but only minor incidents occurred and no injuries were reported.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A military magistrate was beaten by the personal guard of the commander of the Sokola 1 operation after the magistrate ordered the arrest of two Sokola 1 soldiers for allegedly trying to steal a large amount of military rations which were found in their homes. He was also held by the military intelligence service for 4 hours before being released.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: UDPS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: At least 1 person was killed in clashes between UDPS supporters and police forces in Kinshasa. The fight allegedly started when a police officer was passing the UDPS HQ and was attacked by activists, which led to the officer firing into the crowd while trying to escape. During the incident a bus was torched; police also used tear gas to try to disperse the crowds. There was also an unverified report that a police officer was killed.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Mazembe)
column17: 03 - 08 August. Five Hutu, two Hunde and 11 Nande civilians are killed by Mayi-Mayi groups (mainly Mayi-Mayi Mazembe and Mayi-Mayi Nyatura) in Kibirizi. Seven of the civilians were killed on 07/08, though the exact date(s) of the remaining fatalities are not known. 18 fatalities spread over 6 events between 3 and 8 August.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A miner was allegedly killed by police after being pursued by them for a minor debt in Kpangba, in the Bunia area.

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Kamwina Nsapu militiamen ambushed a train traveling from Kananga to Ilebo in Mfwamba village in Dibataye sector. They severely beat two police officers and stole one of their weapons.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: After a new head of the locality from a local family was allegedly appointed in Ngwa, in the Kongolo area of Tanganyika, the situation was disputed by another family and a brawl broke out, which included the use of machetes. Many people were wounded and houses were destroyed. The two families have been in competition for power in the area for months.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Mazembe)
column17: 03 - 08 August. Five Hutu, two Hunde and 11 Nande civilians are killed by Mayi-Mayi groups (mainly Mayi-Mayi Mazembe and Mayi-Mayi Nyatura) in Kibirizi. Seven of the civilians were killed on 07/08, though the exact date(s) of the remaining fatalities are not known. 18 fatalities spread over 6 events between 3 and 8 August.

column6: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: 04 August. MONUSCO was directly targeted on August 4 when suspected Allied Democratic Forces elements fired a rocket-propelled grenade round towards the MONUSCO base in Semliki. As a result of the sustained pressure from the operations, Allied Democratic Forces elements continued to move north, including into Ituri province.

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column17: Kamwina Nspau militiamen occupied the town of Tshenge in Kasai-Central.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia
column17: A Mayi Mayi militia killed an IDP in the Kibirizi area.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Mazembe)
column17: 03 - 08 August. Five Hutu, two Hunde and 11 Nande civilians are killed by Mayi-Mayi groups (mainly Mayi-Mayi Mazembe and Mayi-Mayi Nyatura) in Kibirizi. Seven of the civilians were killed on 07/08, though the exact date(s) of the remaining fatalities are not known. 18 fatalities spread over 6 events between 3 and 8 August.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Hundreds of miners took to the streets in Mungwalu, in the Bunia area, to protest the killing of a miner, allegedly by the police who were pursuing her over a small debt. The miners attacked a police station causing the police to flee, but they later returned and fired shots into the air to disperse the protesters.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: PPRD: Peoples Party for Reconstruction and Democracy
column17: The PPRD organized a march in Lubumbashi to support the ""inclusive national dialogue"" launched by President Kabila.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Residents of Kabamba (Kabare) attacked a police station over accusations that police failed to intervene in a robbery that led to a woman's death. The residents blockaded the main road to Bukavu/Kalehe/Goma. Police were unable to disperse the protesters despite reinforcements from Kavumu.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Mazembe)
column17: 03 - 08 August. Five Hutu, two Hunde and 11 Nande civilians are killed by Mayi-Mayi groups (mainly Mayi-Mayi Mazembe and Mayi-Mayi Nyatura) in Kibirizi. Seven of the civilians were killed on 07/08, though the exact date(s) of the remaining fatalities are not known. 18 fatalities spread over 6 events between 3 and 8 August.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia
column17: Property destruction: Mayi Mayi militiamen set fire to the Ngoroba IDP camp in the Mazembe area of Rutshuru. The inhabitants fled the area and no casualties were reported.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 2 people were found dead in the Nyanzale area of Kibirizi, at least one of the bodies was that of a Nyatura fighter who had been burned alive in his home.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: At least 4 civilians were killed by unidentified gunmen in the Kashalira area.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A soldier and a civilian were killed by unidentified assailants in Kahunga.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Mazembe)
column17: 03 - 08 August. Five Hutu, two Hunde and 11 Nande civilians are killed by Mayi-Mayi groups (mainly Mayi-Mayi Mazembe and Mayi-Mayi Nyatura) in Kibirizi. Seven of the civilians were killed on 07/08, though the exact date(s) of the remaining fatalities are not known. 18 fatalities spread over 6 events between 3 and 8 August.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: The national president of the UDR was abducted by armed men wearing military uniforms in the municipality of NDjili.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A soldier was killed and 3 others wounded by a Mayi Mayi militia attack in the village of Tomombo in Mitwaba.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Mazembe)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 7 civilians were killed in an attack on Kibirizi by Mazembe Mayi Mayi militiamen. Congolese forces arrived during the attack and fought them off.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Mazembe)
column17: A suspected member of the Mazembe Mayi Mayi militia was killed by Nyatura fighters.

column6: Nyatura-FDLR Coalition: Nyatura -Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: At least 7 people were killed and hundreds of homes burned in a raid allegedly by FDLR-Nyatura coalition militiamen on Kibanda.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: About 100 youths demonstrated outside the offices of the representative of the AU in the Gombe commune of Kinshasa to support the inclusion of the representative in the ""political dialogue"" called by the president.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Youths from the Masisi area have set up roadblocks on the road between Masisi and Goma in order to prevent humanitarian work in the area, which contains 30 IDP sites. They accused the NGOs of not living up to the expectations of the population, lacking transparency in their use of funds, and having failed to recruit enough local staff.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: MLC: Movement for the Liberation of Congo
column17: The youth wing of the MLC held a demonstration and burned tires in front of the office of the federation of the new province of Ecuador in Mbandaka. The youths disapprove of the current federal committee.

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 9 people were killed in Tshimbulu in an attack by a new militia created by Kamwina Nsapu, the chief of the territory of Dibaya. The attack started with an assault on the residence of the chief of police, where his bodyguard was killed. They then set fire to the police headquarters, the CENI office, the mayors house and other buildings, before killing 4 police offices and wounding 2 others. 4 militiamen were also killed during the incident. The militia was allegedly created to rid Kasai-Central of law enforcement personnel who harass the population.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column8: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column17: 11 FARDC soldiers and a MONUSCO peacekeeper were wounded during operations against ADF rebels in the Beni area. A helicopter dispatched to recover the wounded came under fire and had to turn back. They were successfully evacuated the next day.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: PNC officers arrested 9 young people who were demanding that they be allowed to participate in the ""political dialogue"" called by the president. The officers allegedly beat some local people during the arrest.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Lawyers (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Lawyers in Mbuji-Maya organized a march to request the lifting of immunity for an MP accused of beating up one of their colleagues.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Mazembe)
column17: 03 - 08 August. Five Hutu, two Hunde and 11 Nande civilians are killed by Mayi-Mayi groups (mainly Mayi-Mayi Mazembe and Mayi-Mayi Nyatura) in Kibirizi. Seven of the civilians were killed on 07/08, though the exact date(s) of the remaining fatalities are not known. 18 fatalities spread over 6 events between 3 and 8 August.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia
column17: Looting: Several properties in the Mvula area of Mitwaba were raided by Mayi Mayi militiamen, who fired shots into the air to scare the villagers away.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column8: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column17: FARDC soldiers backed by MONUSCO have engaged in clashes with ADF rebels in the south Eringeti area since the beginning of an operation against them on Aug.8, which has resulted in an unconfirmed number of ADF rebels killed (coded as 10). 3 soldiers were also killed, and another 3 wounded.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Students (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Over 200 students from the Faculty of Agricultural Sciences Institute of Yangambi in Kisangani demanded the rehabilitation of a dormitory they had been housed. The dormitory was burned down in July by University of Kisangani students.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Residents of Kashusha barricaded the main road leading to the Kavumu airport to protest the killing of 3 people during a robbery the day before, and a growing sense of insecurity in the area due to banditry.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A group of 6 assailants armed with guns and machetes attacked a group of Nyabibwe residents returning from the Kiburi mining site, killing 1. They are believed to be part of a network of shepherds from the Kalehe highlands who often attacked residents of the area.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: FDLR-FOCA: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda- Forces fighting Abacunguzi
column17: Arrests: The commander of the FDLR-FOCA was captured by FARDC at Katiru in Rutshuru territory.

column6: Okito Dimba Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Lotelama Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: At least 15 people were killed and 60 houses burnt in a clash between two rival camps of the ruling family in the villages of Okitodimba and Lotelama in the Okolongo sector of Sankuru.

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 11 policemen and 9 members of Kamwina Nsapus (Jean-Pierre Pangi) militia, including the leader himself, were killed in a clash with police in the Tshimbulu area which was allegedly started by Nsapus militia. 4 other police are missing, while 40 militiamen were captured during the fighting.

column6: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column17: Official sources claim at least 42 civilians were killed (civil society sources in Beni say 51) with machetes by suspected ADF rebels in an overnight attack on the Rwangoma neighbourhood of Beni territory.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Vigilante Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 13 August 2016, residents of Nyabibwe in Kalehe captured 6 gunmen and relieved them of their weapons following an attack on a group of Nyabibwe residents who had been returning from a mining site. The gunmen were handed over to FARDC.

column6: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column17: Official sources claim at least 42 civilians were killed (civil society sources in Beni say 51) with machetes by suspected ADF rebels in an overnight attack on the Rwangoma neighbourhood of the territory.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 3 people were killed and several injured in an attack by unidentified assailants at Runingu market in South Kivu. The mastermind of the attack was later arrested at Kavimvira on the border between Burundi and DR-Congo.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia
column9: Hutu Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 3 Hutu residents of Nyanale were kidnapped by Mayi Mayi militiamen from their fields near Nyanzale. They were allegedly found dead in Katwe, near Nyanzale, a few days later.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: 6 FDLR rebels and 14 local fighters aligned with the FDLR were killed during clashes with Congolese soldiers during August as part of the Sokola II operation (the 6 rebel deaths coded in another event). 10 fighters were also arrested and 7 others were sent to the UN mission.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: UDPS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column17: Pro-Bruno Mavungu activists (the former secretary general of the UDPS) and youth members of the UDPS clashed outside their parties former HQ in the Limete commune of Kinshasa. At least 2 people were injured in the fight. The youth members of the UDPS were allegedly armed with machetes and iron bars and were accused of being sent by Felix Tshisekedi to disrupt the Mavungu supporters meeting.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 3 members of the Catholic NGO Caritas were kidnapped as their convoy passed through the Mpati area of the Bashali-Mokoto grouping in the Masisi area. A second vehicle escaped although it was fired upon, resulting in wounds to a German journalist. The hostages were later released after a ransom was paid.

column6: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column17: 3 people were killed in an attack by suspected ADF rebels in Mayimoya in the Oicha area.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Hutu Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Nande Communal Group (Democratic Republic of Congo); Hunde Communal Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: After the bodies of 3 Hutu residents of Nyanzale were found dead, Hutu in the area rioted and burned the houses of Nande and Hunde in the area who they accuse of being behind the killings.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: People marched from Butembo to Beni to protest against insecurity in their territory. Once they arrived these protesters were blocked outside the city by security forces while clashes occurred in Beni between protesters and security forces there (it was not clear if these protesters became involved in the clashes between protesters and police in Beni).

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column17: Arrests: 80 ADF rebels were arrested in Beni territory by FARDC in connection with the capture of an Imam who was engaged in youth recruitment in the area.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Thousands of demonstrators protested in Beni against insecurity in their territory following the killing of more than 40 civilians by suspected ADF rebels in Rwangoma and a smaller attack in Mayi moya the day before. The protesters raised barricades and clashed with police who used tear gas to attempt to disperse them, and later soldiers who reinforced them. At least 2 people, including a protester who died of a gunshot wound and a police officer, were reported killed and 5 wounded in the violence. At least some of those injured were hit by gunshots.

column6: Nande Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Hunde Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Hutu Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 4 Hutu residents of Bwalanda were killed when Nande and Hunde groups from the Nyanzale area went to the village and burned houses belonging to Hutu. The body of one of those killed was found the next day.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A woman accused of being part of the ADF was beaten to death and had her body set on fire by residents of Beni during protests against ADF attacks in the territory.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Hutu Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: In response to an attack on Bwalanda by Nande and Hunde, Hutu residents of Nyanzale burned most of the remaining Nande/Hunde houses in the town (rioting had led to arson attacks earlier in the week).

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: UDPS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column17: After the UDPS headquarters was allegedly stormed and burned by police forces during the night, 3 charred bodies were found in the wreckage the next morning. At least 2 others opposition HQs were also reportedly burned during the night, including those of FONUS and the MLP.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: OCR: Rally of the Congolese Opposition
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Continued clashes in Kinshasa between large numbers of protesters and police over election delays resulted in 15 killed, while 49 civilians were said to have been killed in total. As many as 3 more police were allegedly killed in the second day of violence. A police station and 12 other police positions were looted and set on fire by rioters according to police. About 126 injuries were also reported, across the protests in Kinshasa, Beni, Matadi and Goma. As many as 368 people were arrested by the PNC, FARDC and ANR (intelligence agency) across protests in Bandundu, Beni, Goma, Kindu, Kisangani, Kinshasa, Matadi and Tshikapa. These totals were according to the UN office for Human Rights.

column6: APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
column9: Ngiti Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A group of demobilized APCLS fighters who were quarted at the Kamina military base are suspected of having buried alive 8 other demobilized fighters from the Ngiti ethnic group as they believed they were being favoured in the selection process for reintegration. At least 1 of those who were buried escaped and later testified against the group.

column6: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 7 people were killed in an overnight attack by suspected ADF rebels in the town of Rwenzori in the Kasinga area. 15 houses were also reported burned. FARDC soldiers intervened to stop the violence.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 2 days of ""dead city"" were announced in the Tshangu district of Kinshasa following violent protests in metropolitan Kinshasa.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: ""Three INGO national staff members were abducted on the Kinyandonyi-Rugarama road in North Kivu when their vehicle was ambushed by unknown armed assailants.""

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Clashes were reported between the Kamwina Nsapu militia and military forces around Kananga airport and in the city centre. The militia allegedly managed to take control of the airport at one point during the 2-days of clashes, but were later ousted from their position after being surrounded. At least 28 people were killed in the violence, allegedly primarily militiamen but also including 8 deaths among Congolese forces. At least 3 civilians were killed, including a hostess of Congo Airways, during the clashes. Between 52-185 militiamen were captured in the fighting. 30 civilians were also injured. Other sources had the casualty figures from 46 to ""hundreds"".

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A suspected Kamwina Nsapu militiamen was stopped by police in the Salongo market area of Kananga, leading to a clash involving gunfire. The clash caused a panic in the area, resulting in 2 killed and several wounded in a consequent stampede.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 1 person was killed and 20 injured after 2 groups of demobilized combatants clashed with machetes and clubs after an argument at a bar. The fight also led to a few houses being burned.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Clashes were still ongoing in the morning between Kamwina Nsapu militiamen and Congolese security forces although no casualties were reported.

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Clashes were still ongoing in the morning between Kamwina Nsapu militiamen and Congolese security forces although no casualties were reported.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Students (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Students of the University of Kisangani protested to demand the release of one of their classmates arrested during countrywide protests on Sept.19. After the students left their campus and marched on the city centre, police arrived to disperse them with tear gas and aerial firing.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 17 people allegedly died after a drunken soldier in civilian clothes began firing into the air in Beni, causing a panic among the population who believed the firing was from an ADF attack. 15 people allegedly drowned while trying to escape the area, while 2 were killed due to heart attacks.

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Kamwina Nsapu militiamen clashed with security forces on the Mwamba-Mbuyi/Tshimpindinga axis. No casualties reported.

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Property destruction: Kamwina Nsapu militiamen burned a police station in Diofa, Demba territory. There were no reports of clashes with police.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Armed South Sudanese rebels decapitated a man abducted in Bangalu, DRC.

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column17: Kamwina Nsapu militiamen occupied Dimbelenge and some surrounding areas. From Septy.27-29, the militiamen allegedly ransacked and destroyed police stations, offices of the securiy services, and administrative buildings.

column6: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column17: 4 ADF rebels and 3 Congolese soldiers were killed in a clash in the Nyaleke area of Beni territory. A conflicting report said that some of those killed were civilians instead.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: OCR: Rally of the Congolese Opposition
column17: The OCR declared 3-days of mourning starting on Sept.27 to remember all those who have been killed in the Beni area over the last two years. Most of the city was shut down.

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column17: Kamwina Nsapu militiamen occupied the Mashala area of Lusambu territory.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: FARDC soldiers have occupied Dimbelenge following Kamwina Nsapu militiamens recent ""sacking"" of the city. There does not appear to have been a fight to take back the town.

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Kamwina Nsapu militiamen again clashed with security forces on the Mwamba-Mbuyi/Tshimpindinga axis after a recent battle in the area. No casualties reported.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019) Garamba National Park
column17: Several people were killed (coded as 3) and others injured in a confrontation between Garamba park guards backed by Congolese soldiers and foreign poachers called Oudas in the Azande area of Dungu. 2 of those killed were FARDC soldiers as well as one civilian, while others were injured including at least one soldier. LRA members and South Sudanese soldiers have been known to poach in the area.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A number of notables from the eastern DR-Congo engaged in a sit-in in front of the provincial governors office to demand the relocation of alleged South Sudanese rebels loyal to Riek Machar who have been staying in a camp in the Nyiragongo territory close to Goma.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 01 October. Suspected LRA elements, crossing from South Sudan, reportedly attacked FARDC troops in Nasumba, killing two soldiers and injuring four, while FARDC killed four assailants.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Christian Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Members of the Christian community of Katana burned down two mosques in the area after a Muslim who had allegedly killed a Christian woman took refuge in a mosque.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Displaced people who fled Dimbelenge into surrounding forests following its recent occupation by Kwamina Nsapu militiamen say they have heard clashes between FARDC and the militiamen in the area. This follows the militiamens departure and militaries occupation of the city.

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column17: Movement of forces: Kamwina Nsapu militiamen again returned to Dimbelenge after occupying it earlier in the week, but it was not clear if they occupied it again or clashed with security forces. Their appearance did lead to displacement of the population however.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: More than 300 SNEL labourers protested to demand the regularization of their jobs.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: Congolese soldiers repulsed attacks by FRPI militiamen on the Tarama and Mulandi villages in the Walendu Bindi area of Ituri. The militiamen did manage to loot shops and steal money during the raid, which resulted in injuries to a child.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019) Prison Guards
column7: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A civilian inmate at a military prison in Libenge (South Ubangi) was killed by a soldier either during an escape attempt, or due to dispute over a contract with the soldier.

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: FRPI militiamen loot shops and steal money during a raid in the Tarama and Mulandi villages in the Walendu Bindi area of Ituri, which resulted in injuries to a child.

column17: 02-04 February - Suspected ADF elements attacked the villages of Kasinga, Malolu and Mamudioma, reportedly killing four civilians and injuring three

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 7 people have been kidnapped in the Ishasha area of Rutshuru since the beginning of October (reported on Oct.9).

column6: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column17: On 5 October 2016, suspected ADF rebels killed one person, seriously injured another, and abducted several in raids on Mayangose and Kasinga in Beni territory.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Angry youths ransacked the HQ of FONER in Mahagi in Ituri after a promised rehabilitation project was found to have not yet been started despite FONER saying it had already spent $39m USD.

column6: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column17: Suspected ADF rebels killed one person, seriously injured another, and abducted several in raids on Mayangose and Kasinga in Beni territory.

column9: Luba Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column7: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A youth was shot by a joint FARDC-PNC patrol in the Mbandaka area when he was mistaken for a militia member.

column6: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column17: At least 7 civilians were killed, 5 by gunshot and 2 by machete, in an attack by suspected ADF rebels northeast of Beni. 2 people were also injured and three houses and a school burnt down. FARDC soldiers intervened, and one soldier and 2 attackers killed in the ensuing fight.

column6: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: At least 7 civilians were killed, 5 by gunshot and 2 by machete, in an attack by suspected ADF rebels northeast of Beni. 2 people were also injured and three houses and a school burnt down. FARDC soldiers intervened, and one soldier and 2 attackers killed in the ensuing fight.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A young girl was injured by a machete and three houses burnt down during an attack on Kashalira village in Rutshuru by 7 Nyatura militiamen. FARDC soldiers arrived to repulse the militiamen who were allegedly looking for a particular person who they were unable to locate, which led to the outburst of violence.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: UDPS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column17: Looting: Bruno Tshibala, Deputy Secretary-General of the Union for Democracy and Social Progress (UDPS), was arrested by the Immigration agents while he was in Kinshasa International Airport to board a flight to Brussels on 9 October. He remains in custody and has been charged with conspiring to perpetrate a massacre, looting and devastation, the criminal charges that appear to be motivated by political considerations.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura)
column17: A young girl was injured by a machete and three houses burnt down during an attack on Kashalira village in Rutshuru by 7 Nyatura militiamen. FARDC soldiers arrived to repulse the militiamen who were allegedly looking for a particular person who they were unable to locate, which led to the outburst of violence.

column6: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-)
column17: Movement of forces: Armed men in UPDF uniforms with ""major engines of war"" were seen operating in the Watalinga sector of North Kivu (close to the border) with villagers saying they disappeared into Virungu National Park.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Bakata Katanga)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Agreement: Gedeon Kyungu, leader of the Bakata Katanga militia who had escaped from prison following a conviction for crimes against humanity, surrendered with about 100 fighters at a ceremony in Malambwe village. The circumstances of his surrender were not clear.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: PPRD: Peoples Party for Reconstruction and Democracy
column17: Primarily youth PPRD members staged a sit-in outside the official residence of the provincial governor to denounce his alleged creation of divisions within the party.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A clash broke out between FARDC and South Sudanese armed forces in Kengezi base, a Congolese locality along the border, after FARC soldiers disarmed a South Sudanese soldier who had crossed into DR-Congo. When they refused to turn over the soldier, who was wounded, the South Sudanese forces accused them of collaborating with rebels and attacked. No casualties were reported.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 2 Kamwina Nsapu militiamen were killed in a clash with FARDC soldiers in the Kena Nkuna area.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A clash was reported between Kamwina Nsapu militiamen and FARDC soldiers in Kena Nkuna. 18 militiamen were killed and 4 others captured during the events. Before the clash broke out, the militiamen looted government buildings, residences of state officials, and the local CENI office.

column6: Batwa Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Luba Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: After some Batwa women were assaulted by Luba in Kabumba village, Batwa community members attacked and killed 3 members of the Luba community in Kabalo territory.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Members of a new self-defense (Mayi Mayi) militia ""Body of Christ"" took up arms in the Mutiri neighbourhood of Butembo and were allegedly planning to go to Beni to protect against the ADF. As they were arming themselves with machetes, slingshots and arrows, FARDC soldiers intervened and opened fire on them, leading to a clash that resulted in 3 fatalities. 2 of those killed were civilians who were reportedly hit by stray bullets, while one soldier also died. A different source said 2 soldiers and 3 civilians were killed.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Luba Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Batwa Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo); Women (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: After Batwa women refused to pay a tax to the Luba village chief of Kabumba, residents of the village assaulted the women.

column6: Militia (Elements)
column7: Bantu Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Batwa Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Property destruction: Between 86-152 schools were burned as a result of ethnic violence between Bantus and Batwas in Kabalo territory in October.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Taxi Drivers (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 7 people were killed during a demonstration by taxi drivers against insecurity. The protesters burned local buildings including a police station and threw stones at others. In response police resorted to aerial firing to disperse them, killing 3 and wounding at least 4 others who died of their injuries in hospital.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 4 militiamen and 2 others were killed during a clash between Congolese forces and Mayi Mayi Simba militiamen in the Kanyaboibi area of Ituri.

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: Looting: FRPI militiamen raided Ngasu village in the Irumu area. The attackers fired several shots into the air before looting property, including livestock and vehicles. FARDC soldiers who were based nearby intervened and attempted to pursue the militiamen but there was no report of a clash.

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column17: Looting: Kamwina Nsapu militiamen attacked the localities of Mupompa, Tshiatshiatshia and Mukamba. It was not clear if they clashed with security forces or if there were any casualties.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Following the deaths of 7 protesters the day before, angry youths erected barricades in the North and South Kalinga and Mambangu suburbs of Baraka.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Following the deaths of 7 protesters the day before, angry youths erected barricades in the North and South Kalinga and Mambangu suburbs of Baraka.

column7: Luba Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Batwa Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: After Batwa community members killed 3 Luba in the Kabalo territory, a Luba self-defense group killed 13 Batwa in the same area.

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 2 FRPI militiamen and a Congolese soldier were killed in a clash in the Mukrio area. The FRPI militiamen had attacked a FARDC position.

column6: Batwa Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Luba Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Violence between Batwa and Luba militias in Kabalo territory continued, resulting in 1 Luba and 3 Batwa killed.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: OCR: Rally of the Congolese Opposition
column17: Beni and Butembo saw small protests of aroud 50 people each to mark the protest strike called by the OCR and to demand the departure of President Kabila.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: OCR: Rally of the Congolese Opposition
column17: Beni and Butembo saw small protests of aroud 50 people each to mark the protest strike called by the OCR and to demand the departure of President Kabila.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: OCR: Rally of the Congolese Opposition
column17: Goma partially followed the OCRs ""dead city"" protest strike, with traffic normal but many shops remaining closed. 200 people also demonstrated to demand the departure of President Kabila.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: OCR: Rally of the Congolese Opposition
column17: The Congolese opposition (OCR) called a 1-day ""dead city"" protest strike. The strike was largely observed in Kinshasa and Mbuji Mayi, an opposition stronghold, but ignored in most other major cities. In the cities where the strike was observed, several youth groups occupied the streets and wore yellow/held up yellow cards to signify their anger with the government.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: OCR: Rally of the Congolese Opposition
column17: The Congolese opposition (OCR) called a 1-day ""dead city"" protest strike. The strike was largely observed in Kinshasa and Mbuji Mayi, an opposition stronghold, but ignored in most other major cities. In the cities where the strike was observed, several youth groups occupied the streets and wore yellow/held up yellow cards to signify their anger with the government.

column6: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: 19 October. MONUSCO establishes a base at Nyunzu.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Kintobongo Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 2 people were killed during an incursion by unidentified militiamen in Kintobongo village in the Bukama area. About 10 armed attackers stormed the village and looted houses. The villagers attempted to fight off the attack but only had access to hunting weapons and blades.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column16: Radio Okapi; Agence Congolaise de Presse
column17: At least 11 militiamen were killed in violent clashes between Congolese soldiers and Body of Christ Mayi Mayi militiamen. The clash occurred at Kabasha hill where about 100 fighters were gathered. 1 FARDC soldier was injured during the clash and many were arrested after.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A priest was killed by unidentified armed men in Lubumbashi.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 2 more Body of Christ militiamen were killed in continued clashes today with Congolese soldiers in the Kabasha hill area.

column6: PRFI: Patriotic Resistance Forces of Ituri
column17: 19-23 October. From 19 to 23 October, suspected FRPI elements raided eight villages on the Bunia-Beni axis, during which at least one civilian was wounded. Exact locations not known.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column17: ADF rebels and Congolese forces clashed in the Mayi Moya area. 3 civilians were killed during the incident.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: Arrests: Col Mucebo Sofuni Habyarimana, a senior member of the Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda, a rebel group that includes members accused of carrying out the 1994 genocide in Rwanda, was arrested in Kiwanja, a village located about 75 kilometres north of Goma, capital of North Kivu and transferred to Goma for questioning.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Families from Butembo and Maboya staged a sit-in in Beni to demand the return of the bodies of children they believe were killed during a clash in Kabasha between Congolese soldiers and Body of Christ militiamen.

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 4 FDLR rebels were killed and 2 others captured after an attack by Congolese soldiers on an FDLR safehouse in the Rutshuru area.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Congolese forces repelled an attack by about 10 armed individuals allegedly from North Kivu on Minova General Hospital. Police also intervened to chase the assailants.

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Arrests: A top commander of the FDLR, Habiarimana Mucebo Sofuni, was captured in the Rutshuru area. It was not clear if he was among those captured on Oct.23.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Colonel Baudouin Yalanda Yagbo, an officer of the Armed Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo, was removed from Tuesday, October 25 by armed men who broke into his home in the neighborhood Museyi, Ngaliema in Kinshasa, and brought to an unknown destination.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: LUCHA: Fight for Change
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The security forces dispersed the protesters in Goma, questioning eight demonstrators, the majority of the Struggle for Change (LUCHA).

column6: Batwa Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Luba Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 26 October. Twa militia elements attacked Luba civilians in the village of Kizika, looting and burning down more than 80 houses and causing the displacement of civilians.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Non-violent activity: The headquarters of citizen Front 2016 was stormed by the Congolese National Police (PNC) who prevented its members from holding a rally to demand respect for the Constitution, those organizations denounce the rights of the man. column17: Police and suspected BDK members clashed in Kimpese. The BDK members had allegedly attacked the Deputy-Minister of Infrastructe's residence over statements he made that the BDK members deemed insulting to their group's spiritual leader. Military forces were later deployed to help deal with the unrest.

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: At least 40 Kamwina Nsapu militiamen attempted to break into the downtown area of Kananga but were repulsed by Congolese soldiers after several hours of clashes. The clashes continued in Nganza in the evening after the militiamen withdrew from the city centre earlier in the day. At least 4 militiamen were killed and 7 people injured, including 2 police. The incident allegedly started as a protest by the militiamen against the arrival of the PM and to demand the departure of the governor of Kasai Central.

column17: Clashes were reported between Congolese forces and former M23 rebels at Songa hill in Busanza group and at Kitagoma. 16 fatalities were reported in fighting between Feb.20-22 (fatalities spread across 5 events). Several other former M23 fighters were also captured.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Clashes were reported between Congolese forces and former M23 rebels at Songa hill in Busanza group and at Kitagoma. 16 fatalities were reported in fighting between Feb.20-22 (fatalities spread across 5 events). Several other former M23 fighters were also captured.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Catholic churches and schools were attacked and in some cases set on fire by unidentified assailants in Lukalaba, Lubumbashi, and Mbuji Mayi. A church in Gbadolite district and another at Katuba-Upemba in the Lubumbashi area were also attacked. These attacks were primarily reported in Haut-Katanga. 4 people were arrested in connection. The incidents are believed to be related to the national political transition agreement.

column17: 5 people were kidnapped from their farms in Kibende. The culprits were suspected to be members of armed groups operating in the area.

column8: Batwa Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 2 people, a nurse and a Batwa militiamen, were killed in a recent clash between Bantu and Batwa ethnic militias in the Tundwa area near Kalemie. 60 other people were also wounded.

column7: Health Workers (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column8: Batwa Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Clashes were reported between Kamwina Nsapu militiamen and security forces in Kananga town.

column17: 6 artisanal miners were kidnapped by Raia Mutomboki militiamen in the Kabare area.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The bodyguard of an MLA got into a confrontation with some motorcyclye taxi drivers blocking a road in Bunia. The bodyguard fired into the crowd, severely injuring one person. The person later died in hsopital.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column7: Teachers (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 7 employees of a Canadian mining company (Banro), including four Congolese, two Tanzanians, and one French national, were kidnapped by unidentified assailants in the Namoya area of Maniema.

column17: 3 police have been killed in attacks by unidentified militiamen on voter registration centres in the Nyamilima, Nyanzale and Birundule localities of Rutshuru (fatalities coded across 3 events). The continuing insecurity in the area has caused CENI to close other registration centres.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: 5 LRA forces ambushed 7 civilians, one after the other, 11km west of Banda, DRC. One of the victims was able to escape while the other 6 (2 women and 4 men) were forced to shell nuts all night. LRA forces also abducted a woman 13 km west of Banda, DRC, while she was on her way to her field with her husband.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Students (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Students from the Higher Institute of Agricultural Studies, Yatolema, protested against illegal barriers erected in their area. They broke one such barrier and set fire to a checkpost of the security forces in the area.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Transport and Ports Corporation (SCTP) employees organized a sit-in outside the administrative building to request payment of four months' salary arrears.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A police officer and 3 members of the BDK were killed in an operation in the Ma Campagne area of Kinshasa which resulted in the arrest of the leader and ""guru"" of the BDK. Additionally, 307 BDK members were arrested.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: An Uruguayan MONUSCO peacekeeper was shot and injured by unidentified assailants in the Kasai-Central region.

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column17: A dozen LUCHA activists protested and staged a sit-in outside the governor's office to demand provincial authorities take steps to lower the price of corn.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: Looting: Suspected LRA forces attacked the community of Disolo, DRC, and looted a person involved in the local school, stealing the salary of the teachers, and looted the health center.

column6: Military Forces of Angola (1975-)
column17: 2 people were allegedly abducted by Angolan security forces from Kai-Nganga village in the Lukula area. They were suspected of searching for FLEC militants who had crossed the border. At least one of those taken was injured by gunfire first.

column6: Bangubangu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 7 employees of a mining company were kidnapped by a group composed of members of the Bangu Bangu ethnic group in the Salambila area of Kabambare territory. Foreign nationals were among those kidnapped.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column6: Batwa Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Bantu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A new wave of IDPs has been reported fleeing clashes between the Batwa and Bantu ethnic groups in southeastern DR-Congo.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Residents of Kindu protested and demanded to be allowed to stone two alleged thieves captured in the area. Police used tear gas to disperse the demonstrators.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 2 journalists were seriously wounded by shrapnel from a grenade allegedly thrown by a police officer while they were covering a protest by residents of Kindu who were demanding to be allowed to stone two alleged thieves. The journalists were standing apart from the crowd and were reportedly directly targeted.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: Looting: A suspected LRA group looted the community of Bandueli, DRC. They looted food and non-food items between 03:00 and 06:00. Security forces were sent to investigate the incident.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Police fired into the air to disperse a protest by motorcycle taxi drivers. The drivers were protesting the death of a colleague after being hit by a police vehicle.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 18 Kamwina Nsapu militiamen and 2 police were reported killed in a clash in the Mwene Ditu area. Another police officer was seriously wounded, as well as several civilians.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia
column17: Looting: Mayi Mayi militiamen allegedly stole at least 50 fishing boats between Mar.9-13 from fishermen on Lake Edward.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: Looting: 6 suspected LRA forces looted 4 motorcyclists on their way Banda, DRC. The assailants spoke Acholi, poor Lingala, and Swahili, they wore a mix of civilian and military clothing, and were armed with 5 AK-type weapons and a machete.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 12 March: 2 UN employees, an American and a Swede-Chilean, and 4 DR-Congo nationals were abducted by unidentified assailants on Tshimbulu Rd near a bridge over the Moyo River in Kasai-Central. The UN officials were in region investigating violence and abuses. The two UN employees were found dead on March 28, 2017, and the 4 Congolese people who accompanied were found dead on May 7, 2018. Later investigations implicated military officers in the killings.

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Clashes were reported in Mwene Ditu between as many as 300 Kamwina Nsapu militiamen who had previously entered the locality and security forces. The clashes lasted between Mar.11-12. No injuries were reported but at least 3 militiamen were arrested. Several people (coded as 3 across 2 events) were killed over the course of the weekend.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column17: Kamwina Nsapu militiamen were reported to be in control of several towns in the Luilu area of Lomani. An MP from the area also claimed they have engaged in killings (unknown fatalities).

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: The body of a resident of Mapanda was found in the Bendera area. This is believed to have motivated the killing of the traditional chief of Kanambe a few days later.

column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A Congolese soldier and 3 Mayi Mayi militiamen were killed in a clash in the Kalau suburb of Beni. The Mayi Mayi militiamen burned some houses before being driven off. 2 soldiers were also injured and 6 militiamen captured.

column17: 2 youths were killed by a landmine explosion in the Gokpa area of Djugu. A third was severely injured and taken to hospital.

column17: Displaced people arriving in Kibirizi reported that they were fleeing an attack by Nyatura fighters on Kishishe in the Bwito chieftaincy near Rutshuru.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: At least one militia member was killed during a clash between as many as 100 Kamwina Nsapu fighters and Congolese soldiers in Tshimbulu. MONUSCO forces were deployed to reinforce the Congolese soldiers and also came under fire.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: FRPI militiamen clashed with Congolese soldiers and stole election-related materials from a registration centre in Kamatsi.

column17: FRPI militiamen raided an INEC camp in the Kagaba area and kidnapped a data entry operator.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Batwa Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Unidentified gunmen killed the traditional chief of Kanambe (a Batwa community) and 4 members of his family in the Bendera area of Tanganyika. This took place 4 days after the discovery of the body of a resident of nearby Mapanda village.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 17 new mass graves were discovered by UN investigators in the areas where the conflict between security forces and Kamwina Nsapu militiamen has been ongoing. 15 of these were found in Tshimbulu, while 2 were found in the Kienke area, while all date back to Mar.26-30 (reported on Apr.21). UN high commissioner for human rights accused the army of killing those in the graves. At least 74 bodies attributed to the military's operations (1 fatality already covered by battles in the area).

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column9: Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019); Tchokwe Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo); Pende Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo); Tetela Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Kamwina Nsapu attacked Shamandongo village in late March. They rounded up the government agent, the chief and an alleged sorcerer and held a ritual killing, using a child soldier. They also burned down the houses of Tchokwe, Pende and Tetela villagers.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The Diocesan Commission for Social Communications of Kananga and displaced people from the area claim that security forces in Nganza have engaged in killings and extortion in relation to hunting down Kamwina Nsapu militia fighters. Later reports by rights groups assert that 40 civilians were killed during the sweeps.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 17 new mass graves were discovered by UN investigators in the areas where the conflict between security forces and Kamwina Nsapu militiamen has been ongoing. 15 of these were found in Tshimbulu, while 2 were found in the Kienke area, while all date back to Mar.26-30 (reported on Apr.21). column17: 16 people, mostly farmers, were abducted and later released by suspected Burundian rebels in the Kiliba area.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Youths erected barricades using burned tires and stones to protest in different neighbourhoods of Lubumbashi over the breakdown of negotiations to solve the political situation. Police backed by Congolese soldiers dispersed the protesters in different places. One police officer was reported wounded in the incidents, while the office of the National Insurance Company was set on fire in the Kampemba area.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia
column17: 2 transporters were abducted from Nyakabere by local militiamen. A ransom was demanded for their release.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Gunfire heard in Kananga overnight was reported to be clashes between Kamwina Nsapu militiamen and police. One person was reported killed.

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column17: Kamwina Nsapu militiamen took control of Luebo and burned public buildings, including the CENI offices, and those belonging to the Catholic church, including a local convent. At least 8 people were reported killed, and at least one person's body was mutilated, during the attack.

column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Clashes were reported in the Luebo and Tshimbulu areas between Kamwina Nsapu militiamen and security forces. Fatalities were reported in Tshimbulu (unknown number ).

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A local human rights activists in Kananga has claimed that between 100-148 people were targeted for extrajudicial killings by security forces during search operations for Kamwina Nsapu militia members in the area. column17: Cinq village in Kasai was attacked by Bana Mura militia organised by FARDC commanders. Luba and Lulua villagers were rounded up and shot or killed by machetes. Villagers who tried to escape were stopped at a military checkpoint on the road out of the village and killed or raped. Bana Mura invaded the hospital, killing some patients and medical personnel. The UN has corroborated 116 deaths in Cinq. Many of the villagers who escaped have been mutilated. The few Kamwina present in the village fled, without reported clashes with the Bana Mura.
