column17: The police subcommission in Aveba, a city in the province of Ituri, was ransacked by a group of angry demonstrators protesting against ""police harassment"" after a person is allegedly killed by a policeman. The circumstances of the killing are not explained (could be criminal or personal).

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Residents of Mahagi riot in response to the killing of two shopkeepers by men who appear to be from the military. Riots start on Saturday, continue Sunday and on Monday the police and military engage the rioters.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Young people from the civil society of the Tshopo demand the resignation of the governor of this province. The youths accuse the governor of mismanagement and impunity.

column6: FOREBU: Republican Forces of Burundi
column17: Two people were killed and four others seriously injured during an attack on a public transport minibus in Kabengwa, south of the city of Uvira in South Kivu. Local officials accuse Burundian dissident group FOREBU of carrying out the attack.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A senior army officer and his bodyguard are killed by unidentified gunmen in Kibirizi. A motorcycle rider also dies in the exchange.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: After the killing of a senior officer and another soldier, soldiers enter Kibirizi and fire shots. Two civilians are fatally hit.

column6: Lendu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Hema Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Walendu Bindi militia occupied the village, looting cattle, torching huts, and kidnapping Hema civilians.

column6: Lendu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Hema Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Walendu Bindi militia occupied the village, looting cattle, torching huts, and kidnapping Hema civilians.

column6: Hema Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Lendu Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Hema ethnic militia attacked Lendu villagers, shooting a person dead and burning a 12 year old to death.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019) Prison Guards
column17: 3 prisoners starve to death in Matadi prison

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Aid Workers (Democratic Republic of Congo); Civilians (International); Aid Workers (International)
column17: ""Over 30 INGO and NGO staff members were abducted when militiamen ambushed and fired at a convoy of four INGO and NGO vehicles on the Mwenga-Tubimbi road. Most of the abductees were rescued during a rescue operation but six staff members (including one international) were still being held by the militia. One of the drivers was seriously wounded in the attack and taken to the hospital.""

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column17: Militiamen claiming to be Chief Kamuina Nsapu beheaded two traditional chiefs on Saturday (May 6th) in the locality of Maswika, in the territory of Luiza (Central Kasai).

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: UNAFEC: Union of Nationalist Federalists of Congo Party
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The police and military prevented Gabriel Kyungu wa Kumwanza from holding a rally in Lubumbashi. They arrested some supporters, other supporters fled and took refuge in the MONUSCO office.

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column17: Between 05 - 10 April. Kamwina Nsapu attacks Kazumba territory. The militia also attacked several other locations including Luiza, Kasai Central and Kamonia; source claims five dead overall.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A military patrol came across an armed group that had established an illegal roadblock. The two groups exchanged fire. One of the roadblock attendants was killed.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 3 vehicles carrying soldiers arrived in Tshisuku on the market day. They threw teargas and looted. When traders resisted, the soldiers opened fire. It is unclear how many people were killed.

column6: Nyatura-FDLR Coalition: Nyatura -Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The Nyatura FDLR coalition attacked a military position in Kitshanga at 2am. 3 people were killed and 4 others injured.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A group of LRA rebels unsuccessfully attacked peasants working in their fields. The peasants were rescued by the military.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: UPDS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 50 UPDS cadres attacked the Limete Police Station, setting alight a troop transport vehicle and a tent. 28 prisoners escaped and police officers were beaten. 100 police officers surrounded the UPDS headquarters and refused to allow UPDS supporters into or out of the building. A policeman later died of burn injuries.

column6: Bana Mura
column7: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019); Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: Luba Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo); Lulua Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 100 Bana Mura militia, led by a FARDC major and some police officers attacked Tshitundu There are 8 confirmed deaths from the attack, including the village's Luba representative, who was publicly executed at the beginning of the attack.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: 20 LRA militants abducted 7 civilians as they travelled from Banda to Kpasi. They were forced to carry looted goods and then released.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: The supervisor of a cocoa purchasing company was kidnapped in Mambasa.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A taxi driver and his passenger were taken hostage by an armed group at a roadblock. The group is demanding USD2000 per hostage to release them.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura)
column8: CNRD: National Council for Renewal and Democracy
column17: The CNRD forces attacked a position held by Nyatura militia, who were under the command of Kasongo. A Nyatura fighter was reportedly wounded.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Suspected LRA rebels came to loot the granaries of the villagers, but were repelled by soldiers.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Some 100 residents of villages in Kaponda demonstrated in front of the Lubumbashi courthouse to protest against the authorities, who they accuse of having sold their villages and fields to 3rd parties.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 2 armed men attacked houses in Kashusha. They killed 2 members of a family.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 2 armed men attacked a store in Miti. The owner managed to escape, but was wounded. They looted goods.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: UPDS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column17: Movement of forces: The police blockaded the UPDS leadership in their headquarters.

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column17: Kamwina Nsapu militia from Lwebo attacked a village in the Lombelo area of Demba. They burned about 100 houses and killed and decapitated 2 boys.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura)
column8: CNRD: National Council for Renewal and Democracy
column17: 2 Nyatura factions, led by Colonels Kasongo and Jean-Marie, formed a coalition and attacked positions held by CNRD fighters. Police report that 17 NDC-R fighters were killed.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: NGOs held a sit-in at the Provincial Governor's offices to protest the authorities' failure to act on the violence against Tshiluba-speaking groups in Tshikapa.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Villagers have barricaded the road to prevent MMG mining company vehicles from passing. They are angry because they feel that MMG is cheating them out of their land.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: UPDS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress; Women (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Female UPDS members held a protest to demand the release of party leaders blockaded in the headquarters. The police broke up the protest violently, firing rubber bullets and teargas that caused several injuries.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A FARDC patrol injured and captured the leader of the Mayi Mayi Nyatura militia, David Komayombi in a clash.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: 23 LRA militants abducted 16 civilians near Parka. They were forced to carry looted goods. 8 were released later in the day. 8 were held for 2 days.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 4 policemen shot at a man who they were arresting. People from his neighbourhood were angered and mobbed the policemen. One was killed and another was badly beaten.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Mazembe)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 5 Mayi Mayi militia attacked a local police station with fire-arms and a rocket launcher. They released 3 of the detainees.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Several women were raped by FARDC forces in Mudiadia. The FARDC forces were conducting a door to door search for Kamwina Nsapu militants.

column6: CNRD: National Council for Renewal and Democracy
column17: CNRD fighters attacked a Nyatura of Kasongo post at 4am. They drove out the Nyatura and proceeded towards Kalengera. Inhabitants nearby have fled.

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column17: Nearly 20 customary chiefs were decapitated in Luiza and Kazumba between January and June 2017 by Kamwina Nsapu

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column17: Nearly 20 customary chiefs were decapitated in Luiza and Kazumba between January and June 2017 by Kamwina Nsapu

column6: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
column17: 30 people were taken hostage by the ADF from villages around Beni.

column6: BDK: Bunda Dia Kongo
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019) Prison Guards
column9: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Members of Bunda Dia Kongo stormed a prison in Kinshasa to free the leader of their movement, Ne Mwanda Nsemi. Up to 600 other prisoners escaped and 50 people were killed.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: LUCHA: Fight for Change
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Activists in LUCHA organised a sit-in at the Mbuji Mayi Attorney General's office to demand the publication of the Election Calendar. 4 protesters were arrested. They were releassed on 19/5

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Protesters took to the streets to demand the resignation of Abdalah Pene Mbaka, Governor of Ituri Province. The police fired teargas and live ammunition to disperse the protest.

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: There was heavy fighting between Kamwina Nsapu militia and FARDC forces. The Kamwina Nsapu militia had high numbers of child soldiers.

column6: Bana Mura
column9: Luba Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo); Lulua Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Bana Mura militia attacked Mwakapenga village, in Kamonia, in mid-May. 11 people were burned alive in their home and others were hacked to death by machetes. 17 Lulua and Luba villagers were killed.

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: May 2017. During the month of May, FRPI executed one person summarily and raped six others in Ituri. Dozens of other HR abuses reported though specific instances unknown.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Dozens of Tshibala supporters invaded the People's Palace before the investiture of the government. Police blocked the entrance to the hall for anyone wearing party regalia.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: 8 LRA kidnapped 3 villagers from Ndamana, in Ango. 1 was killed and the other 2 were released.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: FARDC soldiers destroyed a Mayi Mayi position in Kilobuze, near Kitingi. They killed 2 militants and seized an AK47 rifle.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: LRA forces attacked a military position in Bamangana, killing a sergeant and a civilian (a Mbororo herdsman). 19 people were kidnapped during the attack.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 3 people (an attacker, a soldier, and a police officer) were killed in an attack on a Canadian mine in Namoya. The mine owner, Banro, has announced that it has suspended operations in the mine.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 3 TV5 journalists were beaten and assaulted by the police for reporting on the prison escape in Kinshasa.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Prisoners (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Dozens of prisoners escaped from a jail in Kasangulu.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: An LRA group ambushed a hunter, but he managed to escape. He reportedly shot an LRA as they pursued him.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Strike:Civil Society groups organised a strike in Kavumu to denounce the killings in Sud-Kivu. Schools and markets did not open.

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column17: About 40 Kamwina Nsapu militia attacked Nguej village at around 1900. They abducted the local chief and torched 25 houses.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Strike:Civil Society groups organised a strike in Miti to denounce the killings in Sud-Kivu. Schools and markets did not open.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Prisoners (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 14 prisoners escaped from the Kalemie Prison on Friday. Only 1 has been recaptured.

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Following an attack on a village the previous day, the FARDC launched a counter-offensive.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A police officer was killed and his body was dumped in the Katoka 2 market. Militia fired gunshots into the air after the police officer's body was discovered.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Mazembe)
column17: The Mayi Mayi Mazembe militia attacked the village of Ngoroba in Rutshuru. 3 people were killed and 40 houses were burned down.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: An artisanal miner was shot dead by unidentified assailants.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: The head of CENI wass kidnapped for 3 days. CENI was accused of failing to pay the debt that they owe to local businesses which lent them fuel and resources to use in the voter registration process.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A 17 year old was kidnapped by an unidentified group.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Simba)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Mayi Mayi Simba occupied the Kalay Boeing Mine in Walikale.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: CENI: Independent National Electoral Committee
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: CENI ennumerators protested outside the offices in Mbandaka to demand payment of their February wages. They tore down part of the fence and lit a fire to paralyse the activities in the office. The police dispersed the protest and arrested a protester.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Taxi drivers in Kikwit held a demonstration outside the Town Hall to protest the high taxes that they are forced to pay.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Arrests: Following the escape of prisoners from a Kinshasa jail, the police have carried out a mass-crackdown to re-arrest the escapees. An unknown number of civilians have been targeted in the ongoing mass arrest.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: CNDD-FDD-Imbonerakure: National Council for the Defence of Democracy (Imbonerakure Faction)
column17: There were clashes in Lubuye between the FARDC and the Kalakala Mayi Mayi group and Imbonerakure who had crossed into the eastern DRC from Burundi.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: There was fighting between FARDC forces and Kamwina Nsapu in Miabi. Inhabitants have been abandoning their villages to escape the fighting. 2 Kamwina Nsapu have been killed. Kamina Nsapu have burned down houses in Bena Nsamba, Mbombo, Dipongu and Kansenga.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: PPRD: Peoples Party for Reconstruction and Democracy
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Supporters of the PPRD held a march to protest against a petition criticising the Governor of Kwilu. The march was dispersed when shots were fired.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A group of residents tried to destroy the house of a man suspected of being involved in a kidnapping. The police intervened and fired at the crowd. A 10 year old playing nearby was hit by a bullet and died.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Gumino)
column17: 4 people were wounded in clashes between Gumino Banyamulenge and Fuljiru Mayi Mayi in Mikati village in Minembwe. The population of the village has fled.

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: FRPI raided Bei II village in Irumu, where they stole 157 cattle, looted houses, and abducted 3 teenagers. All of the inhabitants have fled into the forest. The day before, FRPI raided the villages of Ruzinga Mukubwa and Kazana, where they extorted the inhabitants.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: Looting: 6 LRA militants ambushed 2 motorcyclists east of Gangala, looting their belongings. The assailants wore military clothing and were armed with AK47s. They stole food and money.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A doctor was assassinated by unidentified assailants in Mweso.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A student at the Institute of Pedagogical Education in Bukavu was kidnapped by an unidentified group.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: The FARDC arrived at a senior official's farm in Bihambwe to clear away squatters. There was a clash with an unidentified group, in which 2-5 people were killed and many wounded.

column6: Batwa Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Batwa militia attacked Malumbi, near Kalemie. 7 people were killed and 34 people were wounded.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A student at the Catholic University of Bukavu was kidnapped and held for 5 days by an unidentified group.

column6: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column17: At least 17 people have been kidnapped by the Ugandan ADF-NALU and taken to an unknown destination. They were kidnapped from Mayangose, near Beni.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: LRA militants abducted a man and his wife.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A group of 15 unidentified men armed with machetes, stones and sticks attacked the Secretary General of the Congolese Communist Party in his home in Kinshasa. He was seriously injured.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Gumino)
column17: There were clashes between Banyamulenge Gumino and Fuliiru militia in Minembwe. A local chief reported that there had been some deaths and injuries.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Gumino)
column17: Three days of clashes between Banyamulenge Gumino and Bafuliiru militias in several areas of Fizi. Students at Sangani, Aleba, Ngoma and Binyenga were unable to write the primary school exam. Churches in Binyenga and Kahira were burned down in these clashes.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: Looting: 22 LRA militants attacked the community of Nambiogo, near Limai. They looted food. No injuries were reported.

column6: NDC-R: Nduma Defence of Congo (Renewal)
column17: NDC-R forces have occupied several localities in Lubero. They have installed parallel administrations, which tax the population, prevent access to fields, and prevent NGOs from accessing the areas.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A girl from Bagira was kidnapped by an unidentified group.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Gumino)
column17: Three days of clashes between Banyamulenge Gumino and Bafuliiru militias in several areas of Fizi. Students at Sangani, Aleba, Ngoma and Binyenga were unable to write the primary school exam. Churches in Binyenga and Kahira were burned down in these clashes.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Yakutumba)
column17: 2 soldiers and 2 soldiers' wives were killed when Mayi Mayi Yakutumba militia attacked Bendera. 6 soldiers are missing following the attack. 150 civilians were taken hostage and forced to carry the military hardware captured by the militia up into the mounatins

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 2 soldiers and 2 soldiers' wives were killed when Mayi Mayi Yakutumba militia attacked Bendera. 6 soldiers are missing following the attack. 150 civilians were taken hostage and forced to carry the military hardware captured by the militia up into the mounatins

column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On 3 June 2017, ADF and military forces clashed near Virunga Park, near Halungupa (Beni, Nord-Kivu).

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A youth leader from Bagira was kidnapped by an unidentified group.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A group of youths gathered outside the headquarters of the Mambasa Civil Society Office, chanting and shouting slogans. They set fire to the office and the home of the vice coordinator, to protest the civil society letter against the governor of Ituri province.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: LUCHA: Fight for Change
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: LUCHA youth held a march in Kisangani to support the vote of no confidence in the governor of Tshopo. The police barricaded the provincial assembly and arrested protesters.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: LRA forces armed with automatic weapons raided 2 communities near Gangala, abducting 10 civilians. They then looted food, gold, and diamonds from the mine near Gangala.

column17: 11 October. A coalition of the Forces democratiques de liberation du Rwanda/Forces combattantes abacunguzi (FDLR-FOCA) and Nyatura attacked Bwiza, Rutshuru territory, killing three officers of the Congolese National Police and five civilians.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The FARDC recover the city of Mukeba, in Fizi, from the Mayi Mayi Yakutumba, pushing the militiamen to the woods. One of the soldiers was captured by the militia.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Protesters took to the streets in Goma, to protest against the raising of school fees, but the protest was interrupted. In breaking the protest, the police attacked protesters, severely injuring 2 of them, and hurting others. The police used tear gas to disperse the crowd.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: An unidentified group of armed men attacked the manager of the money transfer agency 'La Colombe' and his motocyclist. The manager, who was carrying a bag with money, died.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The militia Elements clashes with the FARDC in the other side of the river Luvua.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A group of armed men in military uniforms killed 4 Hutu civilians and the 3 soldiers that were escorting them between Bambu and Kisheshe, in Bwito.

column6: Hutu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Nande Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 16 October. In Rutshuru, on 16 October, growing tensions between Hutu and Nande resulted in 32 houses being set on fire in Bambo village. MONUSCO deployed and relocated 28 Nande residents as a precautionary measure.

column6: Hutu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Nande Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Property destruction: 16 October. In Rutshuru, growing tensions between Hutu and Nande resulted in 32 houses being set on fire in Bambo village. MONUSCO deployed and relocated 28 Nande residents as a precautionary measure. It is not clear if the unrest was one sided, or against other fighters.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Property destruction: 16 October. Local militia groups burned down offices of the Congolese National Police and the Agence national de renseignements in Fube, south of Moba.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The police stiffled a peaceful march of the meeting of political and social forces for change before it began in Goma. 8 members were arrested and subsequently released.

column6: M23: March 23 Movement
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Agreement: 51 members from the M23 rebel force surrendered voluntarily to the military on Tuesday.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
column17: The APCLS ambushed the military vehicle of the 3411th regiment in Kiusha, in the Mwesso-Kitshanga axis. Local police mentions 2 combatants were killed.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
column17: The APCLS rebels capture the city of Ndondo in the Mwesso-Kitshanga axis.

column6: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The convoy of the operational sector of Sokola 1, of General Marcel Mbangu, was ambushed by the ADF in the Mbau-Kamanga route. 1 soldier was killed.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
column17: The APCLS rebels capture the city of Carton, in the Mwesso-Kitshanga axis.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Toussaint Alonga's brother was attacked and briefly kidnapped from his house in Kinshasa (Alonga is an MP who initiated a petition against the Speaker of the National Assembly; this is expectably why he thinks his relative was targetted).

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
column17: The FARDC got into a battle with the APCLS. The fighting lasted two days.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
column17: The APCLS try to overtake the locality of Kitobo, but are repelled by the FARDC.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
column17: The FARDC got into a battle with the APCLS. The fighting lasted two days.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: UDPS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column17: Arrests: The National Police of Congo arrested 28 members of the UDPS who were gathered for a meeting in Lubumbashi, for allegedly insulting President Kabila (the UDPS claims the number is 48). The police surrounded the building, where the members of the UDPS were barricaded, before calling the FARDC and forcing their entry into the building. The UN Special Representative to DRC called on authorities to release the people arrested. They were released 2 days later.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Property destruction: The houses of Joseph Olengankoy and Alphonse Ntumba Luaba were attacked by armed men, which is expected to be a result of calls for President Kabila to step down and his crackdown on opposition.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Unidentified gunmen attacked the police office of Hoho in the night of the 22nd. The fire exchange lasted some minutes. No injuries were registered.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: UDPS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column17: Police officers use teargas to disperse supporters waiting for the arrival of Felix Tshisekedi at the airport of Lubumbashi. According to the police, these were protesters wanting to throw projectiles at him. Tshisekedi condemned the police action.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura)
column17: Property destruction: Several houses were burned down by Mayi Mayi Nyatura in the locality of Mirangi in Bwito, Rutshuru. The civilians fled the scene to Kanyabayonga-Lusowa.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Charles)
column17: 6 fishermen were kidnapped by an unidentified armed group in Lake Edward. Mayi Mayi Charles have been reported to be involved in harassment towards fishermen in this region.

column6: Djupajalafuru Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Djupagiju Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A land dispute between the residents of Djupajalafuru and Djupagiju degenerated into a fight on the 25th. One person was killed and 2 others seriously injured. Almost all of the houses on either side were looted systematically before being burned. Both villages were emptied of their residents and activities are paralysed.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 26 October. In Tshikapa, Kamonia territory, Kasai province, four women were raped by four FARDC soldiers.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The FARDC have been fighting since the afternoon of the 26th an insurgence from presumably the ADF in the city of Beni. The situation has caused some panic among the residents.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A group of armed men attacked the Evangelical Hospital of Nyakunde. They beat a doctor, a nurse and some patients, taking also drugs and large sums of money. Around 9 to 10 people were assaulted.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 27 October. FARDC and ADF fighting in Beni continues for a second day. Causalities not known.

column6: Batwa Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 28 October. Suspected Twa militia killed five civilians in Kalembe, west of Pweto.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia
column17: Different Mayi Mayi militia groups clashed in Loya on 28 October. One of the militias was headed by General Luc.

column6: Bokalakiti Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Ngobi-Mayi Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A long standing tension between the Kutu and Bokalakiti communal militias, due to forest products collection in the area, led to an armed confrontation between them. The leader of the Bokalakiti went to raid the Ngobi-Mayi with a revolver.

column6: Batwa Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Luba Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 30 October. Suspected Twa militia attacked Luba civilians in Kasanbala and Mwashi village, north-west of Moba. 2 Civilians killed. Fatalities split between both events

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column8: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: Over Oct 30th-Nov 3rd, the FARDC recovered from FRPI the 5 localities of Sorodo, Masira, Adaba, Pali and Ruzinga Mkubwa in the chiefdom of Walendu Bindi in Irumu. Three suspected deaths - fatalities spread over events.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: LUCHA: Fight for Change
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A protest turned violent in Goma. Protesters, responding to a call from LUCHA, were demonstrating against the decision of the national election commission to hold off on elections to replace Kabila until April 2019. Activists had called for a general strike, but unrest broke out at 5am. Rioters barricaded streets and burned tires. One report mentions that rioters started attacking with knives, achetes, spears, arrows. Security forces killed at least 4 civilians and 1 police officer also died. Another report mentions that the police confirms 2 deaths, while witnesses confirm 6. The police station of Majengo was also completely ransacked before being set on fire. In Ndosho neighbourhood, the rioters held their barricades for 5 hours before the FARDC being called in to help.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: Violent clashes broke out in Beni between the FARDC, supported by MONUSCO, and the ADF in Beni, over attempts to gain the control of the route that connects Kamango to surrounding localities. At least one rebel was killed. 3 soldiers were wounded and 1 is missing.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The Mayi Mayi militia conducted by leader Luc Yabili clashed with the FARDC in Loya.

column6: Batwa Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Luba Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 30 October. Suspected Twa militia attacked a Luba militia in Kasanbala village, north-west of Moba, which resulted in civilians fleeing towards Zambia. Causalities not known.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column8: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: Over Oct 30th-Nov 3rd, the FARDC recovered from FRPI the 5 localities of Sorodo, Masira, Adaba, Pali and Ruzinga Mkubwa in the chiefdom of Walendu Bindi in Irumu. Three suspected deaths - fatalities spread over events.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Police in Beni said they had arrested nine demonstrators during a march Tuesday against President Joseph Kabila, a day after clashes in the region that left five dead. All nine were reportedly from LUCHA and protesting in the public highway without authorisation. A LUCHA campaigner stated that the police intervened shortly after the protest started, manhandling the protesters. 9 people from LUCHA were arrested by the police.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column8: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: Over Oct 30th-Nov 3rd, the FARDC recovered from FRPI the 5 localities of Sorodo, Masira, Adaba, Pali and Ruzinga Mkubwa in the chiefdom of Walendu Bindi in Irumu. Three suspected deaths - fatalities spread over events.

column6: Batwa Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Acording to civil society and NGOs, the Twa militia has during this week been plundering houses and villages, killing at least 10. The three locations attacked (Mwabou, Shikayimba and Shikatemba villages) are all located within 30km of Pweto.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column8: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: Over Oct 30th-Nov 3rd, the FARDC recovered from FRPI the 5 localities of Sorodo, Masira, Adaba, Pali and Ruzinga Mkubwa in the chiefdom of Walendu Bindi in Irumu. Three suspected deaths - fatalities spread over events.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column8: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: Over Oct 30th-Nov 3rd, the FARDC recovered from FRPI the 5 localities of Sorodo, Masira, Adaba, Pali and Ruzinga Mkubwa in the chiefdom of Walendu Bindi in Irumu. Three suspected deaths - fatalities spread over events.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: The FARDC, supported by MONUSCO, regained control over the km 14, 15 and 16 of the Mbau-Kamango axis in Beni, on the morning of the 3rd.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Property destruction: Unidentified armed men in military gear broke into the Norwegian consulate. There were no injuries and nothing was stolen, apart from some objects broken. The police says it was not informed. The report mentions that the Norwegian consul is the mother of the wealthy art collector Sindika Dokolo, who mobilises social networks towards President Kabila renouncing his position.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: Clashes between Congolese troops and supporters of a renegade colonel (Abbas Kayonga) in Congo's eastern city of Bukavu killed seven people on Sunday before he surrendered and turned himself in to U.N. Peacekeepers. Seventeen members of Kanyonga's force surrendered to U.N. troops and nine others were captured by the army. A dozen weapons were captured. Two army soldiers and three of Kayonga's bodyguards were killed in the fighting and two civilians were killed by stray bullets, he said. Another later report mentions only one death for Kayonga's bodyguards but three civilian deaths.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: UDPS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The police forces of DRC dispersed a protest that had started in Lubumbashi. Protersters were affiliated with the UDPS according to local authorities and had begun burning tires to protest against the electoral calendar published by CENI.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Another group protested against the electoral calendar of CENI in Rwashi during the morning of the 6th. The police dispersed the protest.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 2 Mayi Mayi rebels were killed and four other were captured in a clash with the FARDC when the latter were ambushed during a patrolling mission. The clash lasted for 20 minutes and 1 military is currently disappeared.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Police fired tear gas cannisters at sudents who organised a protest in front of the University of Bunia. The students started burning tyres in front of the school to protest the decision of the Minister of Land Affairs, attributing the ownership of the concession from the UNIBU to a trader. Shortly after 10am, dozens of police dispatched to the scene. Reports mention arrested people and one student whose hand will have to be amputated after having lost a thumb.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Students (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On Friday 10th, a protest took place in the University of Bunia, in which students protested against the decision to cease by the Minister of Land Affairs of ceasing the land in which the university campus is located to a trader. 16 people were arrested by the police after they intervened to stop the protest.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 10 November. Three women were raped by two men in FARDC uniforms in Kakumba, Kamonia.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 13 November. An intoxicated soldier of the Congolose Armed Forces shot at a crowd in Kazumba area and killed a civilian. He was arrested later

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Les Deboutistes Movement
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On November 13, a new civil group called 'Les Deboutistes' rioted at 5am in Ndosho. They blocked the main street Goma-Sake and burned tires, in protest for a militant belonging to their group whom had been arrested. This was the first demonstration by the group. The Police used tear gas to disperse the youth group.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Mayi Mayi Raia Mutomboki clashed with the FARDC on the night of the 14th to 15th in the villages of Kantungo and Changombe, in Mulamba. The militiamen had just raided some houses when the FARDC intervened. The rebels fled into the forest.

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On November 14, a soldier was killed by the FRPI in Singo, a locality 50km from Bunia, in Ituri. The soldier was in route to his position when he was ambushed by the enemy. There was a clash and 4 minutes later he was killed and his weapon taken.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Unknown people set a bus on fire in Lubumbashi on the 15th, in the same day that a strike by civilians was called in protest of the announcement of the electoral calendar.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Students (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Four people were injured during clashes with the police on Wednesday 15th. Although it started as a peaceful protest, police clashed with protesters, firing live bullets. Accounts differ on the motivations for the protest. On the one side, it is said that protesters were students demanding the resume of their classes; their teachers had been in strike for a week due to their unpaid salaries. On the other end, the protesters are said to be part of a civilian movement in Lusambo to denounce the mismanagement of Governor Berthold Ulungu.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A fisherman and several fish merchants were assaulted by 6 officers in Kalemie when they refused to have their goods seized. At this point, the officers threatened them with knives. After witnesses denounced this, military arrested the officers.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Arrests: Police in the Democratic Republic of Congo made several dozen arrests to stifle protests. LUCHA mentions at least 27 civilians were arrested in Nord-Kivu, including 15 in Goma. 13 other activists were detained while a communique was being read in the province of Sud-Kivu. The government confirms 19 arrests, comprising six in Goma, seven in Lubumbashi and six in Matadi. The Human Rights division of MONUSCO notes that there were arbitrary arrests taking place during the day, notably in Goma and Kinshasa. Human Rights Watch mentions that at least 52 people were arrested while protesting in Goma, Kasindi, Kindu, Kisangani, Kinshasa, and Idjwi.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The Mayi Mayi attacked the prison of Kakwangura in Butembo on November 15th as an attempt to free their relatives. The FARDC quickly intervened and halted the assault. The death toll resulted in 3 militiamen killed and one civilian injured. The escape of prisoners was halted by FARDC's intervention.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On November 15, live bullets were used to disperse protesters who were demonstrating against the electoral calendar dates in the axes Kasindo-Ndosho and Mabanga-Mangengo. The police was supported by the military.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Police dispersed with tear gas, on Wednesday 15th, young protesters who had gathered in Matadi to demonstrate against the electoral calendar. The protest took place in the quarters Nord and Belvedere of Matadi.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: LUCHA protesters manifested in Kasindi, Beni, on the 15th, against the electoral calendar of the presidential elections to replace Kabile. Police who had been deployed stopped the protest and arrested 14 militants.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: In Idjwi, on Wednesday 15th, protesters took to the streets responding to a call from other citizens movements and civil society groups to demonstrate their opposition towards the published electoral calendar and demand that President Joseph Kabila leave office by the end of 2017. The police responded aggressively, beating the protesters and arresting some of them. Among them, there is a report by a 15 year old girl who was likewise assaulted by police.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: In Butembo, on the 15th, protesters belonging to LUCHA and Fulimbi barricaded routes in the quarters of Furu and Kitulu. The police dispersed them with tear gas.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: LUCHA: Fight for Change; Students (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On Wednesday 15th, rioters identified as LUCHA supporters by some, and students by others, burned tires at the Katoka market in Kananga. They were protesting against the electoral calendar published by CENI, but dispersed quickly when the police intervened.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The city of Kilembwe fell, on the night of Sunday 19th, into the hands of the coalition between the Mayi Mayi Yakutumba and Malaika. The FARDC retreated to 20km from the city in order to avoid a bloodbath. The coalition militia attacked the FARDC offices in Kilembwe, killing one soldier. The city of Kilembwe is strategic due to its proximity to the mining site of society Banro, in Namoya. With the taking of this village, the Yakutumba control 80% of the Lulimba-Kilembwe route.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A delegation from the political party Envol was preparing to hold a protest in Kenge, on the 19th, when police quickly intervened and dispersed them with tear gas. The report mentions that several persons were injured during the intervention. Another report mentions 6 severely injured by bullets, 2 by batons and more than 30 militants arrested.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Looting: Civil society in Ikobo, Walikale, claims that the military has since two weeks harassed civilians in the localities of Rusamambu and Muronga. Claims mention that barriers are being erected and that 500 francs are demanded each time in order to assess the camps in both localities. The claims mentions that militaries do not hesitate to demand payment of parts of crops and to torture civilians. The reports have been denied by the military.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A clash between the FARDC and a coalition of Mayi Mayi Mazembe and Malaika took place on the 19th in the locality of Bashu, in Beni. 6 people died, of which 4 militiamen and 2 soldiers. 4 other militiamen were injured. The coalition is said to be defending the Nande community.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Charles)
column17: Looting: The Mayi Mayi Charles Kakule stole 33 boat motors from the fishermen in Kyavinyonge, on Sunday 19th. They demanded 95.000 Congolese francs in return for each motor. The motors were robbed because the fishermen had demanded to pay the weekly extortion of 15.000 francs that had previously been demanded. The Edward lake is surrounded by militias who are impeding the fishing activities.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A 25 year old student was killed in Tenanbo, located at the rural exit of Oicha, presumable by a member of the FARDC. His name was Kambale Kabuyaya Paulin.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The police, supported by the military, intervened in a protest in Oicha, on Tuesday 21st, killing 1 rioter and injuring one other. The participants marched down the street, breaking and bruning during their passage, to protest the death of a 25 year old student killed on the night of the 20th presumably by the FARDC. The participants were dispersed with tear gas and real bullets. One woman died and another boy was shot in the abdomen.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: The FARDC clashed with the ADF since Wednesday, in 3 locations in Beni (points 6, 16 and 25). A FARDC patrol got into a trap during the night, but there are not reported fatalities. The intervention from MONUSCO soldiers prevented the FARDC vehicle from being burned.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On Wednesday 22nd, youth protested in front of the provincial division of health against the new nominations for doctors to run public hospitals and health areas.

column6: FDLR-Rude: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda (Rude Faction)
column17: On Thursday 23rd, 5 people, including a 12 year old adolescent, were decapitated in the region of Kibirizi, in the chiefdom of Bwito, by presumably FDLR-Rude branch Rwandan soldiers.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: During the weekend, the military clashed with the police forces of Yamongomia in Basoko due to disputes over the bags of hemp seized by the Yamongomia police.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 26 November. Clashes take place between FARDC and a coalition of Mai-Mai groups in Makola, Mai-Ndombe and Kahungwe, all three villages located between 120 km and 130 km from Uvira. Causalities not known.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 26 November. Clashes take place between FARDC and a coalition of Mai-Mai groups in Makola, Mai-Ndombe and Kahungwe, all three villages located between 120 km and 130 km from Uvira. Causalities not known.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 26 November. Mai-Mai Yakutumba militia clashed with government soldiers in Tujenge, 109 km south-west of Uvira. Two FARDC soldiers were killed.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 26 November. Clashes take place between FARDC and a coalition of Mai-Mai groups in Makola, Mai-Ndombe and Kahungwe, all three villages located between 120 km and 130 km from Uvira. Causalities not known.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: UPDS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column17: On Monday 27th, 6 people were injured during demonstrations in Beni and Majengo (Goma).

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: Hutu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On the 27th or 28th November, a group of Mayi Mayi Nyatura rebels, a self-defense militia of ethnic Hutus, killed 4 people during an attack in Numbi. One of the victims was a Congolese soldier.

column6: Batwa Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On Monday 27th, the Twa ethnic militia attacked the locality of Kakusa, 20km from Pweto, clashing with the FARDC. During the attack, rebels armed with arrows and light weapons pillaged commerce and agricultural fields belonging to residents. The military was deployed but was caught in an ambush by the rebels, who injured 5 military men.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: UPDS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column17: On Monday 27th, 6 people were injured during demonstrations in Beni and Majengo (Goma).

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: On Monday 27th, Congolese citizens protested against the presence of Burundian refugees in Kamanyola. The protesters protested in front of the MONUSCO offices, where there are more than 2,800 Burundian refugees. Protesters were dispersed by MONUSCO forces. The report mentions that a cemetery where 39 refugees were buried had their crosses stolen by the protesters as an act of provocation.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura)
column7: Hutu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: During the flee of the Nyatura Mayi Mayi from Numbi, one civilian was kidnapped and a ransom was demanded in order to free him.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The FARDC recovered, on Tuesday 28th, the city of Kilembwe, which was under the control of a Yakutumba-Malaika Mayi Mayi coalition. The army recovered, without resistance, the control of the Lulimba-Kilembwe route, following an offensive launched on Sunday.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: LUCHA: Fight for Change; UPDS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column17: Protesters supporting the resignation of President Kabila took to the streets of Butembo on Tuesday 28th. The protest was later stopped by the police, protesters were dispersed and 2 of them were arrested. The protest was organised by LUCHA, Filimbi, 'Parlement debout' and 'new citizenship'.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Yakutumba)
column7: Mayi Mayi Militia (Malaika)
column17: Property destruction: During the flee of the Yakutumba-Malaika coalition from Kilembwe, they set fire to the villages of Tulungu and Mabunga.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019) National Intelligence Agency
column17: 4 journalists working for Radio Veritas were arrested on Wednesday 29th, and since then were tortured by the National Intelligence Agency, according to Journalists in Danger (JED).

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: UNADEF: National Union of Democrats and Federalists
column17: In Lubumbashi, the federal secretary of the opposition Unadef party was kidnapped and taken to an unknown destination.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: While protests were taking place, a member of the 'Rassemblement' movement, was kidnapped, beaten, stabbed and left in a ravine. He is currently receiving medical help and is in a very critical state. The perpretators are unknown.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Movement of forces: The government deployed, on Thursday 30th, more police forces in Kinshasa, in preparation for the protests which had been called for and which the Government had not allowed. Police members were deployed to disperse all the gatherings of 5+ people in Kinshasa.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: UNC: Union for the Congolese Nation
column17: A peaceful protest supporting the departure of President Kabila was dispersed on Thursday 30th by the police in Uvira. Protesters were dispersed with live bullets and one protester was severely injured. The victim was Yorogo Sambaza, section president of the UNC.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: UPDS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column17: During a protest in Matadi on November 30th, 8 members of the UPDS were arrested by police.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: UPDS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column17: On 30th November, violent repressions of anti-Kabila demonstrations: in Uvira, Bukavu, Beni, Lubumbashi, Kindu and elsewhere. The police and security forces made numerous arrests and broke up roadways of burnt tires and barricades erected by opposition activists.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: UPDS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column17: Protesters in the commune of Ndesha, in Kananga, were dispersed and attacked by the police when protesting against the electoral calendar published by CENI. Some protesters were in front of the MONUSCO offices and other near Notre Dame. A member of the UPDS, was reportedly shot and wounded by the police.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Rioters blocked streets and burned tires during dead city protests in Goma on 30th November. In certain areas, shots were fired. A young student was arrested.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: LUCHA: Fight for Change; Journalists (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: In Beni, police suppressed an anti-Kabila demonstration held by LUCHA members. 5 LUCHA militants were arrested and journalists were beaten and arrested.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: UPDS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress; Journalists (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: While attempting to disperse a group of protesters in Ibanda, Bukavu, on Thursday 30th, the police were violent towards protesters and a journalist belonging to Radio Okapi causing injuries. Protesters demanded the departure of President Kabila on December 2017. The police also dispersed protests in the commune Kadutu.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: LUCHA: Fight for Change; UPDS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column17: Injuries, arrests and kidnappings reported in several cities across the country. In Mbuji-Mayi, police violently suppressed protesters who were trying to take to the streets. Barricades were erected on the roads and tires burned on the road.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: UPDS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column17: Protesters took to the streets of Kinshasa on Thursday 30th. Three leaders of the 'Rassemblement' movement were arrested when trying to join the protest. The police spoke of molotov cocktail being thrown, but these claims were not confirmed. Claims of torture during detention. Protesters gathered in front of Tshisekedi's house were also repelled with tear gas in the morning.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: UPDS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column17: On Thursday morning, 30th, 6 protesters were arrested in Kalemie during protests. The protest demanded the departure of President Kabila by December 31st.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 30 November. FARDC soldiers had shot at a crowd at the market in Kabeya Lumbu killing at least 13 persons. Eight other persons were injured by gunshots. Two of the injured later died.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Police dispersed protesters who were holding a demonstration in favour of the departure of President Kabila in Kasindi, on the 30th. The police also arrested 15 LUCHA militants. 2 of them who were released on 4 December claimed to have been tortured.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: UPDS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column17: On 30th November, violent repressions of anti-Kabila demonstrations: in Uvira, Bukavu, Beni, Lubumbashi, Kindu and elsewhere. The police and security forces made numerous arrests and broke up roadways of burnt tires and barricades erected by opposition activists.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Luc Yabili)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On Thursday 30th, the Mayi Mayi Luc Yabili recovered the locality of Opienge, in Tshopo. After 4h of fighting, the FARDC retreated since they were out of ammunition.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: UDPS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress
column17: During a protest against the presidency of Kabila in Furu, Butembo, on the 30th, one of the protesters was killed. The victim belonged to the citizen movement ""Parlement Debout"", affiliated with the UDPS.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki)
column17: Several exactions in Kahele territory, Sud Kivu, by the Mayi Mayi Raia around 30 November: kidnappings were reported in Bunyakiri and in Ebisha. Lootings were also reported in Kambale, Kamananga and Bitale.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki)
column17: Several exactions in Kahele territory, Sud Kivu, by the Mayi Mayi Raia around 30 November: kidnappings were reported in Bunyakiri and in Ebisha. Lootings were also reported in Kambale, Kamananga and Bitale.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: Students (Democratic Republic of Congo); Journalists (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Students gathered on Friday 1st to protest the arrest of the three journalists the previous Wednesday. Their protest was dispersed by police, who shot fires in the air and arrested 8 students.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Violent clashes between the FARDC and Mayi-Mayi Malaika in Kabambare at unprecise dates enable FARDC to recover several areas on the left side of the Lamwa river, including Lusangi on 1 December and Tengetenge. Many fatalities reported in these clashes.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Violent clashes between the FARDC and Mayi-Mayi Malaika in Kabambare at unprecise dates enable FARDC to recover several areas on the left side of the Lamwa river, including Lusangi on 1 December and Tengetenge. Many fatalities reported in these clashes.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Violent clashes between the FARDC and Mayi-Mayi Malaika in Kabambare at unprecise dates enable FARDC to recover several areas on the left side of the Lamwa river, including Lusangi on 1 December and Tengetenge. Many fatalities reported in these clashes.

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column8: CNRD: National Council for Renewal and Democracy
column17: Two antagonist factions of the FDLR (FOCA and CNRD) clashed on Friday 1st in Mpati, Masisi territory. The clash caused the displacement of the local population. OCHA suspended its humanitarian actions due to the instability in the region.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Buhirwa)
column17: 3 doctors were kidnapped in Lemera, on Friday 2nd, while doing a provincial health inspection. The kidnappers demanded a ransom, which was paid. The doctors were released Saturday 2nd.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: FARDC forces deployed to the collectivity of Salamabila, in Kabambare in Maniema, allegedly raped 17 women between end November and early December (report dated 10 December). The last victim was 8 months pregnant and left severely injured.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: MSF: Doctors Without Borders; Aid Workers (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: An armed group broke into the MSF office on the morning of December 4th, in Mweso, and brutalised the officers there before looting equipment and money.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On December 5th, six students of the private university of Tshikama, in Mbuji Mayi, were arrested by police during a protest against the high rates of tuition fees.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The students of the University of Bunia burnt tyres on the road on 5 December to demand the DRC government to return the money spent on buying the land for the campus of the University. The students broke doors and windows and stole items. Police intervened to disperse them and arrested seven.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: LUCHA: Fight for Change; UPDS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress; UNADEF: National Union of Democrats and Federalists; Filimbi Movement; OCR: Rally of the Congolese Opposition
column17: The representative of the OCR claims that, while in detention, their militants were tortured by DRC police members. Date unclear.

column6: Banyamulenge Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Bafuliru Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Banyindu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Clash between the Banyamulenge and a coalition of Bafuliru and Banyindu, in Bijombo, around 5 December. 5 people were killed and 10 others injured. The violence is attributed to the latent conflict that exists in Bijombo.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: MSF: Doctors Without Borders; Aid Workers (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 2 MSF agents were kidnapped on the morning of December 5th by unidentified armed men in Bambu, Nord Kivu. The agents were in mission in the area.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Looting: Senator Aubin Ngongo Luwowo accused the police of ransacking the residence that hosts Radio vision Kindu Maniema (TKM) on December 7th after an emission that was conducted by an officer sent by the Minister of the Interior. The minister had been accused during the emission of receiving a bribe of 250 000 USD from governor Tutu and senator Mulaila. The Minister informed the senator over the phone that he would send the police to the facilities, which confiscated TVs, radios, emissors, among others.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Students in Lubumbashi took to the streets on December 7th to protest the newly-released order that their university building had to be vacated. They occupied several avenues, but were later dispersed by police with tear gas.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Two people were killed during a clash between Mayi-Mayi Raia Mutomboki and FARDC, on the night between the 6th and 7th December, in Bukavu. The army only confirms one dead. The rebels were forced into retreat to Bubamba.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Students protested against the non-setting of fixes rates for the costs of university in front of the National Institute of Buildings and Public Works turned on December 7th. At least 6 students were harmed, including one shot, and several others were arrested when a joint police-military force intervened to disperse them.

column6: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: The MONUSCO forces repelled on December 7th an attack by the ADF on one of their bases along the Mbau-Kamango axis in Beni territory. 15 Dead.

column6: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: 07 December. In Semuliki, North Kivu, which resulted in the killing of 15 peacekeepers from Tanzania. Forty-four peacekeepers were also injured during the attack, attributed to the Allied Democratic Forces (ADF). After a lull in their activities, ADF has resumed their attacks in the area, including against civilians.

column6: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
column17: 07 December. In Semuliki, North Kivu, which resulted in the killing of 15 peacekeepers from Tanzania. Forty-four peacekeepers were also injured during the attack, attributed to the Allied Democratic Forces (ADF). After a lull in their activities, ADF has resumed their attacks in the area, including against civilians. Civilian causalities not known.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: LDP: Liberal Democratic Party; Civilians (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A protest was held by supporters of the Liberal Democratic Party in Goma on 8 December. The police stopped the protest, arresting 4 people, including the president of the opposition LDP, Jean-Paul Lumbu Lumbu. The protesters were demonstrating against the draft law, which according to them excluded youth and women from the deputation race, owing to the representativeness threshold and bail imposed. The police used tear gas to disperse protesters; students who were close were caught in the middle of the tear gas.

column6: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column7: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column16: Daily News (DRC); AFP; MONUSCO; Deutsche Welle; Radio Okapi; UN (unspecified); IRIN
column17: An attack by suspected ADF fighters on the MONUSCO base in Semliki in Nord Kivu in the evening of 7 December left 14 MONUSCO and 5 FARDC soldiers dead. Another 53 blue helmets were injured during the attack and reports of rebel deaths vary from dozens to 72. The attack was described by UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres as a 'war crime' and the worst attack on UN peacekeepers in the organisation's recent history.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Clash between supporters of the president (Charles Pongo) and rapporteur (Martin Shongo) of the provincial assembly in Lusambo left three severely injured. Police fired shots in the air to disperse the groups and arrested several.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Unidentified attackers killed 5 people - 4 belonging to the same family - on the night of 8 December in Mulekera commune in Beni. Residents protested the following day against the violence and the rising insecurity after the attack against MONUSCO. Some burnt tyres in the street.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Unidentified attackers killed 5 people - 4 belonging to the same family - on the night of 8 December in Mulekera commune in Beni. Residents protested the following day against the violence and the rising insecurity after the attack against MONUSCO. Some burnt tyres in the street.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The locality of Opienge was retaken by the FARDC in a clash with the Mayi Mayi Luc Yabili on December 10th. The locality was captured by the Mayi Mayi on November 30th.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Simba)
column7: Mayi Mayi Militia (Manu)
column17: Mayi Mayi Simba Manu attacked the village of Mabuo, chiefdom of Babila Babombi in Mambasa, abducting 46 people abducted. Four people also died in the river when their boat capsized while trying to flee.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Opposition deputies, in collaboration with other protesters, marched in Kinshasa on December 11th to protest against the electoral bill and question senators about the liberticidal nature of the bill under consideration.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Police violently dispersed a protest held by LUCHA in Goma, forcing some protesters into the police cars with sticks. The protesters were demonstrating against the restriction of the political space and the numerous abuses of human rights attributed to the police in Nord-Kivu.

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column7: Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura); Mayi Mayi Militia (Mazembe)
column17: The NGO Action Paysanne pour le Developpement (APD) denounced that the Mayi Mayi Mazembe, Nyatura and the FDLR had been carrying several human rights violations in the Bwito chiefdom of Rutshuru during the previous two weeks, namely kidnapping civilians in large numbers (one report mentions 13 in one day alone), burning villages and undertaking massacres.

column6: APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
column8: APCLS-M: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo (Mapenzi)
column17: 15 December. During the month of December, Mapenzi Likuwe split from APCLS, establishing the APCLS-Renove. The split came after Mapenzi and Janvier Karairi, the APCLS leader, disagreed over mining exploitations and political pressures - Janvier was opposed to Kabila and Mapenzi was seen as easier to influence.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Mazembe)
column17: The Mayi Mayi Mazembe clashed with the NDC-G on Saturday 16th in Kaheri, grouping of Musindi, causing the population to flee on Sunday 17th.

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column8: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: 17 December. The former leader of the FDLR Evariste Nizeyimana surrendered to MONUSCO in the Lubero area

column6: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: During an attack by ADF in Oicha on December 17th, a civilian was killed, alongside a soldier of the FARDC.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Property destruction: the Mayi Mayi Nyatura invaded the locality of Kavumu at 19h in the night on December 18th. They shot several houses, but no human lives were lost - they fled at the arrival of the FARDC.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A soldier was killed on Monday 18th in the region of Djugu.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The Mayi Mayi Nyatura attacked the groupings of Buzu and Mubugu in Kalehe on the night of December 18th.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Non-violent activity: FARDC soldiers are threatening and harassing civilians in the Mukamba-Kabeya-Kamwanga-Mbuji-Mayi route in Kasai-Oriental ahead of the planned 19th December protests. The declaration was given by Eugenie Tshika, national deputy.

column6: Lendu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Property destruction: The Bahema chief accuses the Lendu youth of burning 28 houses belonging to the Bahema, in Blukwa, in retaliation to the burning of Thethe dwellings by members of the northern Bahema community. He also accuses them of burning a house in Resto, along with 8 motorbikes there.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Hema Communal Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On Monday 18th, a young member of the Bahema community was killed by an unidentified armed group. This sparked tensions between the Lendu and Hema groups, and residents fled the area on Tuesday 19th, fearing that intercommunal conflict could happen.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: One hour after the attack in Kavumu, the Nyatura attacked the inhabitants of Numbi and were forced to flee by the police forces.
