During their escape, they left leaflets behind, asking the inhabitants to pay a sum of 2000$ by the end of the year, subject to a new attack by them should the amount not be paid.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 2 young people were arrested in Lubumbashi on December 19th during a protest against the electoral calendar. Both were caught after smashing the windows of a courthouse and trying to burn it.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: UPDS: Union for Democracy and Social Progress; OCR: Rally of the Congolese Opposition
column17: Police beat up a protester in Kikwit, who responded to a call by OCR to protest on the streets. The protester was affiliated with the UPDS.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019) Eco-Guards
column17: On December 19th, the Mayi Mayi attacked the Ivingu location, in Lubero, in order to steal weapons. A civilian was killed alongside 4 of the assailants.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: Military operations in Kaseke, Rutshure, led the FARDC to clash with the FDLR, resulting in the capture of 3 presumed FDLR kidnappers and the release of 3 student hostages. 2 AK 47 weapons were also recovered.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Lendu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Hema Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Property destruction: after the initial tensions between Hema and Lendu in Djugu, there were several fires started during the course of the following days and police/military were deployed to address the situation. Calm returned 5 days after the death of a young man was announced by the Bahema chief.

column6: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: The MONUSCO base which had been attacked on December 7th by the ADF has now been reoccupied.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura)
column17: Property destruction: on December 19th, the Nyatura attacked the locality of Kavumu, shooting against buildings, but causing no casualties.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Property destruction: around 60 houses were burned in the village of Lunju, in Ituri, by inhabitants coming from Walendu Pitsi. This attack occurred in the context of tensions between Lendu and Hema communities.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Djugu Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: The speaker of the FARDC in Ituri confirmed that 2 FARDC soldiers had been attacked by a group of inhabitants armed with machettes in the locality of Tse, Djugu, on Wednesday 20th December. Local sources inform that the soldiers had been invited by a customary chief to disperse a group of inhabitants who sought revenge. Upon arrival, they were attacked with knives and their weapons taken from them.

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column7: CNRD: National Council for Renewal and Democracy
column17: The chief of the Mayi Mayi Nyatura militia - Kasongo Kalamo - was killed on December 20th during combats that opposed the Nyatura versus the FDLR/CNRD in Bukama. He was killed in an ambush that he himself had set for the FDLR.

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Agreement: a former commander of the FDLR - Evariste Nizeyimana - surrendered to the FARDC on Thursday 21st, in Lubero.

column6: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column8: FDLR-FOCA: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda- Forces fighting Abacunguzi
column17: Agreement: an old commander of the FDLR-FOCA surrendered to the MONUSCO forces in Goma, on December 21st. The colonel Evariste Nizeyimana, known as 'Kiszito', is responsible for more than 80 people killed, some of them buried alive. He also orchestrated the burning of several villages, namely Buleusa, as well as the massacre in Miliki.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-)
column17: The Ugandan army announced on December 22nd that it had undertaken a preventive strike on the positions of ADF rebels along the Uganda-DRC border, in Eringiti (8 ADF bases were destroyed: Madina, Canada, Tadia, Popoke, Makayoba, Kaynama, Ngiti and Kikingi). Air force and long-range artillery were used (operation Tuugo). This came after the establishment of a mechanism to share information on ADF with the DRC forces. On Monday 25th, the Ugandan army claimed to have killed 100 rebels.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On Friday 22nd, the Mayi Mayi struck the FARDC in the operational area of Baraka, killing 9 soldiers in two ambushes.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Christian Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On December 22nd, in Bunia, the members of the Kimbangist church of Sayo clashed with autochtonous civilians, wounding 6 people with machetes and stone throwing.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A lieutenant was killed on Sunday 24th in the village of Lweba, 7km from the in Baraka operational zone. Another report mentions that the place was the village of Kakwena and that the attackers were presumably the Mayi Mayi Yakutumba.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Two civilians were severely injured during the weekend of 23-24 December, in the village of Swima, after an altercation between them and the FARDC. The FARDC soldier tried to prevent the passage of a prefect student on a motorbike, which led to a dispute that alerted the population. Due to being inebriated, the soldier started shooting.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The FARDC was attacked by the NDC Guidon in Lubero, close to Kabale. 3 soldiers and 2 rebels died during the attack.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A man was killed in Kasanga, Beni, by two armed men dressed in FARDC clothes on December 24th.

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: Movement of forces: the FDLR heavily deployed military along the border after the strikes against ADF undertaken during the weekend, as a response to the growing tensions felt and in order to prevent an expansion of the conflict into Uganda.

column6: NDC-R: Nduma Defence of Congo (Renewal)
column17: The Mayi Mayi Mazembe were attacked on December 24th by the NDC Guidon in Kasone Kimule. 3 people died (2 Mayi Mayi and 1 NDC member), and the NDC seized 2 AK-47s.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Property destruction: Unidentified armed men attacked Lukungula, Kalehe, on December 24th. They were looking for 2 ANR agents, but realising that they could not find them, proceeded to burn down the houses belonging to them. They also looted during the process.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Vigilante Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On Sunday, 24th, the inhabitants of Lembabo and Simbiliabo, in Bunia, lynched 2 people who were stealing.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: The residence of Joseph Kabila was set on fire on December 25th, in Musienene, Lubero, by an unknown armed group (presumed to be the ADF or the Mayi Mayi). During the event, one police officer was killed.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On December 25th, the Mayi Mayi Ebu Ela attacked the FARDC in Kikwena, Fizi. One soldier was killed and two others were injured. Some weapons were stolen.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Unidentified armed men trying to rob a house were intercepted by the police in Katindo, Goma, and the clash led to three deaths.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki-Kizamoto)
column17: The Raia Mutomboki-Kizamoto attacked the village of Niabembe, in Sabunda, on December 25th. Apart from looting several goods such as phones and gold, they also abducted 2 men.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Mazembe)
column17: A man was shot dead by the Mayi Mayi Mazembe in Kitsambiro, Lubero, on December 25th.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: An area chief was killed on December 25th in Beni. The motives for his death are still unknown, but his death was caused after an altercation between him and his assassins.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura)
column17: The Mayi Mayi Nyatura attacked the village of Yobora, in Bwito, Rutshuru, on December 25th, killing 4 people, of which a woman and 2 children. They also burned 144 houses during the attack.

column6: CNPSC: National Coalition of the People for Congo's Sovereignty
column17: On December 26th, the CNPSC killed a 55 year old man during the night.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019) Eco-Guards
column17: On December 26th, 2 Mayi Mayi Charles rebels, who had just stolen a boat for patrol, attacked the park forces in the Virunga national park. The latter retaliated with a rocket launcher, which killed the 2 rebels, along with 3 fishermen and 1 woman.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A coalition of Nyatura Kasongo, Domi and Love attacked the FARDC position in Matanda on December 26th. One 16 year old boy was killed and 2 other men were injured.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Unidentified armed men raided Kabuza, in Walikale, abducted a girl and a woman, and raped them.

column6: CNPSC: National Coalition of the People for Congo's Sovereignty
column17: Armed men identifying as part of the CNPSC coalition attacked Iseke, Fizi, on December 27th. They coerced civilians to carry the property they were looting and proceeded to release them after all the goods had been transported.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On December 27th, the FARDC tortured a 37 year old man in the town of Shabunda. The man died from injuries.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura)
column9: Nande Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: The same group of Mayi Mayi that had attacked Rutshuru on December 25th attacked again, this time in Mutanda, on the night of December 26-27th. A young person was killed and two other civilians injured by bullets during the clash. Civil society notes that the reemergence of intercommunal conflicts led the targeting by the Mayi Mayi of the Nande community.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On December 28th, unidentified armed men raided a warehouse in Nkafu, Bukavu, and killed a 15 year old boy. Two other men were injured.

column6: CNPSC: National Coalition of the People for Congo's Sovereignty
column17: Looting: the CNPSC raided Kaseke, in Fizi, looting several goods and stealing animals.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Leopard)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: The Mayi Mayi Leopard attacked a position belonging to unidentified armed men in the village of Yambi, Beni, on December 28th.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura-Kavumbi)
column17: The Nyatura Nzayi clashed with the Nyatura Kavumbi in Kametembe village, Masisi. 3 rebels were killed during the clash.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A 50 year old man was tortured in Nyabibwe on December 28th by unidentified armed men. The man died from the injuries.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Mwenyemali)
column17: On December 28th, the Mayi Mayi Mwenyemali attacked a ranch and injured a farmer.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On December 28th, the FARDC patrol murdered a man in Mutinwa, Fizi.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A FARDC soldier killed a woman in Kasindi Vieux on December 28th.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The FARDC clashed with the Mayi Mayi on December 28th in Kasindi Lubiriha, 90km northeast of Beni. 6 militia men were killed by the FARDC, as well as one soldier. The rebels left behind an AK47 and the FARDC are currently pursuing them.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The FARDC simultaneously attacked the Mayi Mayi Masembe who were in the villages of Masereka and Vusitoro in Lubero, on December 29th. Several injuries were reported on the FARDC side.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On December 29th, the FARDC shot and killed 5 people thinking they were Mayi Mayi rebels. Among the victims were 2 women, 2 men and a 6 month old child.

column6: Batwa Ethnic Militia (Burundi)
column17: To exert revenge over the killing of one of its members, armed Twa men attacked the village of Katato, in Tanganika, on December 29th, killing 2 people and injuring 7 others.

column6: Bantu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Batwa Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A Twa ethnic militiaman was killed on December 29th in the village of Katato, Tanganika, by a Bantu ethnic militiaman, after being mistaken for an attacker.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The FARDC launched an offensive against the ADF in Eringiti on December 29th. 2 rebels were killed and one was captured, along with some weapons.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: During a clash between the FARDC and a coalition of Mayi Mayi Mutomboki Musumbu and Malaika, 3 rebels were killed in Nepanepa on December 29th. 1 of the rebels was captured, 1 soldier of the FARDC captured and 1 FARDC soldier injured.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Two days before the already set date for a manifestation in Kinshasha, LUCHA organised a protest in Kananga, on December 29th. The protesters manifested peacefully against the continued stay of President Kabila in power when the protest was dispersed by the police and 12 LUCHA militants were arrested.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Unidentified armed men attacked Kamananga, Kalehe, on December 30th. They shot and injured three men and kidnapped 2 children who used to be Raia Mutomboki members. Then, they looted and set three houses on fire.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Unidentified armed men attacked Kavumo, in Kalehe (close to Numbi), on December 30th, killing one woman and wounding an ARN agent.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Looting: unidentified armed men raided the Kimemi police station in Butembo on December 30th, stealing an AK-47.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Looting: unidentified armed men looted Braza-Chumba village, in Walikale. They were later arrested by the FARDC after these were alerted to the situation.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki-Kabazimiya)
column17: On December 30th, the Raia Mutomboki-Kabazimiya kidnapped three men from the village of Ndese, in Shabunda.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The Mayi Mayi Raia Mutomboki-Kisekelwa attacked the FARDC in the Kabalo mining site, in Walikale, on December 30th. The attack led to 4 dead (1 FARDC and 3 rebels) and 3 wounded (1 FARDC and 2 rebels).

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On December 30th, unidentified armed men attacked police officers in Sange who were protecting a savings and credit cooperative in the neighbourhood of Musenyi.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On December 30th, the Mayi Mayi attacked the FARDC in Nepanepa village, in Shabunda. The attack resulted in 3 deaths and one captured for the Malaika, and one wounded and one captured for the FARDC. One AK-47 was stolen.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Early on December 30th, in Ndosho, protesters belonging to the ""Congo Conscience"" group started burning tires in the streets. The riot was quickly choked by the police, which arrived at the scene and used tear gas to disperse the crowd in order to return the traffic to normal condition. Some rioters were arrested by the police.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: LUCHA: Fight for Change; Students (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 11 of the LUCHA protesters arrested on Friday in Kananga are undergoing a hunger strike in order to protest the irregularity of their arrest. 3 of them, who are students, are currently sick, according to a statement by their lawyer on January 1st.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019) National Intelligence Agency
column17: On December 31st, the police prevented a protest against Kabila's continued presidency from taking place in Kinshasa. 4 Filimbi protesters were arrested and later reports state that they were subjected to torture while in the custody of the National Intelligence Agency.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura)
column17: Four Nyatura rebels attacked 2 men in the village of Colline, in Rutshuru, owing to a dispute over a woman. One of the victims died.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On December 31st, the Mayi Mayi Mazembe launched an offensive against the FARDC in Kipese. There were 3 dead (2 rebels and 1 FARDC) and several wounded.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On December 31st, the police cracked down on a protest organised by the Lay Coordination Committee in Bukavu, leading to one person injured during the confrontation.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On December 31st, a police officer killed a 41 year old man in Majengo, Goma.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On December 31st, the FARDC launched an offensive on the Mayi Mayi Mazembe in Kirikiri, Lubero. The attack led to one death and 3 injured on the rebels' side.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On December 31st, police arrested fourteen people who were demonstrating in a peaceful protest in Butembo, before dispersing the rest of the protesters.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On December 31st, the police dispersed protesters in the Himbi neighbourhood in Goma. Due to pelting stones, the police arrested 4 of them. On the same day and in a different neighbourhood - Majengo - civilians became violent when a police officer shot a civilian. They were prevented from exerting mob justice when other policemen intervened.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Police broke off, on December 31st, a LUCHA protest in Lubiriha, Beni. The protesters demanded the implementation of the New Years deal when the police intervened and injured four of them.

column6: Lendu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Hema Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Reports of violence against civilians in the form of assaults with machetes owing to intercommunal violence are causing people to flee Djugu and the region of Ituri. A UN investigation carried out in March 2018 revealed that over 16 December - 14 March, 263 people were killed in violence between the Lendu and Hema ethnic groups, 29 injured and 120 localities and villages burnt down. Most of the victims hail from the Hema group. The violence took place in Djugu territory (Bahema-Nord, Walendu Tatsi, Walendu Djatsi, Walendu Pitsi, Bahema Banyuagi, Ndo Okebo and Mambisa). 163 fatalities coded in individual events in dataset; additional 100 coded in general events for December, January, February and March.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 31 December. Police forces dispersed a demonstration in Kinshasa organised by the Secular Coordination Commitee

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On Sunday 31st December, the presumed Mayi Mayi attacked the police in the village of Batuashama, in Mweka, injuring some of the policemen and burning a police sub-station.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On Sunday 31st December, the DRC police repelled an attack by the Mayi Mayi around the Kananga military district.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura) Kasongo Faction
column17: On January 1st, an 18 year old girl was killed in the village of Mpeti, in Walikale, by Nyatura Kasongo militia men.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: UPLC: Union of Patriots for the Liberation of Congo
column17: On January 1st, the FARDC clashed with the Mayi Mayi Kilalo in Mabuya, Beni, leading to 2 deaths (one on each side).

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On January 1st, the police took 2 men under arrest due to sensitising the villagers of Bulambika, in Kalehe, towards fiscal disobedience. The police then tortured the two men.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On January 1st, unidentified armed men raided the village of Mulima, breaking into houses to steal goods and money. In one of the houses there was no money, so the group kidnapped a 14 year old girl and raped her.

column6: Kuluna Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On January 1st, in the beach in Moanda, a fight broke out between 2 attenders. The Kuluna gang took advantage of the situation and violence ensued. At least 10 people died, of which 1 woman and 9 children.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The FARDC and the Mayi Mayi Hapa na Pale clashed on New Year's Day, January 1st, in the locality of Butondo, in Kongolo.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On January 1st, NDC-Guidon and the FARDC clashed in the Mafilo mining site, in Walikale. The rebels killed one FARDC member, stole his gun and still looted civilians.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A policeman killed a 10-year old girl in Kashuga, Masisi, on January 2nd.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki-Hamakombo)
column17: On January 2nd, the Raia Mutomboki Hamakombo raided the village of Chisasa, in Kalehe, looting money and cattle, and burning 7 houses. During the raid, they kidnapped 2 men and demanded a $1.200 ransom.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019) National Intelligence Agency
column8: Private Security Forces (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 02 January. Six armed men claiming to be members of the Democratic Republic of CongoÐ¥s National Intelligence Agency (ANR) attempted to enter the home of journalist Tshivis Tshivuadi in Kinshasa. The assailants severely assaulted a guard at the residence.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The FARDC and presumed Mayi Mayi clashed on January 2nd near the airport of Kananga. 3 deaths were reported.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 02 January. Mai-Mai Hapa na Pale elements allied with Mai-Mai Yakutumba attacked an FARDC position near Lumumba (20 km south of Bendera), killing three FARDC soldiers.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki-Mabala)
column17: Looting: On January 3rd, the Mayi Mayi Raia Mutomboki Wemba raided the villages of Kakongya, Kiluma, Nyakanya and Mukangi in Shabunda. Among others, they looted solar pannels, money and cattle.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On January 3rd, unidentified armed men killed a soldier in Mukulya neighbourhood, in Beni.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Looting: an unidentified armed group raided the offices of civil society organisations in Butembo during the night of January 4th.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A military personnel killed a taxi driver on January 4th, in Kananga. According to reports, the conflict started when the driver asked the soldier for the pay concerning the travel. The altercation then developed and the soldier shot the taxi driver several times point blank.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On January 5th, unidentified armed men raided the village of Mununze, in Beni. Apart from looting the village, they kidnapped two men, for which they demanded ransoms.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On January 5th, a group of armed men raided a house in Kitumba-Bisagara and killed a 62 year old man and his 14 year old son.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On January 5th, a 34 year old woman was killed by unidentified men in Kibati village.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 05 January. In South Kivu, Mai-Mai Yakutumba and allied groups conducted major attacks against FARDC when Mai-Mai elements attacked an FARDC position near Uvira, killing four FARDC soldiers and five national police officers.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Agreement: on January 5th, Marcel Mulunda, a Mayi Mayi hapa na pale militiaman, surrendered to the FARDC in Tanganika. It is expected that this gesture will incite the other 46 militiamen in the region to surrender as well.

column6: Unidentified Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 2 people were killed by machetes and axes on the night of January 4-5, in the village of Rukaza, in Matanda. The killing is allegedly due to land disputes going on in the region.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On January 6th, the FARDC launched an offensive on the Mayi Mayi Leopards who were moving through Kalau, in Beni.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On January 6th, two police officers kidnapped a 21 year old woman and 23 year old man in Butembo. They beat them and held them for 3 hours.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: Property destruction: A helicopter belonging to MONUSCO was attacked on January 6th, in Fizi. The attack is suspected to have been led by an armed group which is still active in the region, although no identity was confimed.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On January 7th, the Raia Mutomboki Hamakombo attacked the FARDC position at Kambale market in Kalehe territory following the arrest by the FARDC of a woman believed to be Hamakombo's spouse. One 17-year-old boy was shot and wounded and goods were stolen.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: 07 January 2018. A suspected LRA combatant abducted a girl north of Bamangana, Dungu.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On January 7th, clashes between the FARDC and the Mayi Mayi Hapa na pale resulted in the death of five persons. The attack took place in the villages of Numbi, Mbeya and Masumbalungu, in Kilembwe. The victims are 2 militiamen and 3 civilians, which include the Kilembwe traditional chief and his sons.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On January 7th, clashes between the FARDC and the Mayi Mayi Hapa na pale resulted in the death of five persons. The attack took place in the villages of Numbi, Mbeya and Masumbalungu, in Kilembwe. The victims are 2 militiamen and 3 civilians, which include the Kilembwe traditional chief and his sons.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Agreement: 4 Mayi Mayi combatants surrendered to the FARDC in Kalau, Kalingati and Kalunguta, in the territory of Beni, on January 7th. These surrenders are expected to be due to the pression exerted by the military on the militia.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On January 7th, clashes between the FARDC and the Mayi Mayi Hapa na pale resulted in the death of five persons. The attack took place in the villages of Numbi, Mbeya and Masumbalungu, in Kilembwe. The victims are 2 militiamen and 3 civilians, which include the Kilembwe traditional chief and his sons.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 08 January. On 8 and 10 January, suspected ADF elements attacked FARDC positions on the MbauKamango axis. Causalities not known.

column6: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On 8 January 2018, suspected ADF elements attacked FARDC positions on the Mbau-Kamango axis in Kasai and Katanga Provinces. Causalities not known.

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: FDLR-FOCA combatants abducted eleven people who were returning from their fields close to Kahumiro village in Rutshuru territory, on January 9th. The assailants killed five men.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Mazembe)
column17: The Mai-Mai Mazembe shot dead three men aged 36, 37 and 60, respectively, in Domaine, Rutshuru, on January 9th. They also shot and injured a 48-year-old man.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On January 9th, unidentified gunmen fired at a motorcycle carrying a FARDC soldier on the Butembo-Goma road near Kibirizi locality in Rutshuru territory. The FARDC soldier retaliated and the attackers fled. In the clash, a 37-year-old civilian died after he was hit by a bullet.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Police and FARDC dispersed a peaceful march organized on January 9th by civil society in Kitindi village, Shabunda territory, to demand community development from the mining company Banro Mining.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The FARDC attacked the Mayi-Mayi Mazembe position near the village of Domaine in Rutshuru territory, on January 9th. The FARDC chased the armed group out of the village.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki)
column17: On January 9th, the Raia Mutomboki Elenge looted money and goods from traders who were coming back from Isangi close to Katatwa village in Walikale territory. The assailants shot and wounded two men trying to escape and forced eight men to carry the looted goods.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The FARDC repelled, on January 9th, an attack by the Mayi Mayi in the rural comune of Lubero. The Mayi Mayi attacked the area where the FARDC are established, clashing with the forces. No casualties were reported.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Unidentified gunmen held up a motorcycle close to Katsiru in Rutshuru territory on January 10th. The assailants abducted the man and woman and stole the motorcycle.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: UPLC: Union of Patriots for the Liberation of Congo
column17: On January 10th, the Mai-Mai Kilalo attacked the FARDC position in Lubero rural commune in the territory of the same name.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: UPLC: Union of Patriots for the Liberation of Congo
column17: After reinforcements arrived on January 10th, the FARDC managed to expel the UPLC from Kipese, recovering control of the territory.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Unidentified armed men broke into a house in Mapendo, in Rutshuru territory, on January 10th, where they shot and killed a woman. In a nearby property, the assailants came across a policeman who shot at them. During the clash the policeman, a man and two women were killed; an infant was shot and wounded.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Kifuafua)
column17: On January 10th, armed men identified as Mayi-Mayi Kifuafua Delphin Mbaenda killed a woman in Mandje village in Walikale territory, accusing her of being a witch. The assailants looted the victim's house.

column6: Batwa Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: During the month of October, Batwa militias raped and gang raped 17 women along the Kalemie-Kabulo-Kioko road in Tanganyika. The attacks often occurred as the group attacked villages. Coded as four incidents each week in October.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: Looting: A suspected LRA member attacked and looted 3 cyclists and a motorcyclist in Bambangana, on January 10th. The report has nevertheless a low verification rating. No injuries reported.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Early January 2018. FARDC arrested Romaric Madango an anti-balaka leader and two fellows after they crossed into DRC. They were later extradicted to CAR

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: ALPC: Alliance for the Liberation of Congolese People
column17: On January 10th, the FARDC repelled an attack by the ALPC in Brimu, periphery of Ingbokolo in Aru (Ituri). The attack was launched against the positions of the military in retaliation for the killing of their leader last November during a FARDC operation in the area. The clash lasted for an hour, after which the rebels fled, leaving behind an AK-47. The positions of the military in Brimu were reinforced to ensure the population's safety.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: MLC: Movement for the Liberation of Congo
column17: 10 January. An hour-long exchange of fire occurred at Ndrimu (location not found) between FARDC and suspected armed elements of the Armee de liberation du peuple congolais, a residual armed group associated with the Kakwa community. The group has been largely dormant, and its strength is assessed to be fewer than 50 elements.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: UPLC: Union of Patriots for the Liberation of Congo
column17: Briefly after the UPLC occupied the locality of Kipese, the FARDC repelled their attacked and reclaimed control of the location. The UPLC reportedly took refuge in a location nearby and are waiting for reinforcements to arrive in order to launch another offensive in Kipese.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 10 January. On 8 and 10 January, suspected ADF elements attacked FARDC positions on the MbauKamango axis. Causalities not known.

column6: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On 10 January 2018, suspected ADF elements attacked FARDC positions on the Mbau Kamango axis (Beni, Nord-Kivu). Causalities not known.

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column17: During the week of 7-13 January, the Mayi Mayi Kamwina Nsapu set fire to houses in Kakenge, Mweka, reportedly following orders from the traditional leader of Kalamba. Reports mentions that some people were injured, and that some babies died in the hospital due to lack of medicine.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The Mayi-Mayi Malaika attacked the FARDC position in Kalole-Mapepo village in Shabunda territory on January 11th. The assailants stole 38 goats and other goods. They forced seven men to carry the stolen goods.

column6: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
column17: A dozen civilians, including a Congolese journalist, were kidnapped by the ADF in Beni, on January 11th. The rebels blocked the vehicles coming from Kasindi before taking the civilians hostage.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: An ambush from the FPRI against 8 women in the chiefdom of Walendu Bindi, in Ituri, on January 11th, was prevented due to the intervention of the FARDC.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The 8 women who had been ambushed the FRPI were then undressed by the same FARDC military men that prevented their ambush, with one of the women being raped by one of the militaries. Earlier that day, women fish vendors going to Bavi were also taken hostage by FARDC men to transport their goods and forced to go into the forest before they were released.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Police fired tear gas at churchgoers on Friday, January 12th, who gathered to mourn the seven people killed in protests against President Joseph Kabila two weeks ago. The police claims it fired the tear gas outside the church in order to avoid another polical demonstration.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: DRC police dispersed a march led by Vital Kamerhe in Kinshasa, on January 12th. According to the officers, Vital gathered a crowd of supporters in the high way after a mass organised in order to remember the victims of the December 31st protest. The police claims it was forced to use tear gas to disperse the crowd since the protest was not authorised in advance. During the march, protesters pelted stones at the police.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Taxi Drivers (Democratic Republic of Congo); Students (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Economic activities and traffic are paralysed in Ituri since January 12th due to the arrest of the president of the taxi association, which took place on January 11th. The protesters are composed mainly of taxi drivers and students, who have blocked streets and demand the release of the taxi association president.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The FARDC launched, on January 13th, an offensive against the ADF in Beni and Lubero, in response to the recents attacks by the group. Gunfires and explosions were heard in Beni all throughout Saturday (13th).

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Presumed FARDC attacked the ADF in the periphery of Oicha on January 13th. Shots were heard in the locality and it is suspected that the FARDC are attacking the 'death triangle' situated in between Mbau, Kamango and Eringeti. The reports are not confirmed by the military. Military forces overtook two ADF camps.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: Around 13 January 2018, the FARDC launched an offensive in Eastern DRC. The offensive took place in the territories of Beni, Oicha and Lubero, and targeted all the armed group involved in conflict in the region, in particular the ADF.

column6: Batwa Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Luba Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 14 January. There were reported clashes between Twa militias and the Elements at Kabulembe (45 km south-east of Pweto), causing a deterioration of the humanitarian situation in Katama groupement (40 km north-east of Pweto), including displacements of the local population. Causalities not known.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On Sunday 14th January, 2 IRC agents were kidnapped by an unidentified armed group in Mazonde. The two were released 3 days after on Wednesday, thanks to the interveniton of a major who had deserted the army and who is now in command of a Twa militia.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On the night of January 13th to 14th, an armed group with killed a pregnant woman in Gemena. The group sought to rob her house and broke down her front door. When the woman approached the window, she was shot and died. The group has reportedly been active in Gemena for some time.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On January 14th, a group of armed men attacked the FARDC near Kananga airport. The assailants attacked the soldiers during their sleep and proceeded to set their tent on fire. 4 soldiers were killed.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On the night of January 14th to 15th, a trader was killed in Kamanyola by an unidentified armed group.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Between January-April, report of over 10 targeted killings as well as kidnappings and looting by unknown gunmen stationed at Virunga National Park. 10 fatalities spread over four events between January and April.

column6: Lendu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Hema Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A UN investigation carried out in March 2018 revealed that over 16 December - 14 March, 263 people were killed in violence between the Lendu and Hema ethnic groups, 29 injured and 120 localities and villages burnt down. Most of the victims hail from the Hema group. The violence took place in Djugu territory (Bahema-Nord, Walendu Tatsi, Walendu Djatsi, Walendu Pitsi, Bahema Banyuagi, Ndo Okebo and Mambisa). 163 coded in individual events in dataset; additional 100 coded in general events for December, January, February and March.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Non-violent activity: Civil society in Mongala is accusing the stationed military personnel in the villages of Lisala and Bumba of ransoming passing civilians and merchants. In order to recover the money paid, merchants raise prices, creating scarcity of products.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The Mayi Mayi Yakutumba attacked villages in the Mutambala sector on January 15-16, trying to besiege them, but were repelled by the FARDC.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Youth gathered on the morning of January 15th to protest the death of a trader, during the night, at the hands of an armed group. The national route was blocked and all economic activity was paralysed. By midday Monday, police fired warning shots to disperse demonstrators who were trying to set fire to a police station.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: On January 14th, in collaboration with the armies of neighbouring countries and MONUSCO, the FARDC regained control over the village of Mambaiko/Mamba Iko, expelling the ADF.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: On January 14th, in collaboration with the armies of neighbouring countries and MONUSCO, the FARDC regained control over the village of Silimbamba, expelling the ADF.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: On January 14th, in collaboration with the armies of neighbouring countries and MONUSCO, the FARDC regained control over the village of Sesele, expelling the ADF.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On Monday, January 15th, the ADF attacked the FARDC in Munzambayi, commune of Rwenzori, where they were repelled. According to the FARDC, 5 people were injured (3 of which seriously) and 2 weapons were seized. A later testimony reports 3 FARDC deaths.

column6: Batwa Ethnic Militia (Burundi)
column17: On January 16th, a civilian was killed by the Batwa militia in the village of Kalubembe, 41km from Pweto. The militiamen attacked with arrows, killing one man and injuring another woman.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: On January 16th, the LRA kidnapped citizens and refugees from Gwane.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019) National Intelligence Agency
column17: 2 National Intelligence Agency officers were abducted by armed men in the province of South-Kivu on January 16th. Two days later, there was an attack on a military position in Fizi.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The Mayi Mayi Yakutumba attacked villages in the Mutambala sector on January 15-16, trying to besiege them, but were repelled by the FARDC.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Gunshots were heard on the morning of January 16th in the hill 'Tujenge', 12 km to the south of Baraka. Some passerby women were told by the FARDC to turn back when they were heading there. One of the women says she saw the dead body of a combatant on the ground. The Yakutumba claim 5 FARDC soldiers were killed, though this is unverified.

column6: APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
column17: The headquarters of the Mayi Mayi APCLS in Matende, Lwibo, were attacked by a coalition of NDC-R rebels and APCLS dissidents on January 17th. According to local sources, at least 6 people died (2 on the NDC-R side and 4 on the APCLS) and 7 were injured (NDC-R side).

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: On January 17th, the LRA kidnapped citizens and refugees from Sukadi.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 17 January. From 17 to 19 January, in the Uvira area, FARDC repeatedly clashed with the Burundian Forces nationales de liberation and associated Congolese Mai-Mai groups. Causalities not known.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 17 January. Clashes between Kamuina Nsapu militia and FARDC in Kambamba, about 65 km north of Tshikapa, resulting in the killing of at least four Kamuina Nsapu militia members

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 17 January. DRC forces and Kamwina Nsapu militia clashed at Kananga airport. An estimated three dead.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Security Measures: the FARDC announces the launch of a sensitisation towards disarmament campaign in Lubero, in order to promote defection from the Mayi Mayi militias. The FARDC confirms the defection of commander Nzilamba Katika of the Mayi Mayi Leopard, known by Yesu.

column6: Government of Angola (1975-)
column8: Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Agreement: after two days of discussion, the provincial governors of Kasai Central and Kwango and the provincial minister of energy of Lualaba decided to reopen the DRC-Angola border which had been closed since 2017.

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column7: CNRD: National Council for Renewal and Democracy
column9: MSF: Doctors Without Borders; Aid Workers (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On January 18th, 2 MSF agents were kidnapped by armed men in Kalembe, in the territory of Masisi. The convoy was returning from Walikale when they stopped to provide medical assistance and fell into an ambush. The FDLR/CNRD are accused of being the actors, among others.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A military convoy, headed by general Philemon Yav, the commander of military operations, came under fire by the Yakutumba on January 19th in Fizi. Four soldiers killed.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 18 January 2018. An unidentified armed group looted a man on a motorcycle south of Zambaleke, Dungu.

column6: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 19 January. ADF launched attacks on FARDC in Oicha region resulting in 12 killed FARDC soldiers and 4 ADF rebels

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: ADF attacked 2 locations near the Uganda border on Friday 19th - the villages of Parikingi and Abialos, resulting in the death of 4 rebels and 20 FARDC soldiers. 4 AK-47s were recovered, as well as a Motorola radio and a mortar. The attack was repelled by the FARDC, but the clash was described as being of an extremely violent nature. Fatalities split between events.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: ADF attacked 2 locations near the Uganda border on Friday 19th - the villages of Parikingi and Abialos -, resulting in the death of 4 rebels and 20 FARDC soldiers. 4 AK-47s were recovered, as well as a Motorola radio and a mortar. The attack was repelled by the FARDC, but the clash was described as being of an extremely violent nature. Fatalities split between events.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The FARDC resumed its bombing in Beni on Friday 19th January, in a continued attempt to target ADF.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: On January 20th, the LRA kidnapped citizens and refugees from Ndamana.

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: An FRPI incursion in the south of Irumu targeted 6 villages during the course of January 20-21. In Sasa, the rebels raped a woman and ransacked the village.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On Saturday 20th, 3 FARDC soldiers were killed in a clash with ADF that took place in Nyakele, Beni.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Movement of forces: the police and the FARDC were deployed to almost all of the parishes in Mbuji Mayi in order to surround and prevent the protests called by the CLC from happening the next morning. Barriers guarded by the state forces were placed on the main arteries of the city and all the circulation was cut. Forces were also deployed to Kisebwe, in Kalemie, to prevent protests. MONUSCO observers were on the field. The SMS services, social media and internet were blocked ahead of the protests at 23:00 GMT, Saturday night.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: An FRPI incursion in the south of Irumu targeted 6 villages during the course of January 20-21. In Sukwa (report mentions Supka), the FRPI ransacked the village but was then repelled by the FARDC. In Songokoi, the army intervened in order to prevent FRPI from ransacking the population.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 20 January 2018. An unidentified armed group abducted five Central African IDP children near Digba, Bas Uele.

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: Looting: An FRPI incursion in the south of Irumu targeted 6 villages during the course of January 20-21. In Nyamabo-Songolo, the rebels ransacked the population.

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: Looting: An FRPI incursion in the south of Irumu targeted 6 villages during the course of January 20-21. In Tulabo, the rebels ransacked the population.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: CLC: Lay Coordination Committee; Christian Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On January 21st, the protest organised by the CLC took place in Kisangani. Several people organised and started marches, accompanied by their priests. The marchers demanded the full application of the Saint Sylvester agreement. Some marched for 500m, others for 1km, but the marches were then stopped by police officers who dispersed protesters with tear gas and real bullets. Some people were injured.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: CLC: Lay Coordination Committee; Christian Group (Democratic Republic of Congo); MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: On January 21st, protests organised by the CLC in Kinshasa were choked by police, who used excessive force. Live bullets were shot near the St. Gabriel de Yolo Sud parish (commune of Kalamu), and one protester was injured. Protesters at Saint Jean-Baptiste parish were also dispersed with tear gas and live bullets; one protester was beaten up. MONUSCO reports that 6 protesters were killed, including a 16 year old girl, along with 57 people injured and more than 100 people arrested nationwide.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: CLC: Lay Coordination Committee; Christian Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On January 21st, the protest organised by the CLC took place in Bukavu. The police deployed their forces in several parts of the city to stop the protest.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: CLC: Lay Coordination Committee; Christian Group (Democratic Republic of Congo); LUCHA: Fight for Change
column17: Arrests: On January 21st, Christians and other protesters such as LUCHA militants were arrested nationwide in Kinshasa, Goma and Beni. MONUSCO reports more than 100 arrests. ACAJ reports 247 arrests.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: CLC: Lay Coordination Committee; Christian Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: National Congolese police intervened on Sunday 21st in Lubumbashi, stopping the protests organised by the CLC in order 'to protect public order'. The police claimed the protesters wanted to burn tyres and block roads.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The FARDC intervened after the attack in Kokola, on January 21st, and repelled the ADF.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 21 January. FARDC launched operations against Mai-Mai Yakutumba on 21 January and took control on 25 January of Kazimia, a stronghold of the armed group. Causalities not known in both instances.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 21 January. ADF launched an attack against an FARDC camp near Mayi Moya on 21 January. Causalities not known.

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: Looting: An FRPI incursion in the south of Irumu targeted 6 villages during the course of January 20-21. In Mbisa, the rebels ransacked the population.

column6: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
column17: Suspected Islamist Ugandan rebels (ADF) killed three civilians in Kokola on January 21st. The victims were a taxi driver and his two customers.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: CLC: Lay Coordination Committee; Christian Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Christians in the village of Mbuji Mayi on January 21st were injured while participating in the protest called by the CLC. Several protesters were arrested. 4 tear gas grenades were thrown into the Saint Jean Baptiste Bonzola cathedral, where Christians were locked up.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Kifuafua)
column17: Two factions of the Mayi Mayi Kifuafua faced each other in the locality of Makungulano, in Walikale. They clashed due to the sharing of goods collected at the market, causing the population to flee and the activity in the locality to stop. There are two severely injured people.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Vigilante Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On January 22nd, young people in Mbandaka burned a civilian alive - mob justice. The victim had tried to dismantle a solar panel at the Basoko market when he was suprised by a group of young people. They then took him to the front of the Basoko police station, where they burned him alive.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 22 January 2018. An unidentified armed man, who wore military fatigues and spoke broken Lingala, looted three people along a road near Nambia, Haut Uele.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On January 23rd, the Mayi Mayi Yakutumba launched an offensive against the FARDC in Baraka. They came from the direction of Lake Tanganyka and attacked the forces, killing one person and injuring another 4.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Banyamulenge Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 23 January. A Banyamulenge landowner was killed by unknown assailants near Mutarule.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: End-January 2018. LRA attacked villages in the Ango, Bangadi, Bondo, Dungu and Faradje territories. Exact locations and dates not known.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: End-January 2018. LRA attacked villages in the Ango, Bangadi, Bondo, Dungu and Faradje territories. Exact locations and dates not known.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: End-January 2018. LRA attacked villages in the Ango, Bangadi, Bondo, Dungu and Faradje territories. Exact locations and dates not known.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: End-January 2018. LRA attacked villages in the Ango, Bangadi, Bondo, Dungu and Faradje territories. Exact locations and dates not known.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: End-January 2018. LRA attacked villages in the Ango, Bangadi, Bondo, Dungu and Faradje territories. Exact locations and dates not known.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: APRDC: Alliance of Patriots for the Restoration of Democracy in Congo
column17: On January 24th, the APRDC, a dissident militia from the Mayi Mayi Nyatura clashed with FARDC in the locality of Muheto, in Masindi. Mayi-Mayi ransacked the local commerce and intimidated the population upon overtaking the location. After being called for reinforcement, the FARDC repelled the APRDC and retook control of the area.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Students (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On January 24th, students from the University of Kinshasa protested against the academic fees they were demanded to pay. The police intervened, using tear gas to disperse the crowd and arresting some of the students. During the process, some students were injured, while four police officers were also reportedly injured due to pelting.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 24 January. On 24 January, suspected ADF elements attacked FARDC in Mapobu (10 km east of Oicha), killing 5 FARDC soldiers and wounding 36 others. MONUSCO provided support in evacuating the wounded.

column6: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
column17: On Thursday, January 25th, one civilian was killed and three others injured during an attack by ADF in Eringiti.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Yakutumba)
column17: Looting: on January 25th, while escaping from Ubwari, the Yakutumba looted the village of Mahembe (situated between Lulimba and Salamabila.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On January 25, a sailor from the naval force named Tresor Akondji Simba raped a woman in Baraka.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Students (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On January 25th, the protests by students at the University of Kinshasa continued. Police shot real bullets and used tear gas to disperse the crowds, with reports mentioning that officers stole computers, money and phones, and tracked students down in their residences. At least one student was brought to the hospital after being hit by a bullet. Three policemen were reportedly injured.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: UPLC: Union of Patriots for the Liberation of Congo
column17: On January 25th, the FARDC launched an offensive against the UPLC in Kasindi-Lubiriha, 90km east of Beni. During the operation, one of the rebels was killed. A subsequent report mentions two deaths.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 25 January. FARDC launched operations against Mai-Mai Yakutumba on 21 January and took control on 25 January of Kazimia, a stronghold of the armed group. Causalities not known in both instances.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 25 January. On 25 January, a large group of Mai-Mai elements attacked an FARDC position in Mahembe (25 km west of Lulimba), forcing FARDC to retreat. Causalities not known. It is not known if the Mai Mai attacks gained control of the area.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: 25 January 2018. An LRA combatant looted a family and abducted the wife near Kulugbangu, Dungu as they were traveling from Nambia to Bambangana.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On January 27th, civil society organised a sit-in in Bukavu to protest against the insecurity seen in the region.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 27 January. Suspected Mai-Mai elements clashed with FARDC in Kahoho (50 km south-west of Lulimba) and reportedly burned houses before retreating. Causalities not known.

column6: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: On Saturday, January 27th, a Pakistani member of MONUSCO was killed during an operation in Lulimba against an armed group. At least another peacekeeper was injured during the attack. Later reports indicate the attackers were Mai Mai.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: 27 January 2018. The LRA looted travelers 15 km from Nambia. The assailants also abducted two men to carry the looted items. The abductees were later released.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On January 28th, the FARDC clashed with the Mayi Mayi Yakutumba in Katenga village.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On January 28th, the FARDC clashed with the Mayi Mayi Yakutumba in Manga village.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On January 28th, the FARDC recovered the location of Nemba.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On January 28th, the FARDC clashed with the Mayi Mayi Yakutumba in Dine village.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On January 28th, the FARDC clashed with the Mayi Mayi Yakutumba in Mizimu village.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On January 28th, the FARDC recovered the location of Kazimia.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On January 28, an exchange of shots between police and an unidentified armed group in Kinshase led to two people killed in the comune of Bandalungwa, in Kinshasa. The armed group, who was on the run while being pursued by police, started the exchange. Their driver was killed, as well as a police officer. At least 2 civilians were injured.

column6: NDC-R: Nduma Defence of Congo (Renewal)
column17: Two factions of the Nduma NDC group - Renewal and Mandaima - clashed with one another in the villages of Mukaka and Kailinge, in the grouping of Ihana in Walikale. One person was killed and others were injured.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The FARDC clashed with the FNL forces in Kiliba on January 29th. The clash started at 2am and lasted until 6am. The rebels were taken by surprise by the FARDC, who conducted an ambush in the Rusabagi quarter. 3 people were killed.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: After the driver of a vehicle killed 2 people during the riots that took place in Basoko, he fled to Lokutu to get protection from the Congolese police. The civilians from Basoko went to the Lokutu police station to protest his killing of 2 people and were dispersed by the police with live bullets. One of the police officers nevertheless shot against one of the victims family members.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: After the police officer shot against one of the protesters on January 29th, these became violent, managed to get one of the police officers and lynched him in the open.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: FNL-N: National Forces of Liberation (Nzabampema Faction)
column17: On 29 January 2018, four FNL Nzabampema Faction rebels were killed by the Congolese army on their way back to the Rukoko reserve (in Burundi along the BDI-COD border near Kiliba/Uvira).

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 29 January. Two days of unrest took over Kasai between January 29-30. Clashes between the FARDC and Kamwina Nsapu militia led to 9 deaths. A later reported indicated 20 dead, plus 350 displaced. On Monday, 4 people were killed in the village of Bata Ishama, 12km from Kakenge.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On January 29th, the Congolese police clashed with civilians who became violent in the locality of Basoko, causing 5 deaths (4 civilians and one police officer). A vehicle belonging to the PHC/Feronia society hit a woman, who died along with her baby, and another person along the route.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Protesters held a demonstration in Kisoro on January 29th against the arrest of their LC3 Chairman Didas Muntuki. Over 500 locals gathered with their local MP at Kaku Bridge, at which point police dispersed them with tear gas and live bullets.

column6: NDC-R: Nduma Defence of Congo (Renewal)
column17: Two factions of the Nduma NDC group - Renewal and Mandaima - clashed with one another in the villages of Mukaka and Kailinge, in the grouping of Ihana in Walikale. One person was killed and others were injured.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: The mayor of Beni was subjected to an attack on January 30th, when an unidentified group of men threw a grenade insider her car close to the Kilokwa market in Beni. The mayor managed to get the grenade and throw it back out before it exploded.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: One person was killed by bullets after an altercation between civilians from the village of Leiko and those from Robu. The altercation led to the involvement of a police officer who ended up shooting one of the persons. After the police officer killed one of the people involved, the villagers from Robu started setting houses on fire.

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 30 January. Two days of unrest took over Kasai between January 29-30. Clashes between the FARDC and Kamwina Nsapu militia led to 9 deaths. A later reported indicated 20 dead, plus 350 displaced. On Monday, 4 people were killed in the village of Bata Ishama, 12km from Kakenge.

column6: Rioters (South Sudan)
column8: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: Tensions were registered on January 31st in the periphery of Goma between South-Sudanese ex-combatants and MONUSCO forces. The former blocked roads and pelted MONUSCO forces, demanding their departure from a camp where 370 ex-combatants are living. The MONUSCO, in turn, used tear gas on the ex-combatants.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Non-violent activity: police fired live bullets and used tear gas to disperse the crowd that had gathered in Bulenga, in front of Police Commander Muhammad Kirumira's house, on January 1st. The Commander had announced his resignation the day before, and when police arrived at his place to arrest him, he closed himself refusing to leave. The police broke into his house and arrested him, then carried him outside, preventing him from addressing the crowd that had gathered.

column6: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: Movement of forces: on February 1, the MONUSCO deployed forces to Mweka, where militiamen close to a traditional chief are being accused of arson, and to Kakenge.

column6: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
column17: The ADF attacked the locality of Kitevya (40km north-west of Beni), pillaging a hospital and killing 3 people (2 by bullets and 1 by machete).

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: Catholic Christian Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Police kidnapped a catholic priest after mass in Kinshasa, amid tensions between the church and the DR Congo's government over the president's refusal to step down.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: Catholic Christian Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Congolese police arrested a catholic priest outside his church on Saturday February 3rd in Kinshasa, following mass and amid tensions between the government and the church. During his arrest he was beaten by the police forces and interrogated at length over his alleged association with the Kamwina Nsapu militia. The priest was released hours after.

column6: Hema Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Lendu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On February 3rd, inter-ethnic fighting broke out in Blukwa, around 100km from Bunia, between the Hema and Lendu militias. The attack lasted two days and at least 23 members of the Hema community were killed by Lendu (although reports differ, ranging from 23-32), 12 people were severely injured and several houses were burned during the attack on the Hema village. Police and soldiers were dispatched to the spot to prevent the spread of violence, which followed days of tension between the two ethnic communities in the region.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 03 February 2018. An unidentified armed group looted produce from fields near Manzagala, Dungu.

column6: Hema Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Lendu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On February 3rd, inter-ethnic fighting broke out in Blukwa, around 100km from Bunia, between the Hema and Lendu militias. column9: CNRD: National Council for Renewal and Democracy

column6: NDC-R: Nduma Defence of Congo (Renewal)
column17: The NDC-Mandaima and NDC-Guidon clashed during February 5th in the Mutongo-Kailenge axis.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Activities have been paralysed in Blukwa since the morning of February 5th, due to the tension between police and protesters, who demonstrated against the ""massacre"" that took place on Saturday between the Lendu and Hema communities.

column6: Militia (Kalamba Dilondo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Agreement: a militia chief - Chief Kalamba Dilondo - surrendered to authorities on February 5th, in Kakenge.

column6: Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Agreement: The Tanzanian government extradited the ex-officer of the Congolese army, John Tshibangu, to Kinshasa on February 5th. The officer in question has posted a video on social media launching threats at President Kabila if he did not apologise in the following 45 days for the repression of the marches on Dec. 31.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Demonstrations relating to the inter-ethnic violence experienced 2 days prior in Blukwa also occurred in Bunia on February 5th and 6th. On the 5th, youth tried to block the passage of the governor in the central market.

column6: NDC-R: Nduma Defence of Congo (Renewal)
column17: The NDC Guidon clashed with the Nyatura militia in the Kalembe-Katabo axis, between Walikale and Masisi.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Demonstrations relating to the interethnic violence experienced 2 days prior in Blukwa also occurred in Bunia on February 5th and 6th. On the 6th, stores remained closed and streets deserted.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The FARDC recovered, on January 6th, the locattion of Eringeti, after confrontations with the ADF.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On the night of February 6-7, armed men broke into five houses and raped young girls in the presence of their parents.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: On February 6th, a suspected LRA member ambushed a motorcycle taxi driver. After that, he shot and killed another motorcycle driver who drove by and refused to stop. The assailant was then joined by two others, who proceeded to rob both drivers.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Property destruction: Following the attacks in the Ituri region, the assailants burned houses in the region of Gina, 45km from Bunia.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Inter-community conflicts led to the death of five people on February 7th in the territory of Djugu (Ituri). According to the local coalition for the defense of human rights, 5 people were killed (2 militaries, 2 police officers and 1 civilian). The attacks took place in Gobu, Songo Moya, Songa mbili and Tara.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Inter-community conflicts led to the death of five people on February 7th in the territory of Djugu (Ituri).
