column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The FARDC clashed with the factions Hamakombo and Kizamoto of the Mayi Mayi Raia Mutomboki, which led to 2 casualties on the rebels side. The attacks took place in Nkuni (territory of Shabunda) and Kabalagala (in Kalehe). In Kabalagala, the army recovered one AK-47.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The FARDC clashed with the factions Hamakombo and Kizamoto of the Mayi Mayi Raia Mutomboki, which led to 2 casualties on the rebels side. The attacks took place in Nkuni (territory of Shabunda) and Kabalagala (in Kalehe). In Nkuni, the army recovered one AK-47, killed one militiaman and there were three injured persons. A 9 year old girl was also shot in the leg. The situation in Nkuni is now under control and the people who had been taken hostage by the Mayi Mayi were released.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Inter-community conflicts led to the death of five people on February 7th in the territory of Djugu (Ituri). According to the local coalition for the defense of human rights, 5 people were killed (2 militaries, 2 police officers and 1 civilian). The attacks took place in Gobu, Songo Moya, Songa mbili and Tara.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Owing to the events that had taken place the night before, with the rapes by armed men, the population of Lubumbashi took to the streets to protest the continued state of insecurity in the city.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 08 February. General Yav announced that FARDC operations had resulted in the death of 83 Mai-Mai Yakutumba elements and 6 FARDC soldiers and the capture of 120 Mai-Mai elements. He added that almost all the localities formerly under the control of the armed group had been recovered by FARDC, including the Ubwari Peninsula and the coastline of Lake Tanganyika from Kalemie to Uvira. Date(s) of operations not known.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 08 February. General Yav announced that FARDC operations had resulted in the death of 83 Mai-Mai Yakutumba elements and 6 FARDC soldiers and the capture of 120 Mai-Mai elements. He added that almost all the localities formerly under the control of the armed group had been recovered by FARDC, including the Ubwari Peninsula and the coastline of Lake Tanganyika from Kalemie to Uvira. Date(s) of operations not known.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki-Kokodikoko)
column17: On the night of February 8-9th, Raia Mutomboki armed men led by Kokodikoko reportedly attacked the village of Kabikokole, chiefdom of Wamuzimu in South-Kivu. During the attack, more than 100 women and girls were allegedly raped in the forest and later taken hostage.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A policeman in Yakoma was tortured on February 9th by other policemen, who followed the orders or the colonel of Yakoma police station. The tortued policeman was accused of releasing a detainee, reason according to which the colonel ordered his torture. The victim died due to the injuries.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The FARDC recovered, on January 9th, the city of Uvira, after continued clashes with the Yakutumba since January 21st. The military anihilated the enemy and took control of the location. Since January 21st, 48 rebels were killed and 150 captured.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The FARDC intervened against the ADF during their ambush in Ngite, after they had already burned some buildings and killed 5 civilians.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: 09 February 2018. The LRA looted two civilians along the road in Bamangana, Dungu. The assailants were the same group that abducted three men in the area on the same day (coded separately).

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: 09 February 2018. The LRA abducted three men from Manguliti, Dungu (no coordinates available, near Bamangana). The assailants forced the men to shell peanuts for them before releasing them later that night.

column6: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
column17: After the attack in Mavivi, at around 18h30, around 30 rebels raided Ngite. They killed 4 people with bullets and machetes, and a fifth one died of cardiac arrest. At least two houses were set on fire, 8 stored pillaged and one other person injured.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Prisoners (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: The family of the deceased policeman who was tortured came to the territorial committee and pillaged the place, destroying documents. They also freed prisoners who were held there.

column6: Butembo Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 02 October. Two Red Cross workers were seriously wounded when community members attacked them while they were carrying out safe Ebola burials in the north-eastern city of Butembo.

column6: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: Movement of forces: MONUSCO has deployed more troops to reinforce the UN's presence in Djugu, Blukwa and Fataki since February 10th.

column6: Hema Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Lendu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: More than 60 people were killed during the previous week due to the interethnic conflicts between Hema and Lendu militias. 23 fatalities already reported in data.

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column9: Bakwa Mbuyi Communal Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On February 11th, the Kamwina Nsapu kidnapped the customary chief of the Bakwa Mbuyi communal group and his wife from Katole. They were found dead on February 14th.

column6: Militia (Kamwina Nsapu)
column17: On February 12th, another 4 people were kidnapped by the Kamwina Nsapu militia from Katole.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 12 February. On 12 February, FARDC and the Rwanda Defence Force clashed in the border area close to Virunga National Park, in Rutshuru territory, North Kivu. Causalities not known.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 12 February. FARDC and the Rwanda Defence Force clashed in the border area close to Virunga National Park, in Rutshuru territory, North Kivu. Causalities not known.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The FARDC announced on February 12th that it had recaptured the ""grand bastion"" of ADF rebels in Mwalika, about 80 kilometers (50 miles) from Beni.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Students (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Students started a protest on February 12th demanding the fixation of the charges for the academic fees. The sit-in was organised in Beni after the majority of academic institutions refused to apply the memorandum circulated by the Ministry fixating the prices.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Several detonations were heard on the night of February 13-14. The FARDC were attempting to recover a territory under the control of the ADF in the valley of Mapobu, situated in the triangle of death: Mbanu-Kamango and Eringiti.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column17: 13 February. FARDC spokesperson for Operation Sukola I Mongba, announced that FARDC took control of a major ADF camp in Mwalika, about 80 km from Beni.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The Congolese and Rwandan forces clashed on February 13 when the FARDC were engaged in combat in Isoke, National Park of Virunga, in Rutshuru. The FARDC initially thought it was the ex-M23, but it was in fact the Rwandan forces. There were deaths on both sides, with 6 on the FARDC side (death toll later increased to 10; and another 4 injured) and others in the Rwandan side (although no numbers were confirmed).

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On February 13, students were rejected by academic authorities when they wanted to pay their academic fees at the price of 920 Congolese francs, as defined by the Ministry of Education's memorandum. When they were rejected, they blocked roads in boulevard Sendwe, in Kinshasa. After police arrived, they dispersed them with tear gas.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 13 February. Military forces gain control of an ADF camp in Mwalika. No reported clashes.

column6: Aru Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Aru Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Inhabitants of Rodo village in Aru got into clashes with one another over land disputes in the region. The clashes started on Wednesday and lasted for three days. On February 14-15, 6 people were killed with weapons and 6 others were injured in the village of Rodo.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 14 February 2018. An unidentified armed man ambushed a mother and daughter in Manzagala. The assailant abducted the girl.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 14 February 2018. An unidentified armed man looted four men traveling on motorcycles near Manzagala, Dungu. The assailant was accompanied by a woman with a baby. The assailant fled upon hearing gunshots in the distance.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Students (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A protest by a group of students turned violent on February 14 in Goma, when the students started attacking and molesting journalists, even ripping their vests.

column6: Aru Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Aru Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Inhabitants of Rodo village in Aru got into clashes with one another over land disputes in the region. The clashes started on Wednesday and lasted for three days. On February 14-15, 6 people were killed with weapons and 6 others were injured in the village of Rodo.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: During the month of February, FARDC soldier Julio Opongo Jemelias raped a 25 year old woman while threatening her with his AK47.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On February 15, an unidentified armed group killed a civilian in the commune of Kadutu, in Bukavu, over an exchange of money. The victim was murdered with a Chinese grenade. An hour later around 20h, another armed group tried to pillage some boutiques in the Nguba side of the Ibanda commune. 2 other civilians died while trying to save themselves during this attack.

column6: Lendu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Hema Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A UN investigation carried out in March 2018 revealed that over 16 December - 14 March, 263 people were killed in violence between the Lendu and Hema ethnic groups, 29 injured and 120 localities and villages burnt down. Most of the victims hail from the Hema group. The violence took place in Djugu territory (Bahema-Nord, Walendu Tatsi, Walendu Djatsi, Walendu Pitsi, Bahema Banyuagi, Ndo Okebo and Mambisa). 163 coded in individual events in dataset; additional 100 coded in general events for December, January, February and March.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 15 February 2019. An unidentified armed group attacked Kagili, looting the town and abducting several people.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 15 February 2019. An unidentified armed group attacked Wesu, looting the town and abducting 'several' civilians.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Between January-April, report of over 10 targeted killings as well as kidnappings and looting by unknown gunmen stationed at Virunga National Park. 10 fatalities spread over four events between January and April.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: On February 16, the LRA attacked the localities of Mobili and Wepa, pillaging houses and kidnapping 7 civilians (2 others are disappeared).

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: On February 16th, 4 people were killed 15km away from Ango by unidentified armed men (suspected to be either the LRA or Mbororos breeders). Since the LRA had attacked the cities of Mobili and Wepa the day before, and they are 15 and 25 km from the centre of Ango, it is likely that it was them.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: On February 16, the LRA attacked the localities of Mobili and Wepa, pillaging houses and kidnapping 7 civilians (2 others are disappeared).

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: FCR: Civilian Front for the Republic
column17: The police forces of DRC choked, on February 16th, a protest organised by the FCR, aimed at demonstrating preoccupation with a new form of insecurity in certain areas of the city.

column6: Aru Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Aru Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Inhabitants of Aru got into clashes with one another over land disputes in the region. The clashes started on Wednesday and lasted for three days. On February 16-17, 2 other people were killed in the village of Etopi.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Civilians in Bukavu gathered to protest the 3 deaths occurred during the night before. They blocked roads before the police intervened and dispersed them. The situation was described as untenable. Youth related to the M23 movement was also part of the riot. The youth torched cars and set up barricades along major roads, and some of them were brutally beaten by police forces who were trying to prevent an uprising.

column6: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
column17: 5 people were killed during an ambush on a civilian vehicle by the presumed ADF in the Eringeti-Oicha axis, in Beni, on February 17th. At around 10h, 3 women and 2 men were murdered, and 8 other people were injured.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Students (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On February 17, the population from Ango rebelled because of the attacks perpetrated the day before and burned some houses belonging to foreigners and to Mbororos breeders. The police were forced to break the protest. One young student was arrested. Another person died from the injuries sustained by the confrontation with police and another is severely injured.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura)
column17: 4 French NGO workers belonging to HYFRO were abducted by presumed Nyatura militiamen on February 17th, between Nyanzala and Kikuku, in Mushikiri. They were returning to their base in Nyanzala when they were ambushed by Nyatura and, out of the 6, 4 were captured. A secondary source reports 2 fatalities.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura)
column17: Later the same day, when the hostages were being taken to an unknown location, they were attacked by another Nyatura faction in Ishola, near Nyanzala, where 2 of them were killed. The third hostage managed to escape while the fourth is still captured.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: ICCN: Congolese Institute for Nature Conservation
column17: On February 17th, 7 people were killed in an attack by unidentified armed men on a vehicle belonging to the Congolese Institute for Nature Conservation. The vehicle was ambushed when it returned from an official mission between Oicha and Eringeti. It is suspected that the perpetrators were ADF, but that was not confirmed.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: The FARDC clashed with an unidentified armed group in Katanga, killing two of them and recovering a PKM weapon on February 18th. A FARDC soldier was severely injured.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The FARDC claims they killed 8 ADF rebels in Nord-Kivu on February 19th, during a clash, in the valley of Mapobu. One of the persons was Muhammad Kayiira, chief of ADF's combat operations.

column6: Protesters (Burundi)
column7: Refugees/IDPs (Burundi)
column17: On 19 February 2018, Burundian refugees from Lusenda camp in DRC held a protest to demand their February food ration. They began a march to the Katunguru II site to go to the base of MONUSCO to express their satisfaction. [Size= no report]

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: 19 February 2018. The LRA looted travelers along the Bangadi-Ngilima road. The group held the civilians for several hours before releasing them.

column6: Lendu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Hema Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 20 February. In Djugu territory, Lendu youths reportedly killed four Hema civilians (two men and two girls) and one FARDC soldier and destroyed some 300 houses in the Tche area (16 km south of Blukwa). The violence has prompted significant population displacements within the province and towards neighbouring Uganda.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 20 February 2018. An unidentified armed group looted a field 5 km from Zigbi, Dungu.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura)
column7: Hutu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Mutanda Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On February 20th, the Hutu Nyatura and a youth communal militia clashed in Bwito, Mutanda, killing one civilian and burning at least 100 houses. The conflict apparently began when a man was heading to work in the fields and was killed by presumed Hutu Nyatura. Then, youth took up arms and attacked the Hutu families accused of collaborating with the combatants.The Hutu population was forced to flee to Nyanzale.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Aid Workers (Democratic Republic of Congo); UN: United Nations
column17: ""One male UN contracted driver was shot and killed when his truck was ambushed while transporting food items in South Kivu by Uvira town.""

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 21 February 2018. The same armed group that looted a field near Zigbi on 20/02, looted another field in the Zigbi area and burned down a house.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: The FARDC and FRPI clashed in the chiefdom of Walendu Bindi, in Ituri, on February 22nd. The FRPI attacked with 5 men through pillaging the population and their houses. At that point, the FARDC was alerted and tried to repel the militiamen. One of the soldiers was killed as well as a civilian.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: ADF and FARDC clashed in Mbau on February 22nd, causing displacement of the population towards Oicha and Beni. 2 ADF rebels were killed during the combat, including a woman. 2 weapons were retrieved.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Movement of forces: The FARDC deployed military to Djugu on February 24th, in order to support the police in countering the recent violence and vandalism observed.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The FARDC clashed with the Mayi Mayi on February 24 in Goma, resulting in 5 deaths (4 rebels and 1 soldier). Apart from injuring 9 rebels who are in the hospital, and capturing another 7, the FARDC also recovered some weapons. 3 soldiers and 1 policeman were injured during the fight.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: PPRDYL: Peoples Party for Reconstruction and Democracy Youth League
column17: On February 24, young leaders belonging to the PPRD movement 'invaded' the Notre Dame of Congo parish in Gombe, in order to express their opposition to the protest called for by the CLC to take place the next day.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 8 people were kidnapped on February 24th from Binza, between Nyamilima and Ishasha.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On February 25, a protest organised by the CLC took place in the Virunga neighbourhood of Goma. The police intervened and dispersed it, arresting 20 people.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Protests called for by the CLC took place in Lubumbashi on February 25. Youth in Lubumbashi burned tyres and were dispersed by riot police. One of them was arrested.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: CLC: Lay Coordination Committee
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 25 February 2018. In Mbandaka, CLC demonstrators attacked the police during the CLC demonstrations. 4 security officers were injured, as well as 4 demonstrators. One of the demonstrators was killed by a police officer while he was returning home. The police officer then fled the scene. In response to the killing, the youth set the police training centre in Mbandaka and the houses of a major and policeman on fire. [size=no report]

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: CLC: Lay Coordination Committee; Veranda Mutsanga
column17: In Butembo, the protests called for by the CLC were started by militants belonging to the Veranda Mutsanga civil movement and were later dispersed by police, who was ready to disperse protesters.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: CLC: Lay Coordination Committee; LUCHA: Fight for Change
column17: In Beni, the protests called for by the CLC were started by LUCHA militants, who started their march around the parish Saint Gabriel de Malepe. They were then dispersed by police who resorted to tear gas.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Protests called by the CLC to denounce the prolonged stay of President Kabila take place in Kinshasa and a number of cities across DRC despite being banned by the government. Police fired live bullets and tear gas in Kinshasa leaving two protesters seriously injured and two others killed. The DRC government blocked all access to internet and SMS during the protests. MONUSCO reports 100 arrests during the protests. PPRDYL members are also accused of having vandalised the national HQ of the CLC in Burumbu.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Protests called for by the CLC took place in Kikwit on February 25.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Protests called for by the CLC took place in Bukavu on February 25.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Protests called for by the CLC also took place in Kisangani on February 25. In Kisangani, at least two people were shot by policemen. Three priests were arrested.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The police and military surrounded Mbuji Mayi to prevent protests called by the CLC. At least four injured, some sources point to one death.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: In Tshopo, CLC protesters attacked the police during the protests called for by the CLC on February 25. 9 security officers were injured as well as 2 of the rioters.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Mazembe)

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia
column17: The Mayi Mayi Nyatura clashed with another Mayi Mayi faction in Mutanda, on February 25.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The Nyatura Love clashed with the FARDC in Bwalanda. Casualties amount to 11 people - 5 Nyatura love and 6 civilians. 7 civilians were injured during the attack.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Mazembe)
column17: The Mayi Mayi Nyatura attacked the Mazembe in Kalusi (Goma) and Kanyasi. 9 civilians were killed and at least 2 rebels were shot dead.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On February 25, unidentified armed men raided Kinyandoni and kidnapped a boy. A ransom was demanded for the return of the boy.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Mazembe)
column17: On February 25, the Nyatura Love attacked the Mazembe in Kanyatsi. 2 Mayi Mayi died.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On February 25, a man was kidnapped by unidentified armed men in Kamukwale, Rutshuru.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: After the attacks perpetrated on Sunday, the Nyatura attacked again on Monday, February 26. The target was Bwalanda, where 4 civilians were killed and 5 others wounded. The FARDC also killed 5 of the rebels.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Looting: Unidentified armed men attacked Kabare and Walungu in South Kivu on February 26th. In Walungu, they attacked 2 health centres, tying up a doctor and a pastor and stealing medicine and drugs. No mentioned injury.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Tchele Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On the night of February 26-27, 2018, a new attack was perpetrated in Tchele, Djugu, by unidentified armed men. 3 people were killed by machette, including one by civilians who took up arms to confront the group.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: At least 14 killed in clashes between Kamwina Nsapu on soldiers and police in Lembelu in Demba on February 26th.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On February 26, a FARDC soldier was killed by unidentified armed men in the Mugunga neighbourhood of Goma.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On February 26, a 43 year old man was killed in Kiwanja communal comune by an unidentified group of armed men.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column17: 27 February. In Kinshasa, a human rights defender was killed when police opened fire on demonstrators. [size=no report]

column17: ""Gunmen intercepted and abducted an INGO contracted driver and his assistant along the Mweso-Kalembe road axis. The vehicle was clearly marked. No additional information about their whereabouts is available at this time.""

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 28 February 2019. An unidentified armed man in military attire, who spoke Acholi and broken Lingala, abducted a woman from Gbatanabu, Dungu. The perpetrator tortured the woman while holding her hostage.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Armed men launched an attack in the localities of Lidjo, Tasti, Ukpa and Chachaku on March 1st, killing one military.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 2 people were killed in Kasumbalesa by unidentified armed men in the week of February 25-March 3.

column6: Lendu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Hema Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: A UN investigation carried out in March 2018 revealed that over 16 December - 14 March, 263 people were killed in violence between the Lendu and Hema ethnic groups, 29 injured and 120 localities and villages burnt down. Most of the victims hail from the Hema group. The violence took place in Djugu territory (Bahema-Nord, Walendu Tatsi, Walendu Djatsi, Walendu Pitsi, Bahema Banyuagi, Ndo Okebo and Mambisa). 163 coded in individual events in dataset; additional 100 coded in general events for December, January, February and March.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Looting: Armed men launched an attack in the localities of Lidjo, Tasti, Ukpa and Chachaku on March 1st. Goods were taken away by the attackers. No reported injuries.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On March 1, there was a search and rescue operation undertaken by Congolese police in Kavumu, Kabare. The police were attacked by unidentified armed men, and the police arrested 15 assailants.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Agreement: At least 50 former members of the Mayi Mayi, belonging to the Union of Patriots for the Defense of Innocents (UPDI) surrendered to the FARDC in Miriki, on March 2.

column6: Lendu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Hema Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On the night of March 1-2, renewed inter-ethnic conflict between the Hema and Lendu in Ituri left at least 34 killed (authorities' numbers). Other reports point to 40-49 people killed. The Lendu reportedly launched the attack.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: After the killing of one civilian, the drunken FARDC soldier was lynched by the local population.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On March 2, a drunken FARDC soldier shot customers in Kalungu village, killing one of them.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On March 2, a 50 year old woman was raped and strangled to death in the village of Chumirwa, in Shabunda.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

This attack comes after an attack the previous week around the region as well, during which a military was killed.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Agreement: 6 Mayi Mayi self-defense rebels presented themselves to Lubumbashi on March 4th, as part of the demobilisation plan put in force. This constitutes the 5th wave of rebels coming from Pweto.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Unidentified armed men murdered a couple in the quartier of Golf Kitoko, 5km from Kasumbalesa, on March 4th. These deaths bring the number of fatalities in Kasumbalesa up to 4 in a week.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019) Kahuzi-Biega National Park
column17: On 4 March, Raya Mutomboki gunmen kidnapped 27 Kahuzi Biega national park rangers from the village of Lulingu, Shabunda, and demanded a ransom.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 4 March, unidentified armed men kidnapped a 60 year old man from Kavegha village, close to Kihoma.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On March 5, the same day as the burning of several houses in the Kekpa group, 4 civilians were killed by an unidentified armed group in Loga group in the Walendu Tatsi area.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Property destruction: On March 5, unidentified armed men burned 5 villages in the grouping of Kekpa, causing the population to flee. No reported injuries.

One of the families launched an offensive against the other, killing 2 people by resorting to both machetes and calibre 12 guns. The other family replied, killing 2 more people, of whom one is a police man.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki)

The responsible actor is the Mayi Mayi Raia Mutomboki and the kidnapped people include 9 administrative employees and 9 guards. The kidnappers are demanding a large ransom, which is being negotiated.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 5 March, unidentified armed men attacked the village of Mangolikene in Beni. 4 women and 3 men were killed; 7 people are missing.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 5 March, armed men kidnapped 7 people in Kitabya, Lubero. They also set some houses on fire.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: An unidentified armed group attacked in Kalebuka, ending up shooting a civilian who was defending his wife, whom they wanted to rape. The man died.

column17: After an attack, the population got enraged and went out to the streets to protest the inaction of the police. The police tried to disperse the rowdy crowd who had started burning tires by resorting to tear gas, but the population then proceeded to raid the police's offices.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Civil society accuses FARDC of killing 2 civilians on March 6th and of setting fire to more than 40 houses in Tshimpanga, Dibaya. The FARDC was supposedly looking for a militia chief in Tshimpanga.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column17: On 6 March, unidentified armed men killed a FARDC soldier in Kamukwale, Rutshuru.

column6: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
column17: Presumed ADF rebels attacked the village of Mangolikene, in the south of Beni, killing 8. 10 people are currently missing.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On 7 March, the FARDC attacked the Mayi Mayi Mazembe in Musasa. One rebel died and another was injured.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On March 7 and 8, unidentified armed men carrying AK-47s attacked 10 localities in Djugu, specifically in the collectivities of Mambisa and Walendu Tatsi. A total of 8 people were killed.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 9 March, armed men attacked Logo, killing 3 people.

column17: On the night of 10-11 March, unidentified armed men looted in Kasumbalesa and used fire arms against civilians, injuring 2 of them. A police car who was going to intervene fell down a ravine.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column17: 12 March 2018. The LRA abducted four civilians, including two women, in the Banda area. On 17 March, two of the women and one of the men were released.

column17: On 12 March, unidentified armed men killed a man in Kiteraga.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On 13 March, during the robberies perpetrated by soldiers this night, one person was injured by bullets in Kananga.

column17: On 13 March, the FARDC killed a civilian in Murambi, Kalehe territory.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On 13 March, after the ADF killed three civilians in Nyaleke, they were attacked by the FARDC, who killed 2 of them.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 14 March, a woman was killed by unidentified armed men in Mulekera commune, in Beni. The attackers broke into her house and shot her twice.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: Vigilante Group (Democratic Republic of Congo); Refugees/IDPs (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 15 March, the head of the police in Mudzi Pela, Bunia, was killed in an IDP camp by revolting IDPs. The police officer went to the rescue of provincial minister Didi Angaika, who had been taken hostage by the IDPs in the camp, during his visit accompanied by the National Institute of Professional Preparation. The minister and some others in his delegation were taken hostages, and when the police intervened, they used tear gas and shots in the air to disperse the crowd. The head of the police was nonetheless hit by a stone in the head, falling dead just after.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Between January-April, report of over 10 targeted killings as well as kidnappings and looting by unknown gunmen stationed at Virunga National Park. 10 fatalities spread over four events between January and April.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 16 March, a group of armed men kidnapped 5 people in the territory of Mambasa. The hostages managed to escape on March 18.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 16 March, a group of armed men broke into a house in Walungu and killed a civilian.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army

column17: On March 18, the FARDC were attacked by the ADF in Sesele. One soldier died.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Over 23-24 March, unknown assailants clashed with the FARDC in Penyi and Jeli in Djugu territory, Ituri. 14 confirmed killed including one soldier and 13 assailants. Other reports also mentioned an attack in Mbachulu, in Ituri.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: UNAFEC: Union of Nationalist Federalists of Congo Party
column17: On March 25, there were protests in the locality of Yaisule in Isangi territory, Tshopo province, headed by UNAFEC protesters. In order to disperse the protests, the police fired shots into the air. The protests were waiting for the arrival from the parliamentary assembly. Later reports mention that several civilians were injured including with machete wounds and that some houses were burned, pointing to potential violent behaviour by the UNAFEC militants.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On March 25, presumed ADF attacked the FARDC in Kokola. 1 soldier was killed and 1 other was injured during the attack. The attack was repelled by the FARDC.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Mazimano)
column17: On March 25, the Mayi-Mayi Mazimano broke into a house in Simba village, close to Lemera, in Uvira, and kidnapped a man, for whom they demanded a $1,500 ransom.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: On March 26, LUCHA militants took to the streets to protest in front of the MONUSCO offices in Goma, before police fired teargas to disperse them. 5 protesters were injured as they forced their way into the MONUSCO offices while the police was firing teargas; a police officer was also injured when he tried to fire teargas. The protesters in case wanted to leave the memorandum, which asked the UN Security Council to vote for a new resolution for its mandate in DRC, vouching to guarantee free and peaceful elections.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: On March 26, LUCHA protesters in Mavivi, Beni, gathered to hand in a memorandum asking MONUSCO to guarantee free elections in DRC. Police repressed the protests. 6 protesters were injured, including one severely.

column6: FDLR-RUD: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda-Rally for Unity and Democracy
column17: On March 26, the FDLR-RUD attacked a house in Rusaka 5 village, next to Nkwenda, demanding money. The owner of the house was then shot and killed because he did not comply with their orders.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On March 27, at night, the ADF attacked Buhili, in the Rwenzori commune, Beni, taking three civilians hostage. After the attack, the ADF were intercepted by the FARDC. The clash lasted for 30 minutes, after which 10 civilians, including the 3 hostages, were killed.

column6: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
column17: On March 27, at night, the ADF attacked Buhili, in the Rwenzori commune, Beni, taking three civilians hostage. After the attack, the ADF were intercepted by the FARDC. The clash lasted for 30 minutes, after which 10 civilians, including the 3 hostages, were killed.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 28 March 2018. An unidentified armed group attacked three hunters near Kpanga, Bas Uele. One of the hunters was killed and another was injured.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: CNPSC: National Coalition of the People for Congo's Sovereignty
column17: On March 28, the Mayi-Mayi CNPSC attacked the FARDC position in Ibwe village, close to Lubondja, in Fizi. 5 soldiers were killed, 10 were injured and 2 rebels were captured.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On March 28, unidentified armed men broke into a house in Ibinza village, close to Izege, and killed two civilians.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On March 28, people in Buhili in Rwenzori commune near Beni protested the ADF killings in the area the previous evening. Motorbike riders joined the protesters setting up barricades on the road.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On March 29, Mayi Mayi rebels attacked a house owned by president Kabila in Kabasha, region of Rwenzori. The Mayi Mayi claim they killed three soldiers; the army claims one soldier and one rebel were killed.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On March 29, a policeman and a soldier were killed by unidentified armed men in Bukavu.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On March 29, FARDC soldiers and police officers arrested costumary/community chief Vincent Mukanganyi in Luiza. According to reports from the Association for the Promotion of Human Rights (APRODH), the captain was tortured on the day of the arrest.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On March 29, two unidentified armed men killed a man in Goma.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: PPRD: Peoples Party for Reconstruction and Democracy
column9: PPRDYL: Peoples Party for Reconstruction and Democracy Youth League
column17: On March 30, there were confrontations between police and youth belonging to the PPRD in Matadi in Central DRC. The confrontations started after police prevented the PPRD from accessing the provincial assembly, after which youth forced their way into it holding machettes. Several windows and cars were broken or hit.

column6: Christian Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Property destruction: In response to the killing of a Catholic man by a Muslim over a private matter the day before, a group of Catholic men burned down the man's house and the mosque in Budjala and chased away Muslims, forcing them to flee to the forest.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On March 31, unidentified gunmen killed 2 people in the Kiwele neighbourhood of Rwashi. People rioted after the event, barricading roads and burning tires on the roads. Three people were injured during the riot, including a police officer.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On March 31, unidentified gunmen killed 2 people in the Kiwele neighbourhood of Rwashi. People rioted after the event, barricading roads and burning tires on the roads. Three people were injured during the riot, including a police officer.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia
column8: Private Security Forces (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: ICCN: Congolese Institute for Nature Conservation
column17: On April 1st, a group of Mayi Mayi attacked the hydroelectric central of the Virunga Society in the locality of Ivingu, in Lubero, killing a security guard attached to the ICCN.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Catholic Christian Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On April 1st, a priest - Celestin Ngango - was kidnapped along with 9 other people in Nyarukwangara, close to Kiwanja, when he was on his way back from Nyarukwangara, in Rugarama from Easter celebrations. The priest was released five days later after a ransom was paid, but the assailants killed three of the other 9 people that had been kidnapped.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column9: Catholic Christian Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On April 1, unidentified armed men held a vehicle carrying the Karambi parish priest and his parishioners close to Buhindangoma, next to Kasenga. A ransom of $500,000 was demanded for his release.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On April 1, the FARDC attacked the Raia Mutomboki Donat and Mabala in Lwigi and Bwise villages of Shabunda territory. One rebel was captured and an AK-47 was retrieved.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On April 1, the FARDC shot at a group of assailants who were robbing civilians in Uvira. During the pursuit, they managed to capture one of the assailants, who was a FARDC soldier.

column6: FDLR-RUD: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda-Rally for Unity and Democracy
column17: On April 2, the FDLR-RUD kidnapped 6 women in the vicinity of Buseregenye, close to Kinyandoni. They raped the hostages and demanded a ransom of $3,000 for their release.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On April 2, the Mayi Mayi Malaika attacked the FARDC in the village of Kibimbo, in Fizi. A FARDC soldier was injured.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On April 2, FARDC soldiers killed four civilians in the mining centre of Salamabila, in the territory of Kabambare.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On April 2, unidentified armed men attacked the village of Bele, grouping of Ngbavi, in Djugu, with the intention of stealing crops and goods. The locals warned the authorities, which arrived at the scene and clashed with the assailants killing 4.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On April 3, unidentified armed men kidnapped a man from his house in Buhuria village in Rutshuru territory, close to Rubare, and demanded a $1,250 ransom for his release.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On April 3, unidentified armed men kidnapped a man in Uvira, demanding a $1,250 ransom for his release.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On April 3, unidentified armed men tried to stop a vehicle in Kashenyi village, in Walungu. They shot at passengers, killing one and injuring ten others.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On April 3, the Nyatura FDP ambushed the FARDC in the village of Gitunva, close to Bishusa. Fatalities among both sides but unknown number.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: On April 3, the FARDC attacked the FRPI positions in Kigo, a village 3 km away from Geti. The FRPI subsequently attacked the state forces in Geti and in Kimamba, with the help of forces coming from Seneka. 3 fatalities - 2 rebels and 1 soldier. The same source reports that a sergeant from the FARDC was killed, another soldier injured and 2 AK-47s taken by the FRPI.

column6: Unidentified Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On April 4, unidentified men who tried to steal fishing material killed a 34 year old man on Kivu Lake, close to Chondo village in Kalehe.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Angola)
column17: On April 5, unidentified armed men killed a man close to Bunake village, in Beni.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On April 5, assailants stole 15 cows from Kizoki village, close to Makobola. The FARDC attacked the assailants and repelled them. One soldier was injured and one rebel killed.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On April 5, a FARDC soldier shot 2 men in Kanyabayonga. One man died and the other was injured.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki-Mabala)
column9: Christian Group (Democratic Republic of Congo); ADECO: Alliance of Congolese Democrats
column17: On April 5, Mayi Mayi Wemba stopped a convoy with ADECO Christians, who were leaving for a pilgrimage. 37 people were abducted.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Agreement: On April 5, 60 Malaika rebels surrendered to the authorities in Kabambare.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: 06 April 2018. A group of LRA combatants, shot and killed a hunter 5 km from Masombido, Bas Uele.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Angola)
column17: On April 6, 10 unidentified armed men broke into the house of Kavingu's cell chief in Beni and abducted him.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On April 6, the FARDC attacked the Mayi Mayi in Kitwa-Muke village, close to Mabuku. 5 rebels were captured.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On April 6, the Mayi Mayi attacked the FARDC in Kasiki. Two soldiers and one civilian killed.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On April 6, the FARDC attacked attacked the Mayi Mayi in Kalemie, with the intention of displacing them. The attack left 13 killed - 11 rebels and 2 soldiers - 3 captured rebels and 5 seized AK-47s.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On April 6, the Mayi Mayi Mazembe attacked the FARDC positions in Mwalika, Beni, with the intention of destabilising their operations. The attack was countered by the FARDC and a clash ensued. Three rebels captured, among which the commander Kambale Mboka Eric. According to FARDC captain capitaine Mak Hazukay, the Mazembe are teaming up with the ADF to take back Mwalika.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Angola)
column17: On April 7, unidentified armed men killed a man in Mayangose, close to Kitobi, in Beni.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Angola)
column17: On April 7, unidentified armed men raped and killed a 25 year old woman in the Pasisi neighbourhood of Beni. The victim's body was found the next morning.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On April 7, when the civilians were later being accompanied by the FARDC, the unidentified armed men who had killed a man attacked again.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura)
column9: Catholic Christian Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On April 8, a Catholic priest - Etienne Sengiyumva - was kidnapped in Kyahemba, which is between Mweso and Kitshanga, by the Nyatura. The priest was later found shot and dead. The attack was reportedly undertaken by only one man. This attack comes one week after another priest had also been kidnapped in North Kivu.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On April 8, unidentified armed men attacked the Mayi Mayi Mazembe in Kanyatsi and killed one rebel.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: 09 April 2018. Three LRA combatants looted a motorcyclist near Soronga. They requested that he go buy supplies for them. The combatants told him they were part of an LRA group moving from CAR into the DRC.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On April 9, the Mayi Mayi Mazembe attacked the Kalunguta village in Beni. They started the raid, but were quickly interrupted when police arrived. Shots were fired in the air and the chiefdom chief's hut was burned down, alongside with his motorcycle. They only left when the FARDC joined the police forces.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019) Eco-Guards
column17: On April 9, five rangers and a driver were killed in an ambush in Virunga National Park by suspected Charles militia. One other ranger was also injured. This attack comes one week after another park ranger was killed in the same location.

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: On the night of April 8-9, the FRPI attacked the village of Kandana Singo in Walendu Bindi, Irumu. The attackers pillaged the village and scared the population off, who fled to nearby locations. During the attacks and the robberies, one merchant was killed.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On April 10, Mayi Mayi rebels attacked Kalunguta, 25km south-west of Beni. The attack turned into a clash between police and rebels.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: On April 10, the FARDC, supported by MONUSCO, recovered 10 localities, among which Gbi, Joo, Cafe and Nyamamba in Djugu, which are along the riverside of Lake Albert until Tchomia.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On the night of April 9-10, the chief Karakara, of the militia that bears his name, was killed alongside 2 guards and one woman who belonged to his militia in a military operation in Rugenge, 20km north of Uvira. The group was partly responsible for the insecurity in the Ruzizi plains, and had established coalitions with foreign groups such as the Burundian FNL. Karakara had been a FARDC chief before joining the revolution in 2013.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: On April 10, the FARDC, supported by MONUSCO, recovered 10 localities, among which Gbi, Joo, Cafe and Nyamamba in Djugu, which are along the riverside of Lake Albert until Tchomia.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: On April 10, the FARDC, supported by MONUSCO, recovered 10 localities, among which Gbi, Joo, Cafe and Nyamamba in Djugu, which are along the riverside of Lake Albert until Tchomia.

column6: Rioters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: After the attack by armed men on April 11, the population rebelled and rioted against the police, burning tires in the street.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: Aid Workers (Democratic Republic of Congo); UN: United Nations
column17: ""One male national UN contracted driver was injured during a reported altercation with a DRC Armed Forces (FARDC) Officer. The staff member was taken to the Baraka hospital and later transferred to Bukavu hospital the following day.""

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On April 11, a group of armed men tried tried to rob civilians in Lubumbashi. After trying to rob money and not managing, they decided to return, but their passage was blocked by a cadet. The armed bandits turned violent and shot him 4 times, apart from injuring his sister. The cadet died and his sister died as well due to the wounds.

column6: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Between 12 and 17 April, ADF attacked FARDC 6km north of Semuliki. 12 soldiers killed and more than 50 injured

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On April 12, civilians in Sankuru, Lubefu, took justice into their own hands and killed 2 police officers. This attack came after the brother of one of the civilians who took up arms died at the police station (cause unreported). The villagers also burned the commisary building and recovered the body of their dead companion.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On April 13, the FARDC clashed with the Mayi Mayi Mazembe in Kasithu village in Beni and repelled them.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On April 13, unidentified armed men killed a woman in Vuhumbi, Beni.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: 13 April.A FARDC officer killed by Mai-Mai group in Kalolo

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Looting: After the fight with the Mazembe, and while searching for them, the FARDC looted villages in the region.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On April 14, unidentified armed men attacked the FARDC in the Ngadi neighborhood of Beni, close to Boikene, and were repelled by the latter.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On April 14, the FARDC attacked the Mazembe position in Maghutu village, in Beni.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On April 14, unidentified armed men kidnapped a man in Kasambiryo, close to Mabuku, in Beni.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On April 14, before the unidentified armed men attacked the FARDC, they forced a man to carry bananas to the Ngadi neighbourhood of Beni, killing him just after.

column6: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: 14 April. FARDC units got surrounded by ADF in Mayimoya and required MONUSCO attack helicopters for support

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On April 14, the ADF attacked the FARDC position in Beni. The attack was repelled by the FARDC - one rebel was killed and another captured.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Weapons Seizure: On April 13, weapons were found in the farm of a deceased general, Laurent Nkunda, chief of the ex-movement of CNDP, in Kasunguru, region of Masisi. The operation to recover the weapons was launched on April 14. Bombs were found alongside ammunition, rocket launchers, among others. It was the customary chief of Bashali Kaembe - Mwami Kaembe - that alerted the FARDC to the existence of these weapons.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Between January-April, report of over 10 targeted killings as well as kidnappings and looting by unknown gunmen stationed at Virunga National Park. 10 fatalities spread over four events between January and April.

column6: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
column17: Agreement: Around 60 children left the FRPI group in Ituri between April-June 2018.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On 15 April, a FARDC soldier shot dead a taxi driver in Misisi village in Fizi territory after refusing to pay for his fare.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On 15 April, the Nyatura FDP captured and killed a FARDC soldier in Rugari village in Rutshuru territory.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Mazembe)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 15 April, unknown armed men clashed with the Mayi Mayi Mazembe in Karambi village in Lubero territory.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki)
column17: 15 April (on or around). During mid-April, Raia Mutomboki groups raped at least eight women in the areas of Kamungini, Kiluma, and Keba (no coordinates are available for any of the villages), in the Shabunda territory.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki)
column17: 01-30 April. Raia Mutomboki raped at least five women in the areas of Busolo and Kabogosa (no coordinates available), along the Shabunda-Walungu border.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Women (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: For two consecuritve days on April 16-17, women came out to the streets to demand the construction of a route to evacuate the water coming from the Nyangara towards Lake Tanganyika. Due to heavy rains, several houses are flooded and many people are displaced.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On April 16, unidentified armed men attacked a Fusso truck in Kanyamahoro, in the region of Kibati, killing one student.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Mazembe)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 16 April, the Mayi Mayi Mazembe clashed with armed men in Masika village in Lubero territory. Similar clashes occurred the day before in Lubero.

column6: Unidentified Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 16 April, unknown gunmen broke into a house in the Buturande neighborhood of Kiwanja in Rutshuru territory during the night, looting money and goods and kidnapping a woman for whom they later demanded a ransom.

column6: Unidentified Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 16 April, unknown gunmen raided Nkwenda village in Rutshuru territory, looting goods and kindapping a man for whom they later demanded a ransom.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 16 April, unidentified gunmen took positions on the road close to Lupango village in Uvira territory and shot dead traders driving back from the Rubanga market. On the same day, unknown gunmen also kidnapped two men in Uvira territory (from Cotonco village) demanding a $10,000 ransom.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: On April 16, the FARDC clashed with the ADF in the region of Garlic, 50km north of the city of Beni. 2 helicopters belonging to MONUSCO supported the FARDC with airstrikes.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki-Donat)
column17: On 16 April, the Raia Mutomboki Ngandu/Donat raided Keba and Wamery villages in Shabunda territory, looting goods and abducting eight people.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: In April, two more people killed by unidentified armed in Kalehe area. Human rights associations claim there are several displaced people in the area armed with fire weapons. They seem to have settled in Ramba.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Women (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: For two consecuritve days on April 16-17, women came out to the streets to demand the construction of a route to evacuate the water coming from the Nyangara towards Lake Tanganyika. Due to heavy rains, several houses are flooded and many people are displaced.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Looting: On April 17, unidentified armed men attacked the village of Kibati, pillaging 22 houses and forcing the residents to flee.

column6: Unidentified Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 17 April, unknown gunmen fired at a mini bus on its way from Butembo to Oicha, wounding seven. The assailants also burned down two houses and looted stores in the area.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 17 April, unknown gunmen kidnapped two civilians in Kapsa village in Rutshuru territory and asked for a ransom.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 17 April, unknown gunmen wearing FARDC and police uniforms forced two young boys to show them the way to Ngite village in Nord Kivu and beheaded them.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Mambasa Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On April 17, the FARDC clashed with a new group in the village of Nyekeke, in Mambasa. The militants were repulsed by the armed forces during a patrol. They reportedly fled, leaving behind 6 AK-47s. There were several injured on the militants' side.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: 18 April 2018. The LRA stopped three hunters and forced them to lead them to Makpangi. Once in the village, the combatants looted food and other items.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On April 18, 4 bodies were found close to Kibati.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura)
column8: APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
column17: On 18 April, a clash broke out between APCLS and Nyatura Domi combatants at a meeting in Bunkuba village in Rutshuru territory. Nine APCL members and four Nyatura killed and one injured.

column6: APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 18 April, APCLS combatants attacked a position of unidentified armed men in Kilambo village in Masisi territory.

column6: Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column7: Students (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column8: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column9: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On April 18, students took the streets to protest the kidnapping of another student the previous Sunday in Mugunga, periphery of Goma. The police tried to disperse the crowd during their walk to the cabinet of the province's governor, but did not manage. During the struggle between them, the police used tear gas to disperse them, and was aided by the military. Some students were received in the cabinet of the governor.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On April 18, a coalition of Raia Mutomboki Ndarumanga and Kokodikoko clashed with the FARDC in the mining site Parking, in Shabunda. The rebels arrived from the grouping of Baliga, and engaged in a 30 minute fire exchange, resulting in the killing of one soldier. Local workers and the population fled the site.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Malaika)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Agreement: During the two weeks prior to April 30, around 1300 Malaika rebels surrendered in Wamaza.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: Movement of forces: On 19 April, arrival of strongly armed LRA in the forest of Gangala, Nasombo, Naparka and Bambangana around Doruma.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Nyatura) Love Faction
column17: On 19 April, Nyatura love militants broke into the house of the Chumba local customary chief in Rutshuru territory. They shot him dead along with two other members of his family.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Raia Mutomboki)
column17: On April 20, the Raia Mutomboki attacked the locality of Bimpanga in Shabunda. Civil society claims two women were raped and 20 people were kidnapped to help them carry looted goods. This was the third attack in Shabunda this week.

column6: Beni Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 20 April, unknown gunmen shot and killed two men close to Kasitu village in Beni territory. The assailants stole the victims' motorcycle. On the same day, unknown gunmen also killed another civilian in Beni territory (Mangolikene village) while he was returning from his field.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On 20 April, police forces repressed a peaceful demonstration of former members of the Coopec Imara, which went bankrupt in 2013, in the Ndendere neighborhood of Bukavu. One civilian injured.

column6: ADF: Allied Democratic Forces
column17: On 20 April, ADF gunmen killed a motorcycle driver and his client close to Tungudu village in Beni territory. They were on their way to Ndalya market in Ituri. The FARDC chased and attacked the ADF forces right after the attack, killing one ADF.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On April 20, the FARDC clashed with the ADF on the Beni-Kasindi axis, 15km north-east of Beni. Six fatalities in total in two separate attacks outside Beni on that day. These attacks come as a way of discrediting the FARDC owing to the recent recaptures of territory in the 'triangle of death' in between Mbau-Kamango and Eringeti, in Beni. The ADF is moving in small satellite groups around the region, launching attacks were possible, in order to counter the FARDC.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: On 20 April, ADF gunmen killed a motorcycle driver and his client close to Tungudu village in Beni territory. They were on their way to Ndalya market in Ituri. The FARDC chased and attacked the ADF forces right after the attack, killing one ADF.

column6: Lubumbashi Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On the night of April 21, unidentified armed men with the intention of looting broke into a house and killed a woman and her baby in the Kisanga area of Lubumbashi. Similar attacks are reported to occur daily in Lubmbashi.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: ""Two unarmed security guards at an INGO compound were administered an unknown drug in order to incapacitate them and facilitate a break-in into three different INGO offices on the compound. The perpetrators stole vehicles and laptops. Both of the security guards required medical attention.""

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On April 22, armed men raided the locality of Kau, in Djugu, and kidnapped 8 people. They first attacked the village of Dolo, where a 30 year old man was injured, and then proceeded to kidnap civilians in Kau.

column6: Lubumbashi Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On April 22, unidentified armed men with the intention of looting broke into a house in Mukuntu area of Lubumbashia, opening fire on three members of family and raping the fourth member, a young girl. Similar attacks are reported to occur daily in Lubmbashi.

column6: LRA: Lords Resistance Army
column17: 22 April 2018. An LRA group, containing women and children, looted travelers along the road as they returned from the Manbungulu market in Bas Uele.

column6: Batwa Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Looting: On April 22, the Twa militia attacked Kagoba, in Kalemie, pillaging the local market stands. People fled in fear.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On April 22, unidentified armed men kidnapped a 64 year old man from Mahungubwe.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On April 22, a soldier killed another soldier in the Boikene neighbourhood of Beni. One soldier had misbehaved, and the FARDC deployed a platoon to address the issue. The platoon commander tried to reprimand him, but was shot and died.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: CNRD: National Council for Renewal and Democracy
column17: Non-violent activity: On April 22, CNRD rebels chased three policemen out of Katsiru after considering them personae non gratae. The policemen fled to Kitchanga. Despite the presence of the FARDC on Katsiru, the CNRD have a base 2km away, and can exert their influence, often coming to the city to extort habitants.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On April 22, the head of the Mayi Mayi Raia Mutomboki Mabala - Kikukala Wemba - was killed during a clash with the FARDC in Lutika. The rebels had gathered in Lutika after the attacks perpetrated in Bampinga and Parking the previous week. The clash lasted two hours, after which the chief Kikukala Wemba was shot. The other 12 rebels then fled, and Wemba succumbed to his injuries.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On the weekend of April 21-22, ""rebels"" attacked the FARDC positions in Langbe. There was exchange of shots.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Enyele Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On April 22, the Enyele attacked the FARDC position in Dongo in Sud-Ubangi, Equateur, killing 2 soldiers, one agent of the financial authorities and injuring one police officer. The FARDC killed 4 assailants and captured another 3. At least 40 people drowned while trying to cross the river into the Republic of Congo to flee the violence.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On the weekend of April 21-22, ""rebels"" attacked the FARDC positions in Tchuki (grouping Buku). There was exchange of fire.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On April 23, unidentified armed men attacked the FARDC position in Ntoto. One soldier and one assailant died.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Agreement: On April 23, the leader of the Hapa na pale militia - Misano - surrendered to the FARDC in Makutano, alongside his troops. The local civil society organisation disclosed that before he joined Hapa Na Pale militia group, Misano was one of the traditional chiefs in Bena Mambwe chieftaincy

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column8: Enyele Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: 23 April. Enyele militias attacked a FARDC position in Mobambo killing two soldiers

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On the night of April 23, the FARDC clashed with the Mayi Mayi Karakara in the village of Kigoma west of Sange in South Kivu. Two rebels who intended to avenge their brother Karakara who had been killed in Rugeje two weeks prior were killed. Among the rebels was the young brother of Karakara, who had taken up arms after the death of his sibling. The rebels were in the village of Sange when they fell into an ambush by the FARDC.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On April 25, unidentified armed men kidnapped a man from Rutsiro village, Rutshuru, and demanded a ransom.

column6: Mayi Mayi Militia (Malaika)
column17: On April 25, Mayi Mayi Malaika rebels attacked the village of Kabulongo, in Shabunda, abducting a man and looting goods and livestock. After the Malaika had left, the FARDC ambushed and captured two of them.

column6: Unidentified Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Property destruction: On April 25, unidentified armed men broke into a farm in Tahiro village, Uvira, and killed 17 cows, injuring another 39.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On April 25, Mayi Mayi Malaika rebels attacked the village of Kabulongo, in Shabunda, abducting a man and looting goods and livestock. After the Malaika had left, the FARDC ambushed and captured two of them.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On April 25, tensions escalated in Kpandroma in Djugu during a livelihood distribution as displaced people protested unfair distribution and began pillaging goods; the police forces fired shots to disperse the rioters. Two killed - a baby who fell from the back of his mother while she was stealing goods and was stomped on by the crowds; another from the police gunshots.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: Arrests: On 25-26 April, police and FARDC forces arrested 28 people in Kisangani and Kabondo accused of causing insecurity in the area.

column6: Police Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On April 25, LUCHA protesters organised a peaceful march in Beni against insecurity in the country.
